The meaning is that though He has he far entered into the extrinsic potency of maya and is imma- bonent within the conditioned individual being (mayike) asi orbits indwelling Self (antaryami), by His own innate potency) (svarupa-Å›akti), He remains situated in His own intrinsic being (sva-svarupa), meaning that He is not in contact with mÃ¤yÃ¤. à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤°à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥‹à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤œà¥ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ tom This other witness [ká¹£etrajÃ±a] is distinct [from the jiva], because He is the knower or witness of all ká¹£etras due to being Vasudeva [the shelter of all beings]. [In contrast, the ká¹£etrajÃ±a described in the previous verse knows only its own ká¹£etra.] This means that the other [Supreme] witness is distinct from the jiva who is deluded by mÄyÄ. Being utterly free [from the influence] 8 The verb avadhiyamana, which is glossed by the word avasthapyamana (isted established), is in the passive voice. The use of the passive would imply that there is another agent who is doing the action of placing or situating, but ÅšrÄ« Jiva is clarifying that there is no other such agent; ParamÄtmÄ accomplishes this by His own agency of intrinsic potency. Because this does not involve any effort on His part, the passive voice has been used. This follows the more sensible reading, so’paro mÃ£yÃ£-mohitaj jivÄƒd anyoâ†’ 102 11 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self of maya, this other witness is the pure ká¹£etrajÃ±a and the ÄtmÄ (the Self), which here refers to ParamÄtmÄ, or the Supreme Immanent Self. For these reasons also, the primary quality of ká¹£etrajÃ±a is found only in ParamÄtmÄ. à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥€à¤¡à¥‡" (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥ª à¥¤ à¥¨à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ notisluger This is stated by Daká¹£a: “Although a jiva can know all these [the body, the senses, and so on], as well as the gunas of primordial nature, he does not know the omniscient unlimited Bhagavan whom I worship” (SB 6.4.25).10 the ordinan) Commentary IN THE FIRST BOOK of the á¹¢at Sandarbhas, i.e., Tattva Sandarbha, ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmi established the Bhagavata Purana as the supreme authority in the field of metaphysics. He also concluded that the Bhagavata Purana, which embodies the essence of the Vedas (see SB 1.1.2), primarily delineates the three topics of sambandha, abhidheya, and prayojana. Sambandha means the relation between Absolute Reality (tattva) and Its energies. The cosmos is a manifestation of two energies in the form of the individual living beings (jivas) and pri- mordial nature (praká¹›ti or mayÄ). To understand sambandha, or relation, it is necessary to understand the sambandhi, or the refer- ent of the relation. In Bhagavat Sandarbha, the author explained in detail who the Absolute Reality is. In this book, he focuses on the individual beings and primordial nature, the two constituents of the cosmos, and their regulator, ParamÄtmÄ, a partial manifesta- tion of the tattva called Bhagavan. Bhagavat Sandarbha began with the citation of an important verse from Srimad Bhagavata Purana: mÄyÄ-rahitaá¸¥, which is found in the Krama-sandarbha and some manuscripts of Paramatma Sandarbha. ? The word also appears in the last quarter of SB 5.11.13 in the locative case, “in the Self” (Ã¤tmani); there it has been glossed as sva-svarupe, “in His own intrinsic being.” Ese 10 sarvam pumÃ¤n veda gunamÅ› ca taj-jÃ±o na veda sarvajÃ±am anantam ide no 12Tinonamel om 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined to gofono T the All those who have realized Absolute Reality (tattva) describe that Pho Reality as nondual consciousness (advaya-jÃ±Äna). That Reality is t referred to as Brahman, ParamÄtmÄ, and Bhagavan. (SB 1.2.11)" Bhagavat Sandarbha and ParamÃ¤tma Sandarbha together form an extended explanation of this verse, which refers to Absolute Reality by the three appellations, Brahman, ParamÄtmÄ, and Bha- gavan. Brahman and Bhagavan were the subject matter of Bhagavat Sandarbha. ParamÄtmÄ will now be elaborately explained in this volume; hence, it is called Paramatma Sandarbha. ParamÄtmÄ was defined by Åšri Jiva GosvÄmi in Bhagavat Sandarbha as follows: on moo bluoda midtbane fovan When this tattva in the form of Bhagavan, which has all the above- stated qualities and is the complete manifestation of Absolute Real- ity, is described or realized as the controller/regulator of living beings by the process described before, He is called ParamÄtmÄ, or God as the Supreme Immanent. (Bhagavat Sandarbha, Anuccheda 3) The definitive feature of ParamÄtmÄ is His controlling or regu- lating power (aiÅ›varya). Individual beings are never fully indepen- dent, either in their conditioned or liberated state. As discussed in Bhagavat Sandarbha, there is only one supremely independent Reality, called Bhagavan, which ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va GosvÄmi has identified as ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a along with His various lila-avataras, such as RÄma. In other words, the aspect of Krsna that embodies the regulatory or controlling function is called ParamÄtmÄ. In the spiritual world, Vaikuntha, Bhagavan Himself acts as ParamÄtmÄ, but in the mate- rial world He takes a special ParamÄtmÄ form. This is the subject of this Sandarbha.dandi honovoga molt i A doubt may be raised here. In the verse cited above (SB 1.2.11), Absolute Reality (tattva) is sequentially named as Brahman, Param- ÄtmÄ, and BhagavÃ¤n. Based on this order, it might be expected. that ParamÄtmÄ Sandarbha would come before Bhagavat Sandarbha, and not vice versa. There are two reasons for this reversal of order. 11 vadanti tat tattva-vidas tattvam yaj jÃ±Änam advayam brahmeti paramatmeti bhagavan iti sabdyate 13 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self First, there is no separate Sandarbha for the explanation of Brah- man. According to ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmi, Brahma Sandarbha is con- tained within Bhagavat Sandarbha. Consequently, because Brah- man is to be explained previous to ParamÄtmÄ, as per the order of words in SB 1.2.11, Bhagavat Sandarbha, which contains Brahma Sandarbha, must come prior to ParamÃ¤tma Sandarbha. Brahman is the manifestation or realization of Bhagavan devoid of qualifica- tion. Thus, Brahman cannot be comprehended without knowing Bhagavan. 13 BAYThe second reason is that according to the hermeneutic princi- ple, “The order according to meaning overrides the word order,” Bhagavat Sandarbha should come before ParamÃ¤tma Sandarbha, because Bhagavan is the source of ParamÄtmÄ as well as of Brah- man. To understand these two in truth, knowledge of their source is indispensable. ParamÄtmÄ is the regulator of the material energy, called mÄyÄ or praká¹›ti, which manifests the cosmos, and also of the individual living beings conditioned by the material energy. Material energy conditions a living being by covering his self-awareness and by pro- viding him with a material body. To understand the Controller, it is also necessary to understand the controlled. Hence, ÅšrÄ« Jiva cites two verses spoken by Jada Bharata to King Rahugana that delineate both the characteristics of the individual self and ParamÄtmÄ in relation to phenomenality, or mayÄ. Both are here called ká¹£etrajÃ±a, i.e., “the knower of the presentational field,” meaning the witness of the field of all phenomena, both internal and external, that are presented to consciousness. Like many verses in the BhÄgavatam, these two also involve a certain ambiguity in that they do not overtly state that the ká¹£etra- jÃ±as they describe are different from each other. The verses could therefore be interpreted from the monistic point of view, which holds that there is only a single consciousness that appears both as 12 ato’tra brahma-sandarbho’py avantarataya mataá¸¥ Bhagavat Sandarbha, Anuccheda 7 13 pathakramÄd artha-kramo baliyan MahÄbhÄá¹£ya on PANINI 1.1.58 Jon bns 14 HR manammi s 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined to golino sell 1 the individual beings as well as ParamÄtmÄ. In his commentaries to both the previous and following verses, ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ« does make the statement that the two ká¹£etrajÃ±as are different, as ParameÅ›vara and jiva, a fact acceptable to all Vedantis. ÅšrÄ«dhara, however, seems to lean toward the monistic view by saying, “The ká¹£etrajÃ±a, witness to the three states of wakefulness, dreaming, and deep sleep, is the ÄtmÄ, i.e., the Reality (tattva).” ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmÄ« clarifies the mat- ter in his commentary, with special reference in the next subsec- tion (1.2) to Bhagavad Gita, where the subject of ká¹£etra and ká¹£etra- jÃ±a is discussed. He specifically chooses these two verses so that one cannot misconstrue the radical monistic theory of the self’s absolute identity with Brahman. The word ká¹£etra, which literally means “a field,” is often used to signify the physical body. Just as seeds are sown in a field, grow and produce some fruit, the physical body serves as a field of action, karma, which is the seed from which the fruits of happiness or mis- ery are produced. One who knows the field and its modifications is called ká¹£etrajÃ±a (jÃ±a means “a knower”), so it is applicable both to the jiva and ParamÄtmÄ, who is the companion of each jiva in the physical body. Nevertheless, though both are ká¹£etrajÃ±as, they are not equal. The jiva misidentifies with the two types of material bod- ies, physical (gross) and psychical (subtle), which are products of mÄyÄ. The subtle body is the psychic apparatus attending the jiva, which includes the mind along with the five cognitive senses, the five conative (or active) senses, and the five divisions of the vital force (prÄna). These two types of bodies are called the upadhis of the jiva. bat Upadhi means “limitation,” “condition,” “adjunct,” “nomencla- ture,” or something external that has been superimposed upon and limits an object or entity. When a red rose is in proximity to a crys- tal, the latter reflects the color of the rose and appears reddish even though by nature it is colorless. This reddishness is the upadhi of the crystal. Similarly, a jÄ«va, who is in reality pure (suddha), or in other words, transcendental to mÄyÄ, as stated in SB 5.11.12, appears to reflect or possess the modifications of the mind in the form of happiness and misery when in their proximity.(m)or 15 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self The mental modifications are the upadhis of the jiva, because they impose a limitation on the pure nature of the jiva. The gross body is another upadhi, restricting the awareness of the jiva within its bounds. The mind is here called the “impure agent” (aviÅ›uddha- kartuá¸¥). The mind itself is inert by nature and has no inherent agency. It exhibits consciousness only by the association of the ká¹£etrajÃ±a, the individual conscious being. Once it is intelligized, it makes use of the senses and the vital force to perform action and thus becomes an agent. It is called impure because it functions only for its own independent and separative interest, in non-awareness of Bhagavan, who is the source and proprietor of everything in the cosmos. Not acknowledging the existence and ownership of Bhagavan is the impurity of the mind. food bowos It should be noted that the term jiva can be used to indicate the living entity, both in its pure, transcendental, and eternal nature, as well as in its conditioned state. Therefore, the term jivopÃ¤dhi has been used by the commentators to gloss the word jivasya, appearing in the verse, in order to clarify that it is the adjuncts or upÄdhis that are a product of illusion (mÄyÄ) and not the living entity itself. The jiva considers the happiness and misery occurring in the body to be its own and thus remains absorbed in these feeling tones, ignorant of its own true nature, which is transcendental, beyond all material happiness and misery. Therefore, although the jiva is distinct from matter, it considers itself to be material. In this state, it engages in materialistic, non-integral pursuits, trying to fulfill its material desires. This conditioning of the jiva has no beginning, meaning that it is without prior cause, and hence it is causeless." It is for this reason that the vá¹›ttis, or mental modifications, are called nitya. Here, the word nitya (lit., “eternal”) does not mean that they are always manifest, but that their flow has no beginning. Every vá¹›tti is temporary but there is a continuous flow of them in the 14 A cause is defined as that which must invariably exist prior to the effect that it produces. So if something is beginningless, it must be without cause. The reason why the jiva’s conditioning is stressed as being beginningless (i.e., causeless) is to refute the idea of original sin, or of a falldown from Vaikuntha, or of an 10 inceptive choice to come to the material world from an intermediate region (taá¹­astha), or other misconceptions that are rampant in the Vaisnava world. ad 16 Ha? som sm 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined to golotno sri waking and dream states. The vá¹›ttis of the mind are perceived by the jiva in those states, while in deep sleep there is no experience arising from either of the two types of bodies. There is no external experience in this state. The other ká¹£etrajÃ±a is ParamÄtmÄ. He also witnesses the phys- ical and psychical bodies of the jiva but is not influenced or condi- tioned by them. This is exemplified in the Mundaka Upanisad (3.1.1) by the allegory of two birds sitting on a tree out of which one eats the fruits of the tree and the other simply looks on. The reason for this is that ParamÄtmÄ is svayaÃ±-jyoti, or self-luminous. He is not dependent on anyone else for His existence, knowledge, or power. Being an expansion of Bhagavan, He is inherently endowed with many of the same powers. Thus, unlike the jiva, He never comes under the sway of the extrinsic energy, mÄyÄ. ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi notes that the verb avadhiyamÄna (“is being placed,” or, “is established”) in the second principal verse of this anuccheda (SB 5.11.13) is in the passive voice (karma-kartá¹›) in the phrase, “who is established in the Self by His own maya.” The use of the passive voice could be interpreted to imply that maya is the agent who has caused ParamÄtmÄ to be placed interior to the indi- vidual self. ÅšrÄ« Jiva clarifies, however, that Paramatma’s establish- ment in the Self is not effected through any external agency, but rather by virtue of the potency that is innate to His own being (sva-mayaya), meaning through His own intrinsic potency (sva- svarupa-Å›akti). This confirms the independent status of Bhagavan, who performs actions through His own energies. Furthermore, the word Ätmani (“in the Self”) here is taken to mean “in His own Self” rather than “within the individual self,” which ÅšrÄ« Jiva explains as meaning “in His own intrinsic being” (sva-svarupa). The word purusa (person) here has a particular significance. Etymologically, it means “one who reposes in the city.” The “city” (pura) signifies the bodies of living beings and therefore, like ká¹£etra- jÃ±a, puruÅŸa can refer to either the individual self or ParamÄtmÄ, who is present as a witness in each body. As will be made clear in Sections 2-4 of this volume, the word puruÅŸa refers to the three aspects of Bhagavan, the puruá¹£ÄvatÄras, who expand from Him for 17 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self the sake of facilitating the creative unfoldment of the cosmos. In one of these aspects, He is present as the indweller in every body as the Immanent Self.thodshower headpik golais The word vÃ¤sudeva (from the verbal root âˆšvas, “to reside”) sim- ilarly indicates that Bhagavan as the Immanent Self knows all bod- ies because He resides in them and is therefore the prime ká¹£etra- jÃ±a. The living being is the secondary ká¹£etrajÃ±a, since it knows only one particular body. This will be explained further with recourse to Bhagavad GitÄ. 1.2 ParamÄtmÄ Is the Knowable and the Primary Knower of All Fields à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§-à¥¨ ) Furthermore, it is said in the Gitopanisad: ibo à¤‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¥Œà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¯ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¬ à¥¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤ à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤œà¥ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¤® à¥¥ à¥­ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ This body, O son of Kunti, is called the field (ká¹£etra) and the one who knows it is called the knower of the field (ká¹£etrajÃ±a) by Bthose who have directly intuited both the field and its knower.d Tale O Bharata! Know Me also to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a situated within o kall ká¹£etras whatsoever. In My view, knowledge of the field and of [both these] knowers of the field is what is meant by [true] knowledge. (GITÄ€ 13.1-2)15 à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤–à¤²à¥ â€œ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ 15 idam sariram kaunteya ká¹£etram ity abhidhiyate etad yo vetti tam prahuá¸¥ ká¹£etrajÃ±a iti tad-vidaá¸¥ ká¹£etrajÃ±aá¹ cÄƒpi mam viddhi sarva-ká¹£etreá¹£u bhÄrata ká¹£etra-ká¹£etrajÃ±ayor jÃ±Änaá¹ yat taj jÃ±Änam mataá¹ mama ysgada lotosgas 18 al tonemal sme1 ParamÄtmÄ Definedo golot T Here, in the statement, “and know Me also to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a,” [the words “and” (ca) and “whatsoever” (api) are to be syntac- tically applied as follows:] “And in all fields whatsoever, you should know Me also to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a. [I am] not like the jiva, whose knowledge is restricted only to its own individual field.” This alone is the intended meaning of the statement. à¤¨ à¤š à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤µ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¤à¤¿ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥ˆà¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€œà¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¥¤ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿- à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¶à¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤®à¥à¤–à¤®à¥ â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤š à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾- à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤…à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥©à¥¤à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤¤à¤¥à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ By pointing out that both IÅ›vara and the individual self have a common substratum [i.e., that they both share the character- istic of being knowers of the field], [Krsna here] is not indicat- ing that the substantive Reality to be known (i.e., the know- able - jÃ±eya) is consciousness alone devoid of all attributes. If that were the case, the phrase “within all ká¹£etras” would be redundant. Moreover, the knowable (jÃ±eya) is pointed out [in the same chapter of the Gita] as being specifically inclusive of attributes. This is indicated in GÄªTÄ€ 13.12, “I shall now describe that [Reality] which is to be known (jÃ±eya),” and in GITÄ€ 13.13, “That [Supreme] knowable has hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads, and faces all around.”"" Again, in GÄªTÄ€ 13.7-1118 knowledge (jÃ±Äna) too will be defined in precisely the same manner [i.e., knowledge too is of a substantive inclusive of attributes and not that of unqualified consciousness]. à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤š " à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° â€œà¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¤¿ â€ ( à¤›à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥®à¥¤à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ " à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥" à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥‚à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ â€œ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ 16 jÃ±eyam yat tat pravaká¹£yÄmi bas The term jÃ±eya (knowable) as it is used here assumes that the Reality being spoken of is naturally endowed with qualities by which It can be known. The implication is that an entirely unqualified entity is inscrutable and hence unknowable (ajÃ±eya). 17 sarvataá¸¥ pÄá¹‡i-padam tat sarvato ‘ksi-siro-mukham 18 amÃ¤nitvam adambhitvam à¤°à¥‡ 19 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self Moreover, if Krsna’s intention in the phrase, “know Me also to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a,” had been to define knowledge as pertaining to an Absolute Reality utterly devoid of attributes, by equating their shared conscious substratum, as in the mantra, “You are That” (tat tvam asi, CHU 6.8.7), then Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a would have said, “In My view, knowledge of the ká¹£etrajÃ±a and IÅ›vara is [true] knowledge” and not “knowledge of the field and of [both these] knowers of the field.” ES à¤•à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ - à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤ƒ " ( à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥¦ à¤¸à¥‚à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥©à¥¤à¥¨à¥¦) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤®à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯- à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ â€“ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¥¤ Tsub However, the meaning of the statement, “knowledge of the ká¹£etra and of ká¹£etrajÃ±a, in My opinion, is what is meant by knowledge,” is as follows: “Knowledge of both items inclusively, of ká¹£etra and ká¹£etrajÃ±a, is considered to be knowledge of Me alone, because the purpose of such knowledge is exclusively the knowledge of Me (ParamÄtmÄ), as stated in the Brahma-sutra, “The deliberation (paramarÅ›a) on the individual self is in order to know the other (anyartha) [i.e., the Supreme Self]” (vs 1.3.20)19 This is in keeping with the fact that the knowable (jÃ±eya) is stated to be only one (GITA 13.12), and it is indeed appropriate [because the Reality to be known has already been described in BhÄgavata Purana (SB 1.2.11) as nondual in nature]. à¤¨ à¤š à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤®à¤¾à¤®à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥‡- à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Nor is it right to interpret the word “knowledge” as it is in the non-theistic Sankhya philosophy, which understands it to mean merely [realization of] the distinction between the field (ká¹£etra) and its individuated knowers (ká¹£etrajÃ±a), because in GÄªTÄ€ 13.2, the pronoun mÄm (Me) necessitates the inclusion of a Supreme Knower, i.e., IÅ›vara (iÅ›varasyÄpeká¹£itatvÄt).asaloge 19 anyÃ¤rthas tu paramarÅ›aá¸¥ Baladeva Vidyabhuá¹£aá¹‡a: jiva-paramarÅ›aá¸¥ paramÃ¤tma-jÃ±ÄnÄrtha eva. ads at tilimi (msg) sidewonin 20 152 ponami ss 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined logolaino str à¤¨ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¤¦à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤­à¥à¤°à¤®à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¸à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾- à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥Œà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¬à¥Œà¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ Nor can we agree with the vivarta doctrine that the personhood (puruÅŸatva) of God (IÅ›vara) is but an appearance born out of illu- sion, because then His words in the form of revealed scriptures, such as the GitÃ¤ along with the Vedas, would be rendered unau- thoritative, thus insinuating the Buddhist philosophy. Such being the case, it would be just as illogical for the proponents of vivarta-vÄda to comment on these scriptures as it is for the Buddhists. à¤¨ à¤š à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¤à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¯à¥‡â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤à¥§ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¹à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤š â€œà¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¿â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤ à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿- à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ â€œà¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥¨à¥¤à¥­ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Nor can it be argued that even if the personhood of God (Isvara) is admitted to be real, we must still draw on [relevant] state- ments from Isvara’s other revealed scriptures, wherein it is stated that knowledge of the unqualified Absolute (nirviseÈ™a- jÃ±Äna) alone is the means to liberation. [This is indefensi- ble] because the intention of the previous chapter of the GitÄ (Chapter 12) was to show the inferiority of such knowledge [in response to Arjuna’s question in the first verse]. In that very chapter, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a made the following statement in regard to His exclusive devotees: “But I quickly become the liberator of those who offer all actions to Me, who are wholly devoted to Me, and who worship Me, meditating on Me through the yoga of exclusive devotion. O Partha, without delay I lift them up from the ocean of repeated birth and death because of their singular absorption in Me” (GITA 12.6-7)20 Here Bhagavan does 20 ye tu sarvÃ¤ni karmani mayi sannyasya mat-parahat olmo ananyenaiva yogena mam dhyÄyanta upÄƒsate teá¹£Äm aham samuddharta má¹›tyu-samsara-sÃ¤garÄt bhavami nacirÄt pÄrtha mayy Ã¤vesita-cetasam 21 12 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self not regard knowledge of the unqualified Absolute as having any relevance [for liberation]. à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¾ â€œà¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¤¸à¤¾â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥¦à¥¤à¥©à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ bood Bhagavan Himself confirms the same in the Eleventh Canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: “Whatever may be attained by perform- ing meritorious acts (karma), penances, the culture of jÃ±Äna, non-attachment, yoga, charity, religious virtue (dharma), or any other means of ultimate welfare, is easily attained by My devotee simply by engagement in bhakti-yoga to Me. Although My devotee does not desire anything except Me, if at any time he should somehow desire heaven, liberation, or residence in My abode, he can very easily attain any of them” (SB 11.20.32-33).1 à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤š - And in the Moká¹£a-dharma [of Mahabharata]22 it is said: the ____ à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤°à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥® à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ 91832 af the Brahmu bergan od fi (16) 201 1897 90 of betlimbs at A person who has taken refuge in Bhagavan NÄrÄyaá¹‡a achieves the four goals of human life even without [recourse to] the appropriate means [generally] employed for attaining them.23

à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¾à¤˜à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤‚ à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§à¥®) â€” ) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤šà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯ à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥¯ à¥¥ 20 202 tshem say he vbloiup I toa” asstowab svianfoxs all à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤²à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ 21 yat karmabhir yat tapasÃ¤ jÃ±Äna-vairagyataÅ› ca yat yogena dana-dharmena Å›reyobhir itarair api sarvam mad-bhakti-yogena mad-bhakto labhate’Ã±jasÄƒ 22 This verse is not found in the mula of the critical edition. According to Baladeva (GITA 12.7), it is from the NÄrÄyaá¹‡iya. It is quoted in Sundara Bhatta’s commentary to Mantra-sodasi 9. ÅšrÄ«dhara Svami quotes it in SB 11.29.5 without naming a source text. 23 yÄ vai sadhana-sampattiá¸¥ puruÅŸartha-catustaye tayÄƒ vinÄƒ tad Äpnoti naro nÄrÄyaá¹‡ÄÅ›rayaá¸¥ yoq or invold 22Tisa menami sa 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined Toygolotu aff Here again [in the 13th chapter of the Gita], so that the specific praises [of the personhood of God] made in the previous chap- ter do not go in vain, and after indicating that knowledge means knowledge of the qualified Absolute [in verses 13.7-11], ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a concludes by saying that such knowledge is easily attainable if pursued along with devotion: In this way, the field (kÅŸetra), knowledge (jÃ±Äna), and the know- able (jÃ±eya) have been described in brief. Knowing this, My devotee attains My nature. (GITÄ€ 13.18) 24 e atta In the G à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤ à¤à¤µ à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾- à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤‚ à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤à¥¨à¥§) - Therefore, in this verse of the Gita, only the knower of the individual field (vyaÅŸÈ›i-ká¹£etrajÃ±a) is identified as the devotee, whereas the knower of the aggregate of all fields (samaÅŸti- ká¹£etrajÃ±a) is the [Substantive Reality] to be known (jÃ±eya). So here, after reminding us of this by citing the knowable (jÃ±eya) together with the knowledge of the field and its knowers, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a continues in the following verses by showing that the jiva- nature of the individuated knower [vyaÅŸÈ›i-ká¹£etrajÃ±a] and the isvara-nature of the aggregate knower [samaÅŸti-ká¹£etrajÃ±a] are both imperishable: wa à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤­à¥à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¦ à¥¥ he Mfferent The living entity situated within material nature experiences the qualities born of that nature [such as happiness and sorrow]. 24 iti ká¹£etram tatha jÃ±Änaá¹ jÃ±eyaá¹ coktam samÄsataá¸¥ Wollnt ont ni mad-bhakta etad vijÃ±Äya mad-bhÃ¤vÃ¤yopapadyate ons navegada el 19 We have translated mad-bhÄvÄya as “attains to My nature,” but there are several different translations given by the various commentators. The Vaisnavas favor translating bhÄva as love, but this does not seem appropriate here. Further on in this commentary, ÅšrÄ« Jiva himself translates it as sÄrsti, or “[the liberation of attaining] equal rank, condition, or power as the Lord.” Upapadyate is often glossed by the commentators as yogyo bhavati, or “becomes qualified [for such liberation].” The primary meaning, however, is “reaches” or “attains.” 23 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self The cause of its birth in species of greater or lesser evolution-H geary complexity is its association with the gunas of primordialanq an nature. (GÄªTÄ€ 13.21)25 tsoibnisatie bas niev nt og jon ob net à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿- à¤¤à¤®à¥ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥¨à¥¨ ) - ing à¤‰à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤š à¤­à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤­à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤®à¤¹à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¥‡à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥§ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥ˆà¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ ough By indicating that the jiva is situated within material nature, from which it logically follows (svataá¸¥) that it is beyond matter (aprÄká¹›ta), Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a clearly teaches here that the jiva is imperish- able (aká¹£ara). Then, by pointing out that the [supreme conscious being or] PuruÅŸa known as ParamÄtmÄ is superior to the jiva, He shows a fortiori that He is imperishable: 62 (pysht) aworl RESTSHW (ontorised (The other PuruÅŸa residing in the body is known as the witness,d the sanctioner, the sustainer, the maintainer, the almighty reg- ulator, and also the Supreme Self (ParamÄtmÄ). All these embodied beings (bhÅ«ta) are ha perishable, whereas the immutable [self] (kÃ¼á¹­a-stha) is called the imperishable. But different from these two is the Supreme PuruÅŸa, called ParamÄtmÄ. He, the imperishable regulator, enters the three worlds and then sustains them. (GÄªTÄ€ 15.16-17)27 à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¥€ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ (sanctioner) means “He who inspires the living beings in accordance with their past actions”; bharta (sustainer) means “He who provides nourishment”; bhoktÄ (maintainer) means “the protector”;28 maheÅ›vara (the almighty regulator) means “the superintendent of all”; and paramÄtmÄ (the Supreme Self) means “the indweller in all.” This is how the words are to be explained. à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥‚à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥ â€œà¤à¤•à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥€ à¤¸ à¤•à¥‚à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤°à¤•à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤¾- à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤¤à¥‹à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤—à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤•à¤¦à¤¾à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Regarding the next two verses quoted above (GITA 15.16-17), the word kuá¹­a-stha (the immutable [self]) means “one who does not undergo change through time,” according to Amara-kosa (3.1.73).29 This is the pure individual conscious being (suddha- jiva), because in the very next verse it is said, “But different from these two is the Supreme Purusa (uttamaá¸¥ puruá¹£aá¸¥), called ParamÄtmÄ.” Thus, here also [in GITÄ€ 15.16-17], the field (ká¹£etra), the knower of the individual field (ká¹£etrajÃ±a), and the knower of 27 dvav imau puruÅŸau loke ká¹£araÅ› caká¹£ara eva ca ká¹£araá¸¥ sarvÄni bhÅ«tÄni kÅ«á¹­asthoâ€™ká¹£ara ucyate uttamaá¸¥ purusas tv anyaá¸¥ paramatmety udahá¹›taá¸¥ Vyo loka-trayam Ävisya bibharty avyaya isvaraá¸¥ non bis 2890 zuotoshop Isubiv dai suosnons diw 28 The verbal root âˆšbhuj carries both the sense of enjoyment or consumption and that of protecting or governing. 29 eka-rupataya tu yaá¸¥ kala-vyÄpi sa kÃ¼á¹­asthaá¸¥ mb sis in snotti 25 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self the aggregate of all fields (sarva-ká¹£etrajÃ±a) are being indicated [as corresponding to the three divisions of ká¹£ara-puruÅŸa (the perishable body), aká¹£ara-puruÅŸa (the imperishable self), and uttama-puruÅŸa (the Supreme Self)]. By use of the word “differ- ent” (anya) [in GITA 15.17], Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a indicates that the latter two imperishable beings are indeed different. It is not possible for them to give up their respective natures. By this it is also shown that they never exist without attributes. SBSH THISIST à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€œà¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯- à¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¹à¥€à¤¨à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯- à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤° à¤à¤µ à¤­à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ Therefore, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s statement, “He attains My nature” (mad- bhÄvÄyopapadyate, GÄªTÄ€ 13.18),3Â° also means that he attains the same status or condition as Bhagavan (sÃ¤rá¹£á¹­i) [not an attribute- less state of liberation]. The import is that although both are equal in terms of their imperishability, the jiva is the one who is captivated by material nature due to its inferior strength, and to dissolve this captivation, IÅ›vara alone is to be known as the Reality meant to be worshiped. Commentary Astairsas F ASIST galbraya hotcup 292190 owl txen a (alon)Voldetudiat edi) pt-out brow In this portion of the first anuccheda, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va discusses Chapter 13 of Bhagavad Gita where the concepts of ká¹£etra and ká¹£etrajÃ±a are introduced, along with an elaborate discussion of PuruÈ™a and praká¹›ti. This analysis is also further related to the correspond- ing portions of the Gita’s 15th chapter. In both these chapters, Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a not only differentiates between conscious- ness and non-conscious phenomena, but also between the indi- vidual consciousness and the supreme conscious entity, or Param- ÄtmÄ. In the course of doing so, it is necessary for ÅšrÄ« Jiva to deal with erroneous interpretations of these passages that deny any distinction between the two kinds of conscious beings. Id 30 In some editions of the Gita, this is verse 13.19. by old day at Aro 26 1192 inonammi 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined logolinos ÅšrÄ« Jiva begins by referring to Krsna’s words in GITA 13.1-2, which identify the presence of two distinct ká¹£etrajÃ±as in the body, i.e., the individual ÄtmÄ and ParamÄtmÄ. In doing so, he refutes vivarta-vÄda, the Advaita doctrine that acknowledges the existence of only one ÄtmÄ, otherwise called Brahman. The statement, “And know Me also to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a residing in all ká¹£etras,” clearly affirms that besides the individual self there is another ká¹£etrajÃ±a. This is the implication of the word ca (also). An individual ÄtmÄ knows only one particular ká¹£etra, but ParamÄtmÄ knows them all. To emphasize this point, the verse employs the compound sarva-ká¹£etresu, “in all bodies” (GITA 13.2)3150 audi Moreover, the word ca highlights the distinction between the individual self and the Supreme Self. Sankara’s radical nondual- istic (kevaladvaita) philosophy adopts the view that there is one absolute, unqualified Reality called Brahman, which manifests as ParamÄtmÄ when delimited by pure sattva-guna (i.e., perpet- ual being unmixed with rajas and tamas) and as the individual ÄtmÄ when delimited by sattva-guna mixed with the other gunas.32 Adherents of this doctrine claim that there is no ultimate differ- ence between the two ká¹£etrajÃ±as. For them, the one unqualified conscious Reality is the ultimate and unique substantive to be known, jÃ±eya. Everything else is ultimately mithya, or devoid of ontological reality. iw bae bauons lis 250 Bus While commenting on this verse (GÄªTÄ€ 13.2), ÅšrÄ« ÅšankarÄcÄrya writes: nove sansa and nevada ad nos ad H SI Know Me, the Supreme Regulator, who am transcendental to con-d ditional existence, to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a, endowed also with the above- ton mentioned characteristics, and present in all ká¹£etras. The impli- cation here is that the ká¹£etrajÃ±a is [apparently] distributed in all bodies beginning from Brahma and extending down to immovable forms by virtue of the limitations imposed by these bodies. Know the ká¹£etrajÃ±a to be devoid of all these divisions or limitations, and Mas imperceptible [i.e., unknowable] through the notions conveyed 31 ká¹£etrajÃ±aá¹ cÄƒpi mam viddhi sarva-ká¹£etreÅŸu bhÄrata 32 Vide Vedanta-paribhÄá¹£Ä 1; Vedanta-sÃ¤ra 7; PaÃ±cadaÅ›Ä« 3.40, 1.16; Vicara-sagara 4.88-89. 27 42 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self Sby words such as sat (cause) and asat (effect). (Bhagavad Gita, Sankara-bhÄá¹£ya 13.2) 33i ÅšrÄ« Jiva refutes Sankara’s interpretation by arguing that were this the case, the compound sarva-ká¹£etresu, “in all ká¹£etras,” would be redundant, as the one who knows all bodies would be identi- cal with the one who knows the individual body. Then he would have used the word eva instead of api (i.e., ká¹£etrajÃ±aá¹ eva mÄm viddhi, “Know Me alone to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a”), and sarva-kÅŸetreÅŸu would serve no additional purpose because there would be only one ká¹£etrajÃ±a. Thus, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a does not instruct that there is one absolute unqualified consciousness that alone is real but which appears as many by the influence of mÄyÄ. Moreover, later in GITA 13.2, Ultimate Reality is stated to be knowable (jÃ±eya). An object devoid of form, energies, and quali- ties cannot be knowable. Furthermore, the knowable is described as qualified, not as devoid of attributes. This contradicts the Advai- tavÄda concept that Ultimate Reality is unqualified indivisible con- sciousness alone that appears as many due only to the upadhis in the form of material bodies. The qualified nature of the knowable is expressed as follows: bus mitu si ai viilsel auobanoo That [Supreme] knowable has hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads, and faces all around, and with ears in all directions. It abides, pervading everything in the world. (GITA 13.13)34 linW In this po of Here the affirmation that Bhagavan has senses and limbs, even though they are of an all-pervading nature, shows that they are real and that He is thus a conscious being with senses and not mere unqualified consciousness. Furthermore, the knowledge described in verses 13.7-11 also pertains to a Reality inclusive of attributes, because ceaseless exclusive devotion is counted as one 33 ká¹£etrajÃ±aá¹ yathokta-laká¹£aá¹‡am capi mam parameÅ›varam asamsariá¹‡aá¹ viddhi jÄnÄ«hi. sarva-ká¹£etreÅŸu yah ká¹£etrajÃ±o brahmadi-stamba-paryantÃ¤neka-ká¹£etropadhi- pravibhaktaá¸¥. tam nirasta-sarvopadhi-bhedam sad-asad-adi-sabda-pratyayago- caram viddhity abhiprÄyaá¸¥. 34 sarvataá¸¥ pÄÅ†i-pÄdam tat sarvato ká¹£i-siro-mukham sarvataá¸¥ Å›rutimal loke sarvam Ã¤vá¹›tya tisthati 28 He tusasum am 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined logolato fi of its elements (verse 10, mayi cananya-yogena bhaktir avyabhicÄƒ- riÅ†i). Such devotion is not possible toward an unqualified substan- tive. If there were no real distinction between the individual wit- ness (jiva-ká¹£etrajÃ±a) and the Supreme Witness (isvara-ká¹£etrajÃ±a), any instruction to the former to be devoted to the latter would be meaningless. The radical nondualists may reply that such instructions are only meant to help the conditioned self to realize its Brahman nature. They claim that worship of God is an intermediary step for less intelligent practitioners. For example, Nilakantha, while commenting on GÄªTÄ€ 12.2, writes: Î¤ÎŸ sagunaod doua While indicating the superiority of nirguna [meditation], specifi- cally because it is said to be difficult to attain, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a speaks the present verse, linguistically affirming the importance of saguna [worship]: “Those who worship (i.e., meditate upon) Me as the Supreme Isvara, do so with their minds constantly fixed upon (i.e., entering) Me (the qualified Brahman), being endowed with supe- rior (i.e., sÃ¤ttvika) faith (Å›raddha), meaning belief in My personal berexistence, or in other words, with the conviction that by worship- ing ParamÄtmÄ, they will certainly be delivered by Him. In reality, it is the jÃ±Änis [AdvaitavadÄ«s] whom I look upon as My very Self, as previously stated, ‘I regard the jÃ±ÄnÄ«s as My very Self’ (7.18). Yet, being omniscient, I take the side even of such fools [the saguna wor- shipers] out of compassion for them, and it is in this sense only that I consider them as the best of those who are united with Me.” (BhÄva-dipa 12.2)35 B at reword batsuhiv silt modw riftw This is how the AdvaitavadÄ«s interpret Krsna’s reply to Arjuna. But if the jiva believes that he is identical to this IÅ›vara, which cer- tainly is the case for those who aim at nirguna Brahman realization, how could he be sincerely devoted to Him? If a non-devotee actor 35 nirgunasya duÅŸprÃ¤ptvoktyaivaá¹ Å›reá¹£á¹­hatvam sucayan saguna-prÄÅ›astyaá¹ ca sabdato darÅ›ayan Å›rÄ«-bhagavan uvÄca mayÄ«ti. mayi sagune brahmani mana Ävesya praveÅ›ya ye nitya-yuktaá¸¥ sadodyuktÄ mÄm parameÅ›varam upasate cintayanti Å›raddhaya astikya-buddhya paraya sÃ¤ttvikyÃ¤ “avaÅ›yaá¹ paramÄtmÄ’yamÄrÄdhito. ‘smÄms tÄrayiá¹£yati” ity evam niscaya-rupaya Å›raddhayÄ upetÄs te me mama â€œjÃ±ÄnÄ« tvÃ¤tmaiva me matam" iti jÃ±Äninam atmatvenaiva pasyato murkheÅŸv api kÄrÅ«á¹‡yÄt paká¹£apÃ¤tavataá¸¥ sarvajÃ±asya yuktatamÄƒ matah.annsydiga matÄá¸¥. 29 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self on stage plays the role of a devotee and another that of God, can the former’s show of devotion be considered genuine? Certainly not. An actor can make a portrayal of devotion but that would not ben- efit him spiritually. Indeed, from the point of view of bhakti theol- ogy, to regard oneself as identical to Isvara would be tantamount to an offence. Jiva raises the following question: Some say that the common conscious substratum (sÄmÄnÄdhikaranya) of the two ká¹£etrajÃ±as described in GÄªTÄ€ 13.1-2 should be interpreted according to the famous statement from Chandogya Upanisad (6.8.7), “You are that” (tat tvam asi). In this interpretation, called pratibimba-vÄda, the pronoun “that” here refers to the unqualified unlimited conscious- ness and the pronoun “you” to the conditioned or limited con- sciousness. Though the two are not equal in our experience, one being unlimited and the other limited, they can be understood as such through the analytical principle of bhaga-tyaga-laká¹£aá¹‡a, or discarding one part of a statement to obtain the correct meaning. Here, if the adjectives “unlimited” and “limited” are dropped, then what remains is “consciousness.” Then “you,” the conditioned reality, can be equated with the unconditioned reality. In other words, a conditioned jiva (tvam-padartha) can be equal to the qual- ityless reality (tat-padartha) only if its conditioning is dropped. In the same way, the Advaitavadi may argue that in the GÄ«tÄ verses under discussion, the purpose of mentioning two types of ká¹£etrajÃ±a is to offer instruction about the qualityless reality called Brahman, with whom the individuated knower is equated, just as is done in the mantra from the Chandogya Upanisad cited above.mitre ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va replies that if such were Krsna’s intention, He would have expressed Himself differently and said, “Knowledge of the ká¹£etrajÃ±a and IÅ›vara is called knowledge” (ká¹£etrajÃ±a-iÅ›varayor jÃ±Änam yat taj jÃ±Änam) instead of “Knowledge of the field and its knowers is called knowledge” (ká¹£etra-ká¹£etrajÃ±ayor jÃ±Änaá¹ yat taj jÃ±Änam). The statement tat tvam asi (“You are that”) teaches the iden- tity of the limited consciousness, i.e., the individual living being referred to by the pronoun tvam or “you,” and the unlimited or 30 Het inenamm! sm 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined la volino will all-pervading consciousness called Brahman, referred to by the pronoun tat or “That.” It does not, however, teach the identity of the inert material body (ká¹£etra) and the supreme consciousness (IÅ›vara). Jiva GosvÄmi here reads the verse somewhat differently from the way it is taken customarily. He joins mama (My) with jÃ±Änam (knowledge) rather than matam (view). Thus, the sentence, instead of reading, “In My view (matam mama), knowledge of the field and the knower of the field is [true] knowledge (jÃ±Äna),” is construed as “Knowledge of the field and the knower of the field is understood (mata) to be knowledge of Me (mama jÃ±Änam).â€ The intent is that knowledge of the body, the individual self, the Sup- reme Self, and the interrelations between them is meant to lead to an understanding of the Supreme Person, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. To support this argumentation, ÅšrÄ« Jiva refers to a sÅ«tra (vs 1.3.20) from the Daharadhikarana of the Brahma-sutra, where a section of the Chandogya Upaniá¹£ad (8.1.1 ff.) is under scrutiny. The Upanisad states that there is a tiny (dahara) lotus-like space (ÄkÄÅ›a) in the “city of Brahman” (i.e., the body) and that one should seek out and inquire into that which dwells in that space. What then is this space? It could mean the material element of ether (bhÅ«tÄkÄÅ›a), the individual self (jiva), or Brahman / VisÅ†u. The first part of the Daharadhikaraá¹‡a (vs 1.3.14-17) establishes that this “sky” (ÄkÄÅ›a), a word that is also used to indicate Brahman, cannot be the material element ether. The next portion of the adhikarana raises the possibility that the dahara is a reference to the individual self, as indicated fur- ther in CHU 8.3.4, but then refutes this proposition: “If it is argued that because there is a reference to the other, namely the jiva, in the dahara section, and that therefore ÄkÄÅ›a means the jiva, this is denied as impossible” (itara-paramarsat sa iti cen nÃ¤sambha- vÃ¤t, vs 1.3.18). In the section of the Chandogya Upanisad to which this sutra refers, the word prajapati refers to the jiva, and it is pointed out that when the jiva meditates on Brahman, the eightfold 31 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self qualities appear in him. These qualities naturally exist in Brah- man, not in the jiva. Thus, the word dahara does not refer to the jiva but to Brahman, by meditation on whom the jiva is endowed with the eightfold qualities. the poin After this, another doubt is raised: “Why, then, is there a ref- erence to the jiva in this section related to dahara” (i.e., CHU 8.3.4)? This question is answered by sutra vs 1.3.20 cited by ÅšrÄ« Jiva here in Paramatma Sandarbha, “The deliberation (parÄƒmarÅ›a) on the individual self is in order to know the other (anyartha) [i.e., the Supreme Self].” The meaning here is that the reference to the jiva is intended to impart knowledge of the Supreme Brahman. It indicates that when a jÄ«va attains perfection, it also becomes endowed with the eightfold qualities (as in CHU 8.1.5) belonging to the Supreme Reality. In other words, although it appears that the Chandogya Upani- sad is describing the jiva, its intention is to explain the nature of the Supreme. Likewise, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va says that although Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a is describing ká¹£etra and ká¹£etrajÃ±a in the verses cited, His intention is to disclose knowledge about Himself, because the jÃ±eya, the sub- stantive Reality to be known, is expressed in the singular. If there were two jÃ±eyas (a ká¹£etra and a ká¹£etrajÃ±a), the dual number would have been used. Moreover, since Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a is the Ultimate Reality, as ÅšrÄ« Jiva has established in Bhagavat Sandarbha, He is that which is most worthy to be known (jÃ±eya), because knowledge of Him includes knowledge of everything else, as stated in the Mundaka Upanisad: “O most honorable one, what is that Reality by knowing which all this becomes clearly known” (MUU 1.1.3)?37 Jed One may misconstrue that Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s teachings in this section of the GitÄƒ speak only of ká¹£etra and ká¹£etrajÃ±a, the former referring to praká¹›ti and the latter to purusa, the two ontological categories of the classical Sankhya philosophy of Kapila, and that therefore He is just 36 ÄtmÄpahata-pÃ¤pmÄ vijaro vimá¹›tyur visoko vijighatso’pipasaá¸¥ satya-kÄmaá¸¥at air satya-sankalpaá¸¥ 37 The Supreme Self is free from sin, old age, death, grief, hunger, and thirst. He has infallible desires and infallible will. kasmin nu bhagavo vijÃ±Äte sarvam idam vijÃ±Ätaá¹ bhavati 32Ha insnemmt sm 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined golon confirming the classical Sankhya view. ÅšrÄ« Jiva disagrees with this idea because Kapila does not himself mention IÅ›vara, the Supreme Person, but in GÄªTÄ€ 13.2, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a says mam (Me), which implies that there is a third reality beyond material nature and the individual living beings. This is confirmed later in Bhagavad GitÄ: ematea ved blow noin vulli sonia vibodios on sved blow There are two kinds of purusas in this world - the perishable and the imperishable. All these embodied beings (bhÅ«ta) are perish- able, whereas the immutable [self] (kÅ«á¹­a-stha) is called the imper- ishable. But different from these two is the Supreme PuruÈ™a, Pascalled ParamÄtmÄ. He, the imperishable regulator, enters the three worlds and then sustains them. (GÄªTÄ€ 15.16-17)38 Here ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a clearly mentions three divisions of ontolog- ical being the ká¹£ara-puruÅŸa (the self conditioned by a perish- able body, baddha-jiva), the aká¹£ara-puruÅŸa (the imperishable self, mukta-jiva), and the uttama-puruÅŸa (the Supreme Self). These refer to ká¹£etra (the body-mind complex of the empirical self), ká¹£etra- jÃ±a (the pure self), and jÃ±eya (the Supreme Self), respectively of the 13th chapter. If the Advaitavada theory that there is only one type of ká¹£etrajÃ±a is admitted, there would be incoherency in Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s instruction. One may object that the physical body cannot be called a purusa. Although this argument is valid, it is not the body in isolation that is called puruÈ™a. Rather, the body along with the individual self is called the purusa. Such usage is also seen in the Taittiriya Upanisad (2.1.1).39 In that Upanisad, the first three puru- ÅŸasannamaya, pranamaya, and manomaya - correspond to the presentational field (ká¹£etra), the vijÃ±Änamaya-puruÅŸa refers to the individuated knowers (ká¹£etrajÃ±as), and the anandamaya-purusa is the Supreme Self, who is to be known (jÃ±eya). A further objection may be raised: In SankarÄcÄrya’s vivarta- vÄda philosophy, IÅ›vara (ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a) is also considered to be an 38 dvav imau puruá¹£au loke ká¹£araÅ› caká¹£ara eva ca 39 ká¹£araá¸¥ sarvÄni bhÅ«tÄni kÅ«á¹­a-stho’ká¹£ara ucyate uttamaá¸¥ purusas tv anyah paramatmety udahá¹›taá¸¥plagen yo loka-trayam aviÅ›ya bibharty avyaya isvaraá¸¥ sa va esa puruso’nna-rasa-mayah bu nike coeffim authen That puruÅŸa verily consists of the essence of food. 33 33 1 The Ontology of Paramatma - The Supreme Immanent Self illusion and does not refer to the Ultimate Reality. As said earlier, the vivarta-vÃ¤da holds that there is only one reality called Brah- man; everything else is an illusion, including IÅ›vara, or God. ÅšrÄ« Jiva responds to this by saying that if this were the case, then the statements of scriptures like the Bhagavad Gita and the Upanisads would have no authority, since an illusory person would have uttered them. Moreover, there would be no difference between the Vedic schools of theology and Buddhism, since Buddhists neither accept the revealed scriptures nor the authority of their speaker. The vivarta-vÄdÄ« might further argue that even if IÅ›vara and the scriptures spoken by Him are admitted to be real, the essence of their teaching is to inform us about Brahman, the qualityless reality. So, in case this insight is not made evident from the verses of the GÄ«tÄ under discussion, then one has to supplement his understanding by recourse to other revealed texts. To this, ÅšrÄ« Jiva responds that in the GitÃ¤ Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a deliberately and clearly states that knowledge of Brahman and intuition of identity with Brahman is inferior to knowledge of Bhagavan and devotion to Him: no vino a Arjuna asks: Between those devotees who are constantly devoted to You in the manner previously described, who worship You in bolle the fullness of being, and those who worship the Imperishable, Unmanifest [Brahman], who have better realized the nature of yoga? 9 Bhagavan replies: Those who, having fixed their minds upon Me, are constantly devoted to Me, and who, being endowed with tran- scendental faith, worship Me - them I regard as the best of yogis. (GÄªTÄ€ 12.1-2)40 wom Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a also says that meditation on the qualityless Brahman is troublesome (GÄªTÄ€ 12.5), but that He personally intervenes to lib- erate His devotees from the ocean of material suffering, as in the 40 arjuna uvÄca el sol in a co evaá¹ satata-yukta ye bhaktÄs tvÄm paryupÄsate ye capy aká¹£aram avyaktam teá¹£am ke yoga-vittamaá¸¥am Å›rÄ«-bhagavan uvÄca mayy aveÅ›ya mano ye mam nitya-yuktÄ upÄƒsate hollylydoll ap Å›raddhaya parayopetas te me yuktatamÄ matÄá¸¥ochas las ping and 34 34 1152 framanual am 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined to golcano ST verse quoted by Åšri Jiva (GITA 12.7). Later, of course, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a states that He is the source of the Brahman feature:is I am indeed the source and shelter of Brahman, of imperishable f liberation, of eternal religion, and of absolute bliss. (GÄªTÄ€ 14.27)11 This suggests that Brahman is nothing but an unqualified aspect of Bhagavan, as argued by Åšri Jiva in Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anucche- das 3, 6, and 7). From all these statements it is clear that the essen- tial intent of scripture is to establish Bhagavan as the Ultimate Real- ity, not Brahman. ÅšrÄ« Jiva thus shows on the authority of the Bhaga- vad Gita that there are two ká¹£etrajÃ±as, the individual living being and ParamÄtmÄ. They are distinct and can never be absolutely one.42 Wherever their oneness is indicated, it is only because the jiva is an integrated part of ParamÄtmÄ and thus shares some iden- tity of nature with Him. But they are never identical, as stated in the GÄ«tÄ: In this way, the field (ká¹£etra), knowledge (jÃ±Äna), and the knowabler (jÃ±eya) have been described in brief. Knowing this, My devotee attains My nature. (GÄªTÄ€ 13.18)43 According to this verse, the individuated knower is certainly not the Supreme Reality to be known (jÃ±eya). The Advaitavada scholars interpret the statement “attains to My nature” to mean that the jiva becomes one with the Supreme. But this contradicts numerous other statements, such as, “But there is another, the Supreme PuruÈ™a, who is called ParamÄtmÄ” (GÄªTÄ€ 15.17). ÅšrÄ« Jiva thus glosses mad-bhava here as sÄrá¹£á¹­i, or “[the liberation of attaining] equal rank, status, or power as Bhagavan.” This is supported by the Chandogya Upanisad (CHU 8.1.5), which states that a liberated jÄ«va attains the eightfold attributes of God. 41 brahmano hi pratiá¹£á¹­hÄham amá¹›tasyavyayasya ca Å›ÄÅ›vatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikantikasya ca 42 uttamaá¸¥ purusas tv anyah paramatmety udahá¹›taá¸¥ GÄªTÄ€ 15.17 43 iti ká¹£etram tatha jÃ±Änam jÃ±eyam coktam samÄsataá¸¥ mad-bhakta etad vijÃ±Äya mad-bhavayopapadyate 35 35 1 The Ontology of ParamÃ¤tma - The Supreme Immanent Self Thus, it is perfectly clear that the individual jiva is ever distinct from and subservient to the Supreme Person, or Purusottama. He alone is the Substantive Reality to be known (jÃ±eya), and the means for the self-revelation of that truth is unconditional devotion. After being endowed with this realization, the jiva becomes like Him, and yet still remains ever distinct and subservient. ld have he 1.3 ParamÄtmÄ Is the Primary Ká¹£etrajÃ±a in Alla lat pporia erit à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€œà¤‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤®à¥â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤šà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¦à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾- à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¥ˆà¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥ˆà¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ asbi 90708 291ere and bas Therefore [in light of the above discussion], we must re-examine the statements of the GitÃ¤ (13.1-2), beginning with, “This body is called the field (ká¹£etra),””" in the following way: The pronoun idam (this) indicates that which is directly perceptible or in proximity to each individual [i.e., every individual directly per- ceives his or her own body]. The use of the singular for both sarira and ká¹£etra in this verse should be taken to mean the indi- vidual bodies [and not just one in any absolute monistic sense], taking an individual body as representative of the whole class. This is necessarily the case because in the next verse the plural, “in all ká¹£etras,“45 is used. Jua “à¤à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ â€œà¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾ à¤®à¤¨à¤µà¤ƒ” (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥ª à¥¤ à¥¨à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾ à¥¤ â€œà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾ à¤®à¤¨à¤¸à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥€à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾ à¤š à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ In the statement, “The one who knows this [body is called the knower of the field],“46 the act of knowing means to know from the [particular] perspective indicated in the [previously quoted] BhÄgavatam verse: “Although a jiva can know all these 44 idam sariram kaunteya 45 sarva-ká¹£etresu bharata 46 etad yo vetti tam prahuá¸¥ 36 Us? à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¯à¤•à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿ â€œà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ â€œà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾ à¤®à¤¨à¤¸à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥€à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ â€œà¤—à¥à¤¹à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥Œ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ " ( à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥¦ à¤¸à¥‚à¥¦ à¥§ à¥¤ à¥¨ à¥¤ à¥§à¥§ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ One should resort to a secondary meaning only when there is no other alternative. Even so, if by these words Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s inten- tion was to equate the jiva to Himself, then instead of saying, “Know Me also to be the knower (ká¹£etrajÃ±a) situated within all fields,” He would have simply said, “Know Me to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a also of that precise nature” or “Know Me [to be the ká¹£etrajÃ±a] to that exact same extent,” and there would have been no need of the addition, “in all fields, O Bharata.” Instead, He considered it necessary to speak of two ká¹£etrajÃ±as, as in the 47 deho’savo’ká¹£Ä manavo bhÅ«ta-mÃ¤trÄm 48 ká¹£etrajÃ±a eta manaso vibhutir jivasya mÄyÄ-racitasya nityaá¸¥ 49 vistabhyaham idam ká¹›tsnam ekaá¹Å›ena sthito jagat in the 377 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self two BhÄgavatam verses [cited as the principal verses of this section, i.e., SB 5.11.12-13]. Likewise, the Brahma-sutra states, “Two ÄtmÄs have entered the cavity of the heart, because it is so described in the scriptures” (vs 1.2.11).50 à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤šà¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¹à¤¿â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥¨à¥§ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°- à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥€à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤· à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤à¥à¤œà¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ â€œà¤…à¤¸à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡- à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¥‡à¤¨à¥ à¤¨ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€ ( à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥¦ à¤¸à¥‚à¥¦ à¥¨à¥¤à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥­ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Furthermore, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a concludes [this topic, GITA 13.21-22] by saying that there are indeed two types of ká¹£etrajÃ±a. Therefore, because the introductory meaning is dependent upon the con- clusion, this alone is the appropriate understanding. [The same principle of the conclusion determining the proper understand- ing of an introductory statement applies in the following text of] Brahma-sutra: “If it be argued that the effect does not exist in the cause because the Åšruti speaks of the world’s non-existence (asat) prior to creation, this is not so, because concluding state- ments show that the word [asat] is used instead to denote a difference of characteristics [and not absolute non-existence]” (vs 2.1.17).51 à¤…à¤¥ " à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥© à¥¤à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤—à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤—à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤š à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾- à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤‚à¤¶à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ viabĞ¿ooses of roast bluoda smo In the statement, “knowledge of the field (ká¹£etra) and of the knower of the field (ká¹£etrajÃ±a)” (GITA 13.2), the knowledge per- taining to the field, which will be shown either as acquired through the senses or as not so acquired, is understood as My [Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s] knowledge alone. Similarly, the knowledge present to the knower of the field, which was previously described as that related to its corresponding individual body, is also understood as My [Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s] knowledge alone. This is so [in regard to the field] because it is My [Krsna’s] knowledge alone that pervades 50 51 38 guhÃ¤á¹ praviá¹£á¹­Äv ÄtmÄnau hi tad-darÅ›anat asad vyapadeÅ›Än neti cen na dharmantarena vÄkya-seá¹£Ätihabi madhy 12 malem1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined to valo the fields (ká¹£etras) as a shadow of a portion of My cognition. Again, it is so [in regard to the knowers of the field] because it is My consciousness alone that pervades the knowers of the fields as individuated portions of My consciousness. There- fore, the statement [made above] that the primary ká¹£etrajÃ±a is ParamÄtmÄ [and not the jiva] is confirmed. oboto odt at ba à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ â€œà¤…à¤œà¤¨à¤¿ à¤š à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ƒ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¦ à¥¤ à¥®à¥­ à¥¤ à¥©à¥¦) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¾ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¾à¤œà¥ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¿- à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ â€œà¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥¦ à¥¤à¥ªà¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¤š (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥¯à¥¤à¥«à¥¨) - The manifestation of the ParamÄtmÄ feature of Bhagavan is also indicated by the personified Åšrutis: “O eternal One. You [Param- ÄtmÄ] from whom all these jivas have come, being their cause, pervade them unrestrictedly [i.e., completely]; thus You are their regulator” (SB 10.87.30).52 According to this understanding, ParamÄtmÄ is to be known as that partial form [of Bhagavan] who possesses special potency and from whom the living enti- ties appear. As is said in the GitÄ: “I pervade and support this entire cosmos by a single fraction of My power” (GÄªTÄ€ 10.42). And also in the Viá¹£á¹‡u Purana: à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤® à¤¤à¤®à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥ª à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ ESTRIE We offer obeisances to the immutable Supreme Brahman; this entire cosmic energy is situated in a portion of a 100,000,000th part of His potency. à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¬ à¥¥ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¹à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¶à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥­ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¥‡à¤œà¤¸à¤¾ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œ à¥¥ à¥§à¥® à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡à¤œà¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥ˆ à¥¤ à¤†à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤®à¥‡à¤˜à¥‹ à¤œà¤²à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ suddha-sargam aham deva jÃ±Ätum icchami tattvataá¸¥ sarga-dvayasya caivasya yaá¸¥ paratvena vartate This as well as the following verses are not found in any extant versions of NÄrada paÃ±carÄtra. Prave-amland aug 40 a2 tommal sms1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined volte dri à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤°à¤‚ à¤®à¤¹à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥¨à¥§ à¥¥ à¤¸ à¤š à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥€ à¤š à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¨à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤µà¤•à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¨à¤¿à¤šà¤¯à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¦à¥‡à¤· à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¨à¥© à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ SISTRIS à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¤‚à¤¶à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤‚ à¤¤à¤®à¤œà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¨à¥ª à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ HB i De Sinno lo BÅšrÄ« Bhagavan replied: O dvija, the all-pervading Deva is the Sup- reme Brahman, the eternal, the universal consciousness of this sim boworld, who is of the nature of transcendental bliss, nondiffer-nt ent from Vasudeva, and as effulgent as hundreds of fires, suns, and moons. Although Bhagavan Vasudeva is the Supreme Con- troller (ParameÅ›vara), being intrinsically endowed with such qualities, He caused a movement in His own radiance through His own potency. Being the personification of light, this Bhaga- vÃ¤n emitted Acyuta, who was endowed with that same radiance. aid Taking shelter of BhagavÃ¤n VÃ¤sudeva, Acyuta, who has infalli-a ble splendor, expanded His own form just as a cloud situated in Tanthe sky sends forth rain. As the ocean agitates itself and pro-b duces waves, He incited His own Self and thus produced a form that was true and radiant. This Bhagavan, who is pure con– sciousness and self-luminous, after generating His own Self by ba Himself, caused an unlimited form to become manifest, called Purusa, who is of the nature of all-pervasive light. This Supreme Regulator is the shelter of all living beings. He is their indweller, [related to them] like the sky to the stars. O twice-born, just as a fire laden with tinder sends off many sparks unintentionally, similarly, this transcendental Bhaga- vÃ¤n sends forth or emits the living beings, who are bound by their previous desires, so that they can become liberated. Thus, know all these [living beings] as integrated parts of Bhagavan and Him, the unborn Bhagavan, as the all-encompassing Whole. (Narada-paÃ±caratra)56 56 Å›rÄ«-bhagavan uvÄca yaá¸¥ sarva-vyapako devaá¸¥ para-brahma ca Å›ÄÅ›vatam cit-samanyam jagaty asmin paramananda-laká¹£aá¹‡am â†’ 41 1 The Ontology of Paramatma - The Supreme Immanent Self à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤- à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤‚à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤- à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤­à¤¯à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒ- à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤­à¤µ à¤‰à¤ªà¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¤¿â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥­ à¥§à¥¬ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ â€œà¤†à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¤- à¤§à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥ªà¥¤à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤š à¥¤ à¤à¤· à¤à¤µ (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦ à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥®à¥¤à¥«à¥¦) - à¤•à¤¾à¤  Therefore, when it is said that ÅšrÄ« Pradyumna is the indweller of Brahma, ÅšrÄ« Visnu of Manu, and ÅšrÄ« Sankará¹£aá¹‡a of Rudra, it is to be understood that Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a alone, having manifested along with His various parts, becomes the [root] indweller of these diverse beings through these [correspond- ing] partial manifestations. For this reason, Rudra is said to have his source (praká¹›ti) both in Sri Sankará¹£ana [for the play of cosmic dissolution], as well as in the Purusa [for the play of cos- mic creation] as in [the prose passage from the Fifth Canto]: “ÅšrÄ« Åšiva worships his own source, who is known as ÅšrÄ« Sankará¹£aá¹‡a” (SB 5.17.16).57 And also, “That Primeval PuruÅŸa, united with rajas, appeared in the beginning as Brahma for the creation of this universe, and, united with tamas, He appeared as Rudra for its destruction” (SB 11.4.5).58 This is also explained in VisÅ†u Purana: mtor & beauborg audi 8. men ytopaj mognÄimo fa 42192 fammi em 1 ParamÄtmÄ Defined to golotno s à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤šà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥
