(SB 10.89.1) wo ein vd. à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¤•à¥à¤·à¥€à¤°à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤®à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤²à¤¨à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾- à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥à¤°à¥à¤—à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤š à¤•à¥à¤·à¥€à¤°à¤¾à¤¬à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤—à¤£à¥‡ à¤ªà¤ à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥€à¤ªà¤ªà¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ 03 The abode of Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u is the Milk Ocean (ká¹£irodaka), because it is well known from the Uttara-khanda of the Padma Purana that the devas headed by Brahma go there repeatedly to supplicate Bhagavan for the protection of the universe. His abode is also famous as VisÅ†u-loka. In the Bá¹›hat-sahasra-nÄma (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 71.141) also, among the collec- tion of names of Bhagavan Visnu, one of His names is “He whose sarasvatyÄs taá¹­e rajan rá¹£ayaá¸¥ satram asate vitarkaá¸¥ samabhut teá¹£Äm triá¹£v adhiseá¹£u ko mahÄn 89 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self abode is the Ocean of Milk.” In some places, the Lord of Svetad- vipa is called Aniruddha, because He is directly a manifestation of Aniruddha. à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¥€à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¥ In this way, the relative superiority of the three gods is made explicit by means of a test? que al sluge dent to doidW 99 Commentary IN THIS SECTION, ÅšrÄ« Jiva begins to stress the supremacy of ViÅŸnu over Brahma and Åšiva, referring to an anecdote from BhÄgavata PurÄÅ†a (10.89), incidentally pointing out that Visnu’s abode is in the Milk Ocean. The story goes that once there was a big confer- ence of sages on the bank of the river Sarasvati. A question came upon the assembly as to which of the three gods - BrahmÄ, Viá¹£á¹‡u, or Åšiva - is paramount. The sage Bhrgu was assigned to ascertain the truth. ed. Falda Bhrgu first went to visit Brahma, his father. To test Brahma’s forbearance, he neither paid the customary respect nor did he praise him. Brahma became furious and glared at Bhrgu with eyes rolling in anger. But since the insult had been inflicted by his own son, he contained his rage. Bhrgu next went to Kailasa, the residence of his elder brother, Åšiva. Seeing his brother approaching, Åšiva rose up from his seat and proceeded to embrace the sage. But Bhrgu avoided Åšiva, say- ing, “I shall not touch you, because you have disregarded social con- vention and flouted the injunctions of the Vedas by putting skulls 2 The last line of Anuccheda 11 appears as the first line of Anuccheda 12 in the g edition of ÅšrÄ« Haridasa SÄƒstri. Being a connecting statement, it both concludes the discussion in Anuccheda 11 and serves as a bridge for the statement that follows in Anuccheda 12. This is readily perceived in the Sanskrit text in which the flow of thought proceeds uninterrupted by translation and commentary. We have moved the statement here so as not to lose its primary sense of bringing a conclusion to the discussion in Anuccheda 11. In addition, we have placed a square bracket at the beginning of the translation to Anuccheda 12 that supplies the statement’s linking function to the ongoing discussion. defin 90 1211 Which of the Three Regulators Is Supreme? eff on your body and smearing it with the ashes of cremated bodies.” Hearing these harsh words, Åšiva became furious and ran to attack Bhrgu with his trident. But PÄrvati fell at his feet, pacifying him and persuading him not to commit the ghastly deed of killing his own brother.gallo asmen brsewody sno entsinos base Bhrgu then moved on to Vaikuntha, the abode of Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u. There he observed that Bhagavan was lying down with His head in the lap of Laká¹£mi Devi. The sage walked up to VisÅ†u and kicked Him in the chest. Visnu immediately got up and reverently spoke the following words, “O sage, please come and have a seat. I was unaware of your arrival, so I did not welcome you properly. Please forgive Me. Your feet are so soft and My chest so very hard. You must surely be feeling some pain after kicking Me.” Saying this, Visnu began to massage Bhrgu’s feet. He continued, “O sage, all My sins have been dispelled by the touch of your feet. From this day I have become the sole abode of Laká¹£mi, the Goddess of Wealth. She will henceforth dwell on My bosom bearing the mark of your foot.” of 15340 HASANGAN ant batslos ad yam and slifi es ad Sage Bhrgu felt great joy on hearing this expression of humil- ity from VisÅ†u. His voice choked up out of devotion and tears fell from his eyes. He could not utter a single word. He returned to the assembly of sages and narrated what he had experienced. Hearing his words, everyone was struck with wonder and had no doubt about the supremacy of Bhagavan VisÅ†u, the reservoir of all virtuous qualities. giderowo Although the BhÄgavatam relates that Bhrgu went to Vaikuntha to see VisÅ†u, ÅšrÄ« Jiva Prabhu points out here that in fact, this would be the guá¹‡ÄvatÄra form of Viá¹£á¹‡u who lies on the Ocean of Milk, which is within the cosmos. In Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anucchedas 73 and 74), Jiva explains that just as Bhagavan appears as an avatara in the material world, so too His eternal abode manifests within the cosmos. A reference to such an appearance is found in the Eighth Canto of the BhÄgavatam (8.5.4-5). The third Purusa of Visnu is called both Ká¹£irodakaÅ›Äyi Viá¹£á¹‡u as well as Aniruddha. He is called Ká¹£irodakaÅ›ÄyÄ« because He resides upon the Ocean of Milk, ká¹£irodaka. He is also called Aniruddha 91 36 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self because sometimes Bhagavan Aniruddha, the fourth member of the quadruple manifestation of Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, personally takes the place of Ká¹£irodakaÅ›Äyi Visnu. llal Dave 8 anshin ald thw ugula air The Brhat-sahasra-nama mentioned here is spoken by Åšiva to Parvati and contains one thousand names of Viá¹£á¹‡u. One of Visnu’s names found there is Ká¹£Ä«rÄbdhi-mandira (Padma Purana, Uttara- khanda 71.141), or one who resides upon the Milk Ocean. In the Uttara-khanda of Padma Purana (Chapter 245) there is a description of the devas headed by Brahma approaching the northern beach of the Milk Ocean to supplicate Bhagavan VisÅ†u.galwollol at sloga Åšvetadvipa (“the white island”) is another name for this abode of VisÅ†u. It is mentioned in Brahma-samhita: “I worship Svetad- vipa, called Goloka” (Brahma-samhita 5.66) Svetadvipa and its res- idents are described in great detail in the NÄrÄyaá¹‡Ä«ya section of the Mahabharata (starting from Santi-parva, Chapter 335), which relates NÄrada’s visit there. It may be mentioned here that in some PurÄÅ†as, stories, such as this one, may be related in a different manner in order to prove the supremacy of Åšiva or another deity. The reason for this is that the PurÄnas are divided into three groups according to the three gunas. The sÃ¤ttvika Puranas are superior to the other two categories because true knowledge comes from sattva - sattvÃ¤t saÃ±jÄyate jÃ±Änam (GÄªTÄ€ 14.17). This was discussed in Anuccheda 18 of Tattva Sandarbha. Moreover, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a says that He establishes a devotee’s faith in whatever deity he is drawn to worship (GITA 7.21-23). This is accomplished through the stories found in non-sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as. In Tattva Sandarbha, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va established the supreme authority of BhÄgavata Purana over all other PurÄnas and ItihÄsas in the matter of the self-disclosure of Ultimate Reality. Thus, the conclusion of BhÄgavata PurÄá¹‡a overrides any contradictory description.sybas riigis 3bhaje Å›vetadvipam tam aham golokam iti yam 4 1.60 For an example, one can consult the Åšiva Purana (Part 1, Chapter 6), which relates the story of a fight that took place between Brahma and Visnu to assert their supremacy.pl Os qu ØªÙ„Ø§Ùˆ 92 22 16 mb Anuccheda 12 tish ViÅŸÅ†u Is Supreme among the Guá¹‡ÄvatÄras ow bollen etrum anoloigaus ad vlame() stil med to] à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¹ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥¤à¥¨à¥©). her spins nests [THE SUPERIORITY OF VISÅ…U among the guá¹‡avatÄras] is also stated by Suta GosvÄmi elsewhere in two verses. [In the first of these, it is said:] Banden Hoidal semaf rado ni envah as…] atthe tiw 978 anmol bas enjoy caused red à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤°à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤° à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤· à¤à¤• à¤‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤–à¤²à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¨à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¨à¥ƒà¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥«à¥§ à¥¥ dauonda] mal bowl Sattva, rajas, and tamas are the three gunas of prakrti, primor-he dial nature. Accepting these for the sustenance, creation, and 48 dissolution of the material world, the one Supreme Person assumes three names - Hari (VisÅ†u), ViriÃ±ci (Brahma), and Hara (Åšiva). But among these three, it is from Visnu alone, who tod is the embodiment of sattva, that the true benefits for human beings are to be obtained. (SB 1.2.23)1 a) suola à¤‡à¤¹ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤• à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤²à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥- à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤•à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥ à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾ à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤­à¤«à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¨à¥‹à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ 55 1 sattvaá¹ rajas tama iti praká¹›ter gunÄs tair yuktaá¸¥ paraá¸¥ puruÅŸa eka ihasya dhatte sthity-adaye hari-viriÃ±ci-hareti saÃ±jÃ±Äá¸¥ Å›reyamsi tatra khalu sattva-tanor ná¹›nam syuá¸¥ hand radio si no wol sb dut bi gubisbarron 931 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self Here, although the one transcendental PuruÈ™a, for the sake of sustenance, creation, and dissolution of this universe, is con- nected separately with each of the three gunas as their presiding deities, He still remains transcendental and untouched by them. He takes the separate appellations of Hari, ViriÃ±ci, and Hara, meaning that Bhagavan appears in the forms [of these three deities]. Nevertheless, of these three, it is from ÅšrÄ« VisÅ†u alone, who presides over the power of sattva, that the true benefits [of human life (Å›reyamsi)], namely, the auspicious fruits called dharma, artha, kÄma, moká¹£a, and bhakti, are to be obtained. à¤…à¤¯à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒâ€“ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥Œ à¤¸à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤°à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤˜à¥‹à¤°à¤®à¥‚à¤¢à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾- à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤¦à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¥à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤—à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¨ à¤š à¤à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤¥à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤à¤µ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ The sense is this: If Brahma and Åšiva are worshiped as limited with adjuncts [i.e., as devas in charge of their respective gunas], then because rajas and tamas are distressful and bewildering [respectively], even if one should attain the fruits of dharma, artha, and kÄma [through them], they will not be very pleasing. If [on the other hand] one worships these two as without any adjuncts [taking them as identical to the Supreme and free of any guna], then even if moká¹£a were to occur, it would neither come directly from them nor be realized swiftly. Rather, only if they are worshiped in the constant understanding that they are both parts of ParamÄtmÄ [i.e., that they are avataras of Param- ÄtmÄ], is liberation to be obtained, and only from ParamÄtmÄ alone. [But] since ParamÄtmÄ is not directly manifest in the forms of Åšiva or Brahma, the ultimate welfare does not proceed directly from them. à¤…à¤¥à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¾ à¤…à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤¦à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ â€œà¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥” (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥ª à¥¤ à¥§à¥­ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤•à¥ˆà¤µà¤²à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤ à¥¨à¥«à¥¤à¥¨à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ IGP Now, [on the other hand,] if one serves Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u, even considering Him to be delimited by sattva [i.e., not knowing 94 36 112 Viá¹£á¹‡u Is Supreme among the GunavatÄras SIT Him as the Supreme], the dharma, artha, and kama achieved [through Him] will be pleasing, because sattva is peaceful by nature. And if one serves Him without material desire [even while still considering Him to be delimited by sattva], then one attains moká¹£a directly, in accordance with statements like, “Knowledge manifests from sattva” (GITA 14.17)2 and “Kaivalya (liberation) is sÃ¤ttvika knowledge” (SB 11.25.24). à¤…à¤¤ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡- How Therefore, it is said in the Skanda PurÄna: How à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤ªà¤¾à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤ªà¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤®à¥‹à¤šà¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ˆà¤µà¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥«à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ He who binds with the ropes of material existence and He who delivers from the same bondage is Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u alone, Be the eternal Absolute Reality and the bestower of liberation (kaivalya). (Skanda Purana) à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤—à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ If, however, one worships Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u without any limit- ing adjuncts [considering Him Supreme], then it is bhakti alone that is attained, the fifth goal of human life, because He [ViÅŸnu without adjuncts] is manifest [to such a devotee] in His form as ParamÄtmÄ. Therefore, ultimate welfare comes from VisÅ†u alone [as stated in the Bhagavatam verse under discussion]. hting Bogidanbu Commentary 100 anup bro vish Raibles Van mo con bote de mo anging ALTHOUGH the Supreme Person is one, He accepts three forms to carry out the three functions of creation, sustenance, and 2 sattvÃ¤t sanjayate jÃ±Änam 3 kaivalyaá¹ sÃ¤ttvikam jÃ±Änam bas yangtoy pienin si pizem Soult ads lo gai bandhako bhava-pÄÅ›ena bhava-pÄÅ›Äc ca mocakaá¸¥ kaivalyadaá¸¥ param brahma viÅŸnur eva sanÄtanaá¸¥ 95 This verse is not found in the extant versions. te noua anoirer 56 95 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self dissolution in relation to the gunas of praká¹›ti-rajas, sattva, and tamas. Of the three, although VisÅ†u enacts the function of suste- nance, He remains untouched by these qualities (gunas). Thus, it is only through the worship of Visnu that humanity can attain the ultimate welfare.wapababais The worship of this trinity can be undertaken either with the understanding that each member harbors the upadhi, or limitation, of his respective guna, or that they are transcendental to the gunas. In the latter case, the immateriality of Brahma and Åšiva would be on the basis of their being partial manifestations of ParamÄtmÄ, whereas Visnu is ParamÄtmÄ Himself. If Brahma and Åšiva are wor- shiped with the view that they have upÄƒdhis, then they cannot grant liberation, and even the boons of dharma, artha, and kÄma derived from them will not be very pleasing. This is because the gunas of rajas and tamas are distressful and delusive, respectively. Libera- tion (moká¹£a), however, is not possible through the worship of these two devas qualified by their upadhis. But even if one worships them as free of upÄdhis, liberation is achieved only belatedly, and that too comes as a result of considering them to be parts of ParamÄtmÄ. In essence, liberation ensues only from Visnu, the ParamÄtmÄ, and certainly not from Brahma or Åšiva directly. On the other hand, if Visnu is worshiped as delimited by sattva, one can still achieve dharma, artha, and kama from Him, and such benefits will be benign because sattva by nature is peaceful. If Visnu is worshiped without any such material motive, then one can also attain moká¹£a. This is again because of the illuminating nature of sattva that leads to moká¹£a. But if Visnu is worshiped with- out any upadhi, then one attains bhakti, the fifth human pursuit beyond dharma, artha, kÄma, and moká¹£a. Bhakti is manifest only from ParamÄtmÄ and not from any presiding deity of the gunas. While commenting on this verse, ÅšrÄ« ViÅ›vanatha explains that Bhagavan assumes the role of an avatara in two ways - through His intrinsic potency, and through His extrinsic potency consist- ing of the three gunas. The first type of avatara includes manifes- tations, such as Matsya and Kurma. All of these are worshipable forms. The second type of avatara specifically refers to the three 96 1158 ms 12 Visnu Is Supreme among the GunavatÄras forms that are related to the three gunas. Among these three, only Visnu is worshipable. Visnu is called sattva-tanu, or one whose body is purely of the nature of sattva. This sattva is not that of phenomenal being but belongs to His intrinsic potency of tran- scendental being-existence (viÅ›uddha-sattva), as is said, “Visnu is directly the Supreme Person, free of the gunas and beyond praká¹›ti” (SB 10.88.5). For this reason, Viá¹£á¹‡u cannot have any material upÃ¤dhis, since the material energy has no power to delimit Him in any way. As such, by His mere proximity He maintains the cosmos through the illuminating potency of material sattva, all the while remaining indifferent to it. It is in this sense only that He is called a guá¹‡ÄvatÄra, and thus He is in no way less than a puruá¹£ÄvatÄra. Brahma, however, is a jiva and is associated with rajas for the purpose of creation. He is called an avatara simply because he is empowered by VisÅ†u to enact the function of creation. This is con- firmed in Brahma-samhita (5.49), cited in the following anuccheda. The ontological position of Åšiva is different. He is neither of the category of VisÅ†u nor that of a jiva, but that of ParamÄtmÄ endowed with material potency. According to Brahma-samhita (5.45, cited in the following anuccheda), he is the precipitate derived from VisÅ†u, as yogurt is to milk. He is closely affiliated with VisÅ†u, and thus there are numerous scriptural statements declaring him as nondif- ferent from the latter. Like VisÅ†u, he too is addressed as IÅ›vara. Yet, he cannot be equated to VisÅ†u in all respects, because he is in contact with the gunas of praká¹›ti. He is thus depicted as the hus- band of DurgÄ or Parvati, the deity of the material energy. Such being the case, one cannot transcend the gunas by worshiping him as Supreme. In conclusion, a deva like Åšiva could be worshiped as:

  1. The independent Bhagavan. This is the concept of the Saivites. 2. The presiding deity of an aspect of the material energy, such as tamas.
  2. A devotee of Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u.
  3. A partial manifestation of Visnu. harir hi nirgunaá¸¥ sÃ¤ká¹£Ät puruá¹£aá¸¥ praká¹›teá¸¥ paraá¸¥ sa sarva-drg upadraá¹£á¹­Ä tam bhajan nirguno bhavet 97 46 I The Ontology of ParamÃ¤tma - The Supreme Immanent Self
  4. A seat, adhiá¹£á¹­hÄna, occupied by VisÅ†u, i.e., an agent or represen- olytative of ViÅŸÅ†u manifesting His powers. In this case, one would adworship ViÅŸÅ†u through him. Among these, the first type of worship is forbidden and is said to lead to degradation. The second type of worship will yield only material benefit. The other three types of worship can award the highest benefit. This is the significance of SB 1.2.23, the principal verse of this section. The essence is that no one but Visnu is the worshipable deity. For more details on this, see Anuccheda 106 of Bhakti Sandarbha. To them we say the following: Although this hierarchy of relative superiority or inferiority [of these deities] is made only in relation to their respective posts, the presid- ing [deity] is the Supreme PuruÅŸa (paraá¸¥ puruÅŸa ekaá¸¥), who is only one, since no distinction is possible in Him. The statement of nondistinction is true; nevertheless, the gradation is indeed unavoidable because of the recognition of the relative superior- ity or inferiority [of these gods due to their being] either direct or indirect manifestations [of Bhagavan]. SÅ«ta makes this point with the help of an example: 5135 à¥ à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤§à¥‚à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥€à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ [6] (ish) “and” brow addr à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤°à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥«à¥© à¥¥ os bisa ai enjoy Just as smoke is better than wood, which is a product of the earth, and fire is superior to smoke because one can perform Vedic sacrifice with it, so rajas is superior to tamas, and sattva, 66 99 1 The Ontology of Paramatma - The Supreme Immanent Self which leads to realization of the Absolute, is superior to rajas. (SB 1.2.24)1 à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤§à¥‚à¤®à¤µà¤¦à¤‚à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤°à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¥à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¤‚à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¯à¥‹ à¤§à¥‚à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥€à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤•- à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥€à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾- à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Wood is a product of the earth and thus unlike smoke, which is partially made of fire. From this it follows that wood is devoid of light and not directly functional in the Vedic ritual. So, bet- ter than the wood used to kindle the sacrificial fire is the smoke [itself], which, being partly made of fire, [can be called] trayi- maya because it has comparatively greater utility in the Vedic rituals. Furthermore, superior even to smoke is the fire itself, since it is directly the element in which the Vedic sacrifices are performed. nta svod vd babsur ved abalm seedw à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤—à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥‚à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‚à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿- à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤°à¤œà¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ In the same way, better than tamas, which is compared to wood [in this analogy] and is far removed from sattva-guna, is rajas, which is compared to smoke and, being a little closer to sattva, leads to Brahman realization. This signifies that rajas is the gate- way to the disclosure of the PuruÈ™a, who is the source of these [three guá¹‡ÄvatÄras] and is compared to the Vedic ritual [in the analogy]. Ignisd rise ouh zbog à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤²à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤°à¤œà¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¤—à¥à¤£à¤šà¥à¤›à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾- à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¥à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤ªà¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ ads tw The word “but” (tu) [following tamasaá¸¥ in the verse] indicates that in contrast to tamas, which is of the nature of stupor (laya), rajas is said to be merely in closer proximity to something a lit- tle akin to Brahman realization. This is so in the sense that parthivÄƒd dÃ¤runo dhumas tasmÃ¤d agnis trayimayaá¸¥ que af of has dona tamasas tu rajas tasmat sattvam yad brahma-darÅ›anamiristimen oiboy 100 Mo2013 The PuruÅŸa Is Directly Manifest Only as ViÅŸnu through its being the cause of conditional knowledge (sopÄdhika- jÃ±Äna), rajas manifests but the outer glow of some inkling of Bha- gavan’s attributes. Yet, it cannot lead to complete realization of the Absolute, since it is a source of distraction and disturbance (viká¹£epa). à¤¯à¤¦à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µ- à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤šà¥à¤›à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥Œ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ As to sattva, which is analogous to fire [in this example], it is direct realization of Brahman. It is directly and properly the gateway to the appearance of the qualities and form of the Abso- lute because its nature is inherently peaceful and pure. There- fore, it is concluded that the Absolute is only indirectly manifest in the forms of Brahma and Åšiva, but directly as ÅšrÄ« Viá¹£á¹‡u. à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ - And so it is said in the Vamana Purana: bidwaladrons of à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤µà¥€à¤¶à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤£à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥«à¥ª à¥¥ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤—à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥€ à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥«à¥« à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Wypinghe in ovods adr and BrahmÄ, VisÅ†u, and Åšiva are the three forms of the Supreme Self, VisÅ†u. Bhagavan Janardana, whose own form is that of VisÅ†u, though situated in Brahma in the form of Brahma, and As in Åšiva in the form of Åšiva, is established exclusively in His own an independent form. (Vamana Purana)2 as equals à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ (à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥¦ à¤¸à¤‚à¥¦ à¥«à¥¤à¥ªà¥¯, à¥«à¥¤à¥ªà¥«-à¥ªà¥¬ ) - This is elaborated in the Brahma-samhita: à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤•à¤²à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¤à¥‡à¤œà¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¯ à¤à¤µ à¤œà¤—à¤¦à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤—à¥‹à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤‚ à¤¤à¤®à¤¹à¤‚ à¤­à¤œà¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥«à¥¬ à¥¥ 2 brahma-viÅŸnv-isa-rÅ«pÄÅ†i trÄ«Å†i viÅŸnor mahÄtmanaá¸¥ brahmani brahma-rupaá¸¥ sa siva-rupaá¸¥ Å›ive sthitaá¸¥ ada prthag eva sthito devo visÅ†u-rÅ«pi janardanaá¸¥ iti sarung ihi maluuvap 101 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self à¤•à¥à¤·à¥€à¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¦à¤§à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤®à¥à¤­à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¥‹à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤‚ à¤¤à¤®à¤¹à¤‚ à¤­à¤œà¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥«à¥­ à¥¥ 30 à¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¥¤sanavag à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ƒà¤—à¥‡à¤µ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¥‹à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤‚ à¤¤à¤®à¤¹à¤‚ à¤­à¤œà¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥«à¥® à¥¥ à¤¦à¤¾à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ 198 I worship the primeval person, Govinda, who manifests His 55 power in Brahma as the creator of the universal egg, just as the sun projects a fragment of its own effulgence into the “sun-crystals” [which magnify a portion of its rays].od is devoid ovitog of aA Just as milk turns into yogurt through contact with a catalytic agent, so Bhagavan assumes the form of Sambhu for a specific purpose, and yet that form [of Sambhu] is in no way distinct from its originating cause. I worship that primeval person, Govinda. since I worship Him, the primeval person, Govinda, who manifests as Visnu in the same way that the flame of one lamp is transferred od to another wick, which then continues to illuminate exactly as the one from which it was lit. (Brahma-samhita 5.49, 5.45-46)3 ××©. à¤¨ à¤š à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ “à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€ ( à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥¦ à¤¸à¥‚à¥¦ à¥¨à¥¤à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ The above example of yogurt should not lead us to conclude that Bhagavan undergoes any modification, because this has been repeatedly negated in accordance with the following principle: “But on the authority of the Vedas [Brahman undergoes no such 3 bhÄsvÃ¤n yathaÅ›ma-Å›akaleÅŸu nijesu tejaá¸¥ sviyam kiyat prakaá¹­ayaty api tadvad atra brahma ya eva jagad-anda-vidhana-kartÄ govindam adi-puruÅŸam tam aham bhajÄmi Th sanjayate na tu tatah pá¹›thag asti hetoh tushasqabat Righ ká¹£Ä«ram yatha dadhi vikara-viseá¹£a-yogato al benodels ai aint yaá¸¥ sambhutam api tatha samupaiti karyÄd ra govindam adi-puruÅŸam tam aham bhajami dipÃ¤rcir eva hi dasÃ¤ntaram abhyupetya dipayate vivá¹›ta-hetu-samana-dharmÄ yas tÄdá¹›g eva hi ca viÅŸnutaya vibhÄti govindam Ädi-puruÅŸam tam aham bhajami tes ne dog-noulived goalul poradit s p 102 12113 The PuruÅŸa Is Directly Manifest Only as Visnur change], and this is to be accepted because it is solely on the basis of revealed sound that Brahman is to be known” (vs 2.1.27). à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤¯à¤¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¯à¥Œ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¦ à¥¤ à¥®à¥­ à¥¤ à¥§à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ As is also [stated in the prayers of the Åšrutis]: “The universe emanates from, and is dissolved back into, the Absolute, who remains unchanged, just as earthen pots are made out of and merge back into clay” (SB 10.87.15).5 of sust à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤²à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ - à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¥Œ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¤®à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¥Œ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥€à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ƒà¤—à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¥Œ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£ à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ The following conclusions can be drawn, in order, from these three examples: In the first, Bhagavan, who is compared to the sun, is partially manifest in the form of Brahma, who is com- pared to a sun-crystal (surya-kanta). In the second, there is no such manifestation of Bhagavan, who is compared to milk, pro- jected into the form of Sambhu, who is compared to yogurt [as milk is not present as such in yogurt]. In the third example, how- ever, Bhagavan is fully manifest in the form of Viá¹£Å†u, who is compared to another lamp wick.dw (meg-idquod ail) inom off swog Isnolietanent smo zad 11 18d 1990s of botol 96 9 Commentary Jadi esllqmi sred batio (vs..) tie-blan sidizzoqmi sziwi o al did yw sideviso ALTHOUGH the one PuruÅŸa is manifest as Brahma, VisÅ†u, and Åšiva and there is no difference between them, they cannot be consid- ered as equals because Visnu is directly the Supreme Person and the other two are not. Their gradation is illustrated by the exam- ple of wood, smoke, and fire. Wood is inferior to smoke because no Vedic sacrifice can be performed with wood alone, even though fire is created by rubbing sticks together. Smoke, on the other hand, is close to fire, and thus the potential for such sacrifice is present in it. By this measure, fire is self-evidently superior. Similarly, rajas, 4 Å›rutes tu sabda-mÃ¼latvÄt 5 wala yilida de calqu yata udayasta-mayau viká¹›ter má¹›di vÃ¤viká¹›tÄt vino mold of tax adidas 103I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self which implies action, is superior to tamas, which corresponds to ignorance and entropy. But sattva is superior to rajas because of its illuminating nature. ÅšrÄ« Jiva comments that rajas is also instrumental in illuminating Brahman. To attain Brahman realization, some suitable action has to be performed. For any action rajas is necessary. But rajas alone cannot lead to brahma-darÅ›ana, because its characteristic nature is that of viká¹£epa, meaning that it gives rise to disruption and turmoil. Without sattva, rajas cannot yield such a result. ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va GosvÄmÄ« cites three verses from Brahma-saá¹hitÄ to show the respective positions of Brahma, Viá¹£á¹‡u, and Åšiva. In verse 5.45, Viá¹£á¹‡u is compared to milk and Åšiva to yogurt, a mod- ification of milk. This leads to the following question about VisÅ†u: Is He Himself transformed when He becomes Åšiva? If yes, then it would contradict numerous statements that establish Visnu as free from any modification. If no, then the example of milk and yogurt is misleading. So, ÅšrÄ« Jiva replies in the negative. Visnu has tran- srational powers and thus does not undergo any transformation to become Åšiva. In the PurÄá¹‡as there is mention of a philosopher’s stone, cinta- mani (lit., a thought-gem), which can create objects just by a per- son’s will. This seems illogical, and if such a thing exists, then we are forced to accept that it has some transrational power. The Brahma-sutra (2.1.27) cited here implies that Bhagavan has incon- ceivable powers by which He can perform otherwise impossible deeds. Thus, He can manifest as Åšiva without undergoing any mod- ification. The Vedas personified in their prayers offer the example bns nog at unei szossed alsupe sa bers The cintamani (“thought-jewel”) is a magical gem that transforms whatever it or touches into gold or whatever else one may wish for. Though the existence of such gems is evidently not scientific or an empirically verified reality, it is a metaphor that conveys a particular idea, in this case that of transforming without being transformed. It is not meant to be taken literally. Every language has its peculiarities, and problems arise when we translate culture specific zola ideas into a completely foreign language. In Sanskrit such things are called kavi-prasiddhi, or poetic testimony, which require no other proof. Some other examples are the ability of a swan to separate water from milk, or the AÅ›oka tree, which is said to bloom only when kicked by a beautiful damsel. 104 13 The Purusa Is Directly Manifest Only as ViÅŸnu of clay. Various pots are made from clay, and after destruction, they merge back into clay. In this process, clay itself does not transform into something else. Similarly, ViÅŸÅ†u manifests as Åšiva without undergoing any change in Himself. ÅšrÄ« Jiva says that Brahma, who is compared to a sun-crystal that reflects the light from the sun, has some similarity to VisÅ†u, who is here compared to the sun itself. Brahma is an adherent of the Vedic way of life; he assists the devas and Manus in fulfilling their duties of sustaining the universe. These acts are reflective of the nature of Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u. But Åšiva is totally different from Visnu in the same way that yogurt has a completely distinct nature from milk. Åšiva puts on a garland of skulls, wraps snakes around his neck and arms and smears ashes on his body. He destroys the universe. This is just the opposite of Visnu’s demeanor. dr D AUÃ¨ ine By contrast, however, the Viá¹£á¹‡u guá¹‡ÄvatÄra is compared to a lamp that has been lit by another lamp and that shines with the same brilliance as the original. In the same way, this VisÅ†u is identical to ParamÄtmÄ, though one arises out of the other. ond half of the first verse “-principle àª²à«‹àª•àª¶ pivi siis In the primary see, their secondary presence most certainly

As tri-linga [he who bears three marks], he is endowed with the three gunas of nature. He presides over the conditional “I”-principle [ahankÃ¤ra, or ego], which is threefold - sÃ¤ttvika, rÄjasika, and tÄmasika. From this [ego] manifest the sixteen modifi-ple cations [of praká¹›ti]. One who worships [Åšiva as presiding over] any among these [modifications] enjoys the fruit of all [material] opulences. But Bhagavan Visnu is the Supreme Per- son Himself, free from the three gunas and beyond material nature. He is all-seeing (sarva-drk) and the witness (upadraá¹£á¹­Ä). One who worships Him becomes free of the gunas of nature. (SB 10.88.3-5)1 1 sivaá¸¥ Å›akti-yutah saÅ›vat trilingo guna-samvá¹›tah vaikarikas taijasaÅ› ca tamasaÅ› cety aham tridhÄ 106 Heine 14 Visnu Is beyond the Material GuÅ†as à¤¶à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤šà¥à¤›à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤­à¥‡ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤Ÿà¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ bla The phrase “ever remains united with his energy” (sakti-yutaá¸¥ Å›aÅ›vat) means that Åšiva is endowed from the very beginning, that is, always and eternally, with his energy, namely, the lim- iting adjunct (upadhi) formed by praká¹›ti, or the gunas in their state of equilibrium. When the gunas of nature are destabilized, he becomes tri-linga, or “he who bears three marks,” in that he takes on the limiting adjuncts of the three gunas. When these gunas are manifest, he is covered by them. à¤¨à¤¨à¥ à¤¤à¤® à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤•à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ ? à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹ - à¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤• à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¹à¤®à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤š à¤¤à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¤à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯- à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤—à¥Œà¤£à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ 9971 A doubt is raised: It is heard [from authoritative sources] that Åšiva has only tamas as a limiting adjunct, so how is it said here that he has three limiting adjuncts? This is answered in the sec- ond half of the first verse. [The “three” is a reference to] the “I”-principle (aham-tattva), which is of three types as specified here, and he presides over that ego. This means that even though it may be accepted that the other two gunas do not exist in him in the primary sense, their secondary presence must certainly be accepted. à¤¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤®à¥€à¤·à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¨ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¥€à¤¨à¥‹ à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤«à¤²à¤‚ à¤²à¤­à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ [The second verse says:] Then from that ego principle, which is presided over [by Åšiva] as a representative of Bhagavan, come tato vikÄrÄ abhavan á¹£oá¸aÅ›ÄmiÅŸu kiÃ±cana upÄdhÄvan vibhÅ«tÄ«nÄm sarvÄsÄm aÅ›nute gatim taber hier harir hi nirgunaá¸¥ saksat puruá¹£aá¸¥ praká¹›teá¸¥ parah nissa-lleynisdrotera sa sarva-drg upadraá¹£á¹­Ä tam bhajan nirguno bhavetve modw mon so silt The Gita Press edition reads kaÃ±cana instead of kiÃ±cana, and upadhavan in place of upadhavan. anot amam sylindr 107 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self the sixteen modifications. A person who worships [Åšiva as pre- siding over] any among these modifications, taking that ele- ment as being connected to all opulences, attains the fruit that is aspired for. In other words, such fruit is obtained by worshiping him as delimited by that particular adjunct (upadhi).m (oving à¤¹à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥Œ à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥Œ à¤µà¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ upa lo state [In the third verse,] the word hi indicates universal acknowl- edgment [i.e., it is well known that Hari is nirguna] or causa- tion [i.e., because Hari is directly the Purusa, He is without any upÄdhis, or nirguna]. But [in contrast to Åšiva] Bhagavan Hari is transcendental to the limitations (upadhis) imposed by mate- rial nature, being untouched by its attributes. Therefore, being free of the gunas, how can He be limited by these three gunas (tri-linga) and so on [as is Åšiva]?] based at 31 :heater al duob A à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ - à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤· à¤ˆà¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¬à¤¿à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥‹ “à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤®à¤® à¤¤à¤¨à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤°à¤µà¤£à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥‹à¤ªà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ Hed hao Now ÅšrÄ« Åšuka states the reason for this: Hari is directly the PuruÅŸa Himself, namely, the Supreme Controller (IÅ›vara), and not separated like a reflection [from the reflected object]. There- fore, just as the word tanu (body) has been used [to mean energy or manifestation] in SB 11.11.3, “Knowledge and ignorance are My two energies (tanu),” in the same way, sometimes it is said that Hari is endowed with the energy of sattva, which simply means that He is related to it by rendering it functional through His mere glance, etc. [and not that He has it as an upadhi in the way that Åšiva does]. à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¥€ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤œà¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤«à¤²à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¥ Therefore, being all-seeing (sarva-drk), or in other words, being the one from whom everyone’s vision or knowledge (drk) is 2 vidyavidye mama tanu 108 312 14 VisÅ†u Is beyond the Material GuÅ†as m derived, including that of Åšiva and Brahma, He is also their observer or witness (upadraá¹£á¹­Ä). Thus, by worshiping Him, one becomes free from the gunas, meaning he attains a result beyond the material gunas. To woq art to 202292204 20 yalsh galbles’rq To sardana brus this el vie Boward Sexy sirsnier ter ob ni barn (Lune) sexov sdr Commentaryzom aj al alignola"ybod om jon aschinot unos brow sill gui biv THE THREE VERSES under discussion in this section were spoken by Sri Suka in response to a query raised by King Pariká¹£it: esinem adf zomat bas enim,hiva brutto asifamt bybiv esibod ad Åšiva is he who appears outwardly as inauspicious (asiva) [having ow abandoned all enjoyment and social propriety], while ÅšrÄ« Hari [Bhagavan ViÅŸnu] is the husband of Laká¹£mi, the Goddess of wealth and fortune. Nonetheless, it is observed that those among the he devas, asuras, and human beings who worship Åšiva are generally opulent and enjoy sense pleasures, while those devoted to Visnuw Dare indigent. Why is this? (SB 10.88.1-2)308 ÅšrÄ« Suka replied that Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u takes away the wealth of His devotees, which enables them to see through the false ego of independent enjoyership. This vision in turn becomes the basis of total self-surrender unto Bhagavan. They become fully devoted and attain Him, becoming free of the three gunas of nature. In contrast, Åšiva blesses his devotees with material enjoyment, which aggra- vates the sense of enjoyership and diverts consciousness toward the mundane.rb ed sao prapin ai univ son12 y In This description makes evident the supreme status of VisÅ†u, as well as Åšiva’s and Brahma’s subordination to Him. Being tran- scendental, He awards transempirical benedictions to His devotees. Material benedictions are temporary, and thus Bhagavan has no impetus to offer them. He is like a skilled physician who cures the disease from the root, without allowing his patient to eat the 3 devÃ¤sura-manusyeÅŸu ye bhajanty aÅ›ivam sivam prayas te dhanino bhoja na tu laká¹£myÄá¸¥ patim harim etad veditum icchamaá¸¥ sandeho’tra mahÄn hi nah viruddha-silayoá¸¥ prabhvor viruddha bhajatÄm gatiá¸¥ 109 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self rich food that might serve as momentary pleasure but is ultimately detrimental. asing thosdo Åšri Jiva comments that sometimes it is said that Visnu is the presiding deity or possessor of the power of sattva-guna, just as Åšiva is of tamas and Brahma of rajas. Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a Himself affirms this in the verse (SB 11.11.3) cited in the main text. In this verse, the word tanu does not mean “body,” although this is its most popular mean- ing. The word tanu is derived from the root âˆštan, which means to expand, to attenuate. Here it is used in the sense of energy or manifestation, and not the body, because vidya and avidya cannot be bodies. Vidya implies sattva, and avidya, rajas and tamas. The word tanu is used in place of sakti to signify that Bhagavan renders vidya and avidya functional without directly contacting them, just as the ÄtmÄ, or self, makes the body functional by its proximity. A doubt that may be raised here is that since ViÅŸÅ†u interacts with sattva, and sattva is His potency, He must be influenced by it. ÅšrÄ« Jiva clarifies that Visnu is not under the influence of sattva-guna. He is transcendental to sattva but animates it merely through His glance.www at V to The knowledge of Åšiva and Brahma is dependent Ãºpon VisÅ†u, who presides over the sattva from which knowledge arises. There- fore, He is called sarva-drk, the source of everyone’s knowledge or awareness. This makes Him a witness to all, because to be a witness one must have awareness. Rajas produces distraction (viká¹£epa), and tamas, torpor (laya). Both are obstacles to the witnessing capac- ity. Since Visnu is nirguna, one becomes nirguna by worshiping Him. This is the true result of worshiping Visnu - not material opulence. Thus, VisÅ†u’s devotees may or may not have material opulence since it is not their aim. gada and bus visoms vie and ad IstistsM tb or Therefore, being all-celing (segreg the one from whom they do samodomingo sa zbys), A hitam at lang manford bbins roldang down-albu 110 162 insaamal smorque T-maman to volato adr ÑƒÑ‡ĞµÑ‚Ğ¿ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¹ ÑTIA bus Amidsia ravo oralV to vosmarque os ont 12 aurten lo que seult ad bnoyed at Herb gniworle bus vi orit gooms and as beinuos el sigaiv duodils ad zerfalldaten svil Anuccheda 15sgered son blode audio tovborg ano of whelv guttagmos to sansa oli ole as air nolistaslimem Visnu Is One with the Supreme PuruÅŸaqmal fo bus con9225 ni rai andions yd all guodi S07E8 ad vlenitus ai uusiv swog à¥§à¥« à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¨à¥¤à¥¬à¥¤à¥©à¥§) do min beeing bus Emdeze berosorge eberek veb ono shera non FOR THIS REASON, Brahma spoke to Narada about the direct one- ness with the Supreme PuruÅŸa only in regard to Visnu [of the three guá¹‡ÄvatÄras]: boon W ducha boro uoh beroded of à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¹à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤§à¥ƒà¤•à¥ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ bogas Smda nt betis 19 yiller ads wattshipuls II (aham) evolve the universe as appointed by Him, and Åšiva ir tad dissolves it under His supervision, while He Himself, endowed vi with the three potencies, preserves it as the PuruÈ™a. (SB 2.6.31)118 à¤…à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° (à¤®à¤¹à¥‹à¤ªà¥¦) -à¤­à¥‡à¤¦ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¤‰à¤¦à¤• à¤¸ à¥¤ The pronoun “I” (aham) here refers to Brahma. There is also a Vedic statement in this regard: 1 2 à¤¸ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸ à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤ªà¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤²à¤¯ à¤à¤µ à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤à¥¤ à¥¬à¥© à¥¤à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¤¹à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¤¿ || à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¥ This shows ]. This is slated He creates through Brahma and dissolves through Rudra. That Bhagavan Hari alone is transcendental, supremely blissful, and devoid of origination and dissolution. (Maha Upanisad)2 srjami tan-niyukto ham haro harati tad-vaÅ›aá¸¥ viÅ›vam purusa-rupena paripati tri-sakti-dhrk sa brahmana sá¹›jati sa rudreÅ†a vilÃ¤payati â†’ comp 111 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self Commentary AFTER ESTABLISHING the supremacy of Viá¹£Å†u over Brahma and Åšiva, and showing that He is beyond the three gunas of nature, ÅšrÄ« Jiva establishes that although Visnu is counted as one among the guá¹‡ÄvatÄras of the Purusa, He should not be regarded as a lesser manifestation. This was also the sense of comparing VisÅ†u to one oil lamp lit by another (Brahma-samhita 5.46). Just as one lamp, though lit by another, is in every respect equal to the original, so Visnu is entirely the same, identical to the Purusa in essence and power. The To show this, ÅšrÄ« Jiva refers to a verse spoken by Brahma to his son Narada. One day, Narada approached Brahma and praised him as the supreme truth (SB 2.5.1-8). He addressed him as omniscient (sarvajÃ±a) and as the supreme regulator of all (sakaleÅ›vara). Yet, he harbored a doubt: What need was there for Brahma to undergo severe penances if he indeed was the supreme master? Brahma responded at length, denying his own supremacy and elucidating the reality of the Supreme Person. The verse cited in this anuccheda is part of his reply. In support of this verse, ÅšrÄ« Jiva refers to the Maha Upaniá¹£ad. From these verses it is clear that Brahma and Åšiva are subordinate to VisÅ†u, who is identical with the Supreme PuruÈ™a. iscoela absolu ity. It is from His delight that Brahma is Vis born and from His anger that Rudra arises. (SB 12.5.1)1 A à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤°à¥à¤¨ à¤•à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤­à¥‡à¤¦ à¤à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤¸ à¤‰ à¤à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤ƒ " (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥®à¥¤à¥§à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ In this verse, Åšri Visnu is not mentioned [by name]. This shows that He is directly one with Bhagavan Hari, [the Immanent Self of the cosmos and the transcendent Bhagavan]. This is stated: “He [the Purusa NÄrÄyaá¹‡a] indeed is Visnu” (SB 3.8.15). 1 à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤š â€œà¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‹ à¤¹ à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¯à¤¤ à¤…à¤¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¤œà¥‹à¤½à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿â€ (à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¥¦ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ mole atranuvará¹‡yate’bhiká¹£á¹‡am viÅ›vÄtmÄ bhagavan hariá¸¥ yasya prasada-jo brahma rudraá¸¥ krodha-samudbhavaá¸¥ 2 sa u eva viÅŸnuá¸¥thething ing dal i gÃ¼ler adul This verse was quoted in full earlier (in Anuccheda 8) where the full explanation can be found. lood baqa 1131 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self The Åšruti also states: “The PuruÅŸa, Bhagavan NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, ver- ily intended. From him [Brahma] were born all the living beings” (Maha-nÄrÄyaá¹‡a Upanisad)3 that He three â€œà¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤à¥¤ à¤‹à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤ªà¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¤²à¤®à¥â€ (à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤ à¥ª, à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ “NÄrÄyaá¹‡a is the Supreme Brahman, NÄrÄyaá¹‡a is the Absolute Truth, the cosmic law, Truth, the Supreme Transcendence, and the Purusa, who is blackish-yellow (ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a-pingala) in color” (MahÄ-nÄrÄyaá¹‡a Upanisad 11.4, 12.1). â€œà¤à¤•à¥‹ à¤¹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£ à¤†à¤¸à¥€à¤¨à¥ à¤¨ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¨ à¤š à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¸à¤®à¤šà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‹ à¤¹à¤¿à¤°à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤°à¥à¤­à¥‹à¤½à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒ " (à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ Also: “[In the beginning] there was only NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, not BrahmÄ and not Sankara. He became a sage (muni) and deliberated. From Him only appeared all these - the universe, BrahmÄ, Agni, Varuna, Rudra, and Indra” (Maha-nÄrÄyaá¹‡a Upanisad 1.1).5 à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¥ gniad ylanouniro. Therefore, it is also fitting that He alone is recognized as the subject worthy of description [in Srimad Bhagavatam]. Commentary by supuses of bis nota kopofife Fis IN THIS SECTION, ÅšrÄ« Jiva presents further references identifying Visnu with the PuruÈ™a. The principal verse (SB 12.5.1) omits the 3 puruso ha vai nÄrÄyaá¹‡o’kÄmayata atha nÄrÄyaá¹‡Äd ajoâ€™jÄyata yataá¸¥ prajÄá¸¥ sarvÄá¹‡i bhÅ«tÄni (a1.8. aa) “pa at bashri [sney sang ad] SH This mantra is not found in the printed version of Maha-nÄrÄyaá¹‡a Upanisad, but To a similar mantra is found in the NÄrÄyaá¹‡a-atharva-sira Upanisad (1). hig nÄrÄyaá¹‡aá¸¥ param brahma tattvaá¹ nÄrÄyaá¹‡aá¸¥ param 4 rtam satyam param brahma puruÅŸam ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a-pingalam 5eko ha nÄrÄyaá¹‡a Ã¤sin na brahma na ca sankaraá¸¥ sa munir bhÅ«tvÃ¤ samacintayat bump Fly (oran) “Finny lindatov vundin Amalord of-nhbang tata eva vyajayanta viÅ›vo hiranyagarbho’gnir varuna-rudrendrÄá¸¥ This and the previous two references are not found in the extant editions of the respective books. Baunt ad oss 114 16 ÅšrÄ« Suka Also Hints at the Oneness between Visnu and the PuruÅŸa name of Visnu because He never takes birth within the material creation, unlike Brahma and Åšiva. This also indicates His identity with the Purusa, who alone existed before the creation. The pro- noun “He” in verse 3.8.15 of Bhagavata Purana refers to the PuruÈ™a, who existed before the creation - before even the birth of Brahma and Åšiva. This is understood from the context of the preceding verses. Although Jiva GosvÄmÄ« has firmly established the supremacy of VisÅ†u, to make it yet more evident, he takes up the subject again. He raises opposition by citing various references that seem to speak of Åšiva’s supremacy or equality with VisÅ†u. Then, he provides the correct understanding of such statements. Such a process of estab- lishing a principle is called sthunÄƒ-nikhanana-nyaya, i.e., driving a post into the ground or hitting a nail into a wall. The more the post or nail is hammered, the firmer it becomes. Similarly, the more a principle has objections raised against it that are then refuted, the more assuredly it becomes established. Sinnar framun As said earlier, Åšiva is a very prominent deity in India, and the supremacy of Visnu is not easily acceptable to non-Vaisnavas, espe- cially those who lean toward the worship of Åšiva. Without clear- ing this confusion as regards Åšiva’s status in relation to Bhagavan ViÅŸÅ†u, it would be difficult to develop firm faith in bhakti unto Bha- gavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, which is the abhidheya-tattva of the BhÄgavata PurÄá¹‡a. Hence, the present exercise is taken up. In other PurÄÅ†as, it is described that if one sees Brahma or Åšiva as distinct from ViÅŸÅ†u, he goes to Naraka [the destination of wrongdoers after death].3 à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤š à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥Œ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯ 1 2 3 trayÄá¹‡Äm eka-bhÄvÄnÄá¹ yo na paÅ›yati vai bhidÄm na te mayy acyute’je ca bhidam anv api caká¹£ate Naraka is an infernal region where those who flout the Vedic injunctions are obliged to enter after death. They are meted out punishment according to the severity of their offense. After due punishment, they again take birth as per their karma. There are many divisions of Naraka. A detailed description of the Naraka planets is given in Canto 5, Chapter 26 of Bhagavata PurÄá¹‡a. 116 117 Viá¹£á¹‡u Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva à¤ˆà¤¶à¥à¤µà¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤• à¤à¤µ à¤¸ à¤¸ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤ƒâ€ (à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ [Reply]: It is true. We also are not propounding a difference [between them], because we began this topic by saying that they are all forms of the Supreme PuruÅŸa and are therefore one. The meaning here is that although Åšiva and Brahma are seen to have distinct natures, and so on, in regard to their respective func- tions of dissolution and creation, they should not be considered as separate supreme controllers (IÅ›vara) independent of Visnu in the carrying out of these acts. Rather, they are in fact His own forms. Therefore, it is said, “Bhagavan is situated in Brahma in the form of Brahma, and so on” (Vamana Purana) à¤¨ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¦à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤£à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤™à¥à¤—à¥€à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤•à¥‡à¤µà¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤£à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤—à¤£à¤¨à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤š à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¥ˆà¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤®- “dmow” ba sdr Nor are we imagining this hierarchy of direct and indirect forms of the different manifestations [of the Purusa], but it is the scripture itself dealing with transcendence that affirms it. We have simply made evident such scriptural statements. Since the latter’s initial flux (ayana) [in the matter of cos- mic creation] takes place there, He is thus called NÄrÄyaá¹‡a [He whose place of movement is the waters]” (VP 1.4.6). à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ F The word “womb” (yoni) [in the Devi-sÃ¼kta verse] means cause or source, that ba yana tabla Similarly, it is said in the Skanda Purana: à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥à¤‚ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ gainigemi tagatik adtie yigmin aved slidwayfiel à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¤•à¥ˆà¤µà¤²à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸ à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤•à¥‡à¤µà¤²à¥‹ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥¬ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Only You, Bhagavan Hari, are intrinsically of the nature of kaivalya [or supreme transcendence], a kaivalya that gods, debeginning with Brahma and Åšiva, cannot attain. (Vaisnava-tantra)” à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° (à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥¨à¥©à¥«à¥¤à¥¯)- Elsewhere it is said: à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤‚ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥® à¤¸à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤µà¥€à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤ à¤¸ à¤ªà¤¾à¤·à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥€ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥® à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ M bm mid One who perceives gods like Brahma and Rudra as equal to Bha- -gavÃ¤n NÄrÄyaá¹‡a is certainly a heretic. (Padma Purana, Uttara-ar Orkhanda 235.9b-10a)12v à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒ â€œà¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥€à¤¨à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¤¤à¥‡ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ pontour biber And there is the Åšruti, “All the universal gods worship Bhagavan Vamana [Viá¹£á¹‡u] who is sitting in the center” (KU 2.2.3).13 Hirwheesely gat bas Commentary ng Tagapa os saloga sv svia THE FIRST VERSE that ÅšrÄ« Jiva discusses is spoken by Bhagavan Visnu Himself to Daká¹£a (SB 4.7.54). Åšiva’s throng had destroyed 11 na labheyuh punar bhaktim harer aikÄntikim jaá¸Äá¸¥ ekagra-manasaÅ› capi viá¹£á¹‡u-sÄmÄnya-darÅ›inaá¸¥ 12 yas tu nÄrÄyaá¹‡am devam brahma-rudrÄdi-daivataiá¸¥ samatvenaiva viká¹£eta sa paÅŸandi bhaved dhruvam Alternate reading: 13 samam anyair niriká¹£eta Å›Ã¤stra pÄá¹£andi bhavet sadÄ madhye vÄmanam ÄsÄ«nam viÅ›ve devÄ upÄƒsate smen bus brand-bala18 119 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self Daká¹£a’s sacrifice and cut off his head. Later on, Brahma and the other devas pacified Åšiva, who fastened a goat’s head to Daká¹£a’s torso, bringing him back to life. Then Daká¹£a completed the sacri- fice in which Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u had appeared to accept the oblation. ViÅŸÅ†u was eulogized by the devas including Åšiva and Brahma, and, after hearing their prayers, He answered them. The verse cited at the beginning of this section comes from that speech. Therein ViÅŸÅ†u appears to say that Brahma and Åšiva are equal to Him, since all three are said to be the cause of the universe. It would thus seem improper to conclude that Visnu is superior to Brahma and Åšiva. The next verse discussed by ÅšrÄ« Jiva is spoken by Åšiva to the sage MÄrkaá¹‡á¸eya (SB 12.10.22). One day, MÄrkaá¹‡á¸eya was meditating in his asrama on the bank of the Puspabhadra River in the Malaya Mountains. When Åšiva and his wife Parvati were traveling through the sky, Parvati saw MÃ¤rkandeya and felt compassionate toward him, and so she urged Åšiva to bless him. Åšiva replied that the sage had attained perfection and had no desires to fulfill, yet he agreed to descend into the aÅ›rama just to benefit from his company. At that moment, the sage was in the state of samadhi and there- fore did not notice Åšiva’s arrival. So, Åšiva devised a technique to draw him out of his samadhi. He entered into the sage’s citta-vá¹›tti, or mental state, and thus the sage’s object of meditation suddenly disappeared and he saw Åšiva in his heart. This was a surprise to him, and he wondered what had happened. In a huff, he opened his eyes and saw Åšiva standing directly in front of him. He then offered worship to Åšiva and Parvati and recited prayers. Being pleased with his reception, Åšiva spoke to the sage. The present verse is part of that dialogue. This verse also speaks of the oneness of Brahma, Åšiva, and VisÅ†u. Many Puranic verses state that if one regards these three devas as different from one another, such a person will enter Naraka. For example, the Padma PurÄÅ†a says: 14 Agaricini mu It is an offense against the Holy Name to perceive the attributes and name of Åšiva as different from those of Visnu. (Padma PurÄá¹‡a, Brahma-khanda 25.15)14 sivasya Å›rÄ« viÅŸnor ya iha guá¹‡anÄmÄdisakalamske mombas 120 17 VisÅ†u Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva And in the Narada PurÄá¹‡a: svi bna To disregard one’s guru, to criticize sadhus, to uphold a differ- ence between Hari and Åšiva, and to criticize the Vedas, all on the strength of the Holy Name of Hari, is to strive simply for offenses. (Narada Purana 1.82.22)15 bas bemen 916 Laziv 10 201 Vos 0 2010love to at borIn response to all these verses, ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmi argues that Brahma and Åšiva are not separate from VisÅ†u, yet they have dif- ferent roles in respect to the creation and dissolution. They are not independent controllers, but manifestations of Visnu for executing specific functions. However, this does not mean that Brahma and Åšiva are equal to VisÅ†u. For ÅšrÄ« Jiva, that Brahma and Åšiva are not different from Visnu means that they are not independent of Him. In GÄªTÄ€ 7.19, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a declares that one who sees everything as Vasudeva (a name for VisÅ†u) is a rare exalted being. This does not mean that everything is Visnu in His complete form. Rather, it means that everything is a manifestation of Visnu’s energy and thus not independent of Him. Everything manifests from Him, but all manifestations are not equal to Him in all respects. There are varieties and gradations of manifestations - a fact that is borne out by our own experience. Visnu is the only independent entity, the Supreme Person, for which there is ample scriptural evidence. The simple principle of real causation is that an effect is both non- different from its cause and dependent upon it. A cause, however, is not identical to its effect and is independent of it. As was described in Anuccheda 10, the sage Atri prayed to the Supreme Regulator of the universe. In response to this plea, Brahma, Åšiva, and Visnu each appeared before him and blessed him to have a son like themselves. By their blessings, three sons were born, named Soma, DurvÄsÄ, and Dattatreya. Now, in the list of avatÄras given in the First Canto, the son of Atri, named Dattatreya, is enumerated as the sixth, but the other two are not mentioned. Dattatreya was born by the blessing of Visnu, and his 15 dhiya bhinnam paÅ›yet sa khalu harinÄmÄhitakaraá¸¥ guror avajÃ±Äm sÄdhunam nindam bhedam hare harau veda-nindÄm harer nama-balÄt papa-samihanam fi formim 121 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self inclusion in this list implies the superiority of Viá¹£á¹‡u over Brahma and Åšiva. blodg This demonstrates that the manifestations of Åšiva and Brahma in the form of DurvÄsÄ and Soma are not on a par with Dattatreya, a manifestation of VisÅ†u. Moreover, it may further be noted that in all lists of avataras only the descents of Visnu are named, and not those of Åšiva or Brahma, nor are these gods themselves named as avataras. In Bhagavad Gita (4.8), Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a says that He comes as an avatara to establish dharma. There are no such statements about Åšiva or Brahma. bo There are also explicit statements declaring that it is highly improper to consider Brahma and Åšiva as equal to VisÅ†u. These apparently contradictory scriptural declarations, i.e., one should not consider Åšiva and Brahma as different from VisÅ†u, and one should not see Brahma or Åšiva as equal to VisÅ†u, must be rec- onciled in order to establish their real intent. This requires proper understanding, which ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va attempts to provide in this anuccheda. 916 and nd lamps to sit am auri amod 17.2line Relativity of Åšiva’s Supremacy 10 alqisaing sigenda er à¤¨à¤¨à¥ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ ? à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µ- à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¬à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤®à¤¶à¥ˆà¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ (à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥­à¥§ à¥¤à¥§à¥¦à¥¬-à¥§à¥¦à¥­) - A further doubt is raised: In some other scriptures, Åšiva is described as the Supreme Deity. [In reply we say,] true, but that can be overridden if one considers the essential and non- essential elements of the scripture. In the Padma and Åšiva PurÄƒ- nas, Åšiva repeats the following words of Bhagavan Viá¹£á¹‡u to UmÄ Devi: I tem à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¶à¤®à¥à¤­à¥‹ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥€à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤µà¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾ à¥¤flora wwwg à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¯à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤•à¤²à¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥¯ à¥¥ and norther word. pratiman-alore 122 17 Visnu Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¤®à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥ˆà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤•à¥à¤°à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤—à¥‹à¤ªà¤¯ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥­à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤• O Sambhu, I continuously propitiate you to secure from you this boon, that in the beginning of Kali, you appear 07 among the human beings through your own partial expan-A asssion. (Varaha Purana 70.35-36) 16 DvÃ¤paradau (lit., at the beginning of Dvaparayuga) is to be taken as a bahuvrihi-samÄsa, conveying the sense of dvÃ¤para adi yasya iti kaliá¸¥, meaning, “Kali is that [age] whose beginning (adi) is [at the end of] Dvapara.” baxin add ai segÄm iz t 17 tvÄm ÄrÄdhya taya sambho grahiá¹£yÄmi varam sadÄ dvÄparÄdau yuge bhutvÄ kalaya manuá¹£Ädiá¹£u svagamaiá¸¥ kalpitais tvam tu janan mad-vimukhan kurum).(extiq) mam ca gopaya yena syat sá¹›á¹£á¹­ir eÅŸottarottarÄƒ esa moham srjamy aÅ›u yo janan mohayisyati ambo ni Sn] tvam ca rudra mahabaho moha-Å›ÄstrÄá¹‡i kÄraya atathyÃ¤ni vitathyani darÅ›ayasva mahÄbhuja prakÄÅ›aá¹ kuru cÄtmÄnam aprakÄÅ›am ca mÄá¹ kuru Of the two verses quoted under this footnote, the first consists of the second half of verse 35 and the first half of verse 36. Therefore, only those PurÄÅ†as that establish VisÅ†u as Supreme provide complete knowledge, for, as it is said: “Knowledge arises from sattvaâ€ (GÄªTÄ€ 14.17). So, too, it is said in the Matsya PurÄna: 19 cons à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥­à¥© à¥¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥„à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¨à¤¿à¤—à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥­à¥ª à¥¥ à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤­à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¡à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤®à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤­à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥­à¥« à¥¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¥ˆà¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤•à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µ à¤š à¥¤ arguti à¤­à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤—à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥­à¥¬ à¥¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤®à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤²à¥ˆà¤™à¥à¤—à¤‚ à¤¶à¥ˆà¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µ à¤š à¥¤ tup me 1 Out roads MoY ashtod of oxy our à¤†à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¯à¤•à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤—à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥­à¥­ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ bid bng taasuo les of garbhognitingad saralailbo The sÃ¤ttvika PurÄnas primarily glorify Bhagavan Hari, the rÄja- sika PurÄnas, BrahmÄ, and the tÄmasika PurÄnas, Siva and Agni. PurÄnas in the mixed gunas glorify Sarasvati and the ancestors (pitrs).
