(Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 236.19, 20, 21, 18)21 al Pissertions à¤…à¤¤ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤·à¤£à¥à¤®à¥à¤–à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ lie 903 al CH Head asnoyrave to Therefore, ÅšrÄ« Åšiva told KÃ¤rttikeya in Skanda Puraá¹‡a: à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¿ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥­à¥® à¥¥ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤· à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¥‹à¤¹à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¹à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥­à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ the In scriptures related to Åšiva, one should accept only those por-h tions that support the conclusions presented in scriptures related to Bhagavan [Visnu]. Visnu alone is Supreme, and knowledge of Him is the sole means to liberation. This is the verdict of the scriptures, and everything else is only for the sake of bewilderment. (Skanda Purana)22 Commentary eng suade joomistat antwollot droom vs Dev M In some scriptures, Åšiva is described as the Supreme Person. For example, in Skanda Purana, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a tells SudÄmÄ: 21 vaiá¹£á¹‡avaá¹ nÄradÄ«yam ca tatha bhagavatam subhe gÄruá¸am ca tathÄ pÄdmaá¹ vÄrÄhaá¹ subha-darÅ›ane Elemis o brahmaá¹‡á¸am brahma-vaivartaá¹ mÃ¤rkandeyam tathaiva ca bhaviá¹£yam vÄmanaá¹ brahmyaá¹ rÄjasÃ¤ni nigadyate [nibodha me]edd mÄtsyaá¹ kÅ«rmaá¹ tatha laingam saivam skÃ¤ndam tathaiva ca agneyakaá¹ tathaitani tÄmasÃ¤ni nigadyate Alternate reading: agneyam ca È™adetani tÄmasÃ¤ni nibodha me paramo viÅŸnur evaikas taj-jÃ±Änam moká¹£a-sÄdhanam squld be use 22 siva-sastresu tad grahyaá¹ bhagavac-chastra-yogi yatad sind du Å›ÄstrÄá¹‡Äá¹ nirnayas tv esas tad anyan mohanaya hi This verse is untraceable in the extant versions. day by whe 125 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self The devas headed by Brahma and Myself are grantors of liberation from this material world only by the grace of Åšiva. There is no doubt in this. Åšiva is the Great God (Mahadeva) and great con- troller (MaheÅ›vara), both in name and deed. O sinless one! Oth- ers are only gods, but not the Great God. (Skanda PurÄá¹‡a, SÅ«ta- Apsamhita 25.47, 25.51)23 In SvetÄÅ›vatara Upanisad it is said: da Everywhere are his faces, heads, and necks. He is in the cavity of everyone’s heart. He is the all-pervading Bhagavan. Therefore, Åšiva is everywhere. (Å›u 3.11)24 (atrÄ 14.37) 7) So, too, it i is said in the Matsya Purana: to He is stated to be the cause of Brahma and Visnu in Rudra- há¹›daya Upanisad: Visnu is the effect and Brahma the action, but MaheÅ›vara (Åšiva) is the cause. It is only for the purpose of creation that Åšiva, who is one, manifests in three forms. (Rudra-hrdaya Upanisad 15)25 The Utpatti-tantra declares the worship of Åšiva as compulsory for everyone: sloa ad bus asungima adi 3p jalbrev Whether one is a worshiper of Sakti, Viá¹£Å†u, Surya, or Ganapati, my dear, one cannot attain perfection without worshiping Åšiva. (Utpatti-tantra)26 Vistremmo Moreover, Parvati Devi makes the following statement about herself to her father, Himalaya: 23 24 O Himalaya, all this world is pervaded by me in all directions. I am the supreme controller (IÅ›vara), the self that runs thread-like mama brahmadi-devaÅ›ca prasÄdÄt tasya sulinaá¸¥ bhoga-moká¹£a-pradaá¸¥ pumsÄm prasado jayate’nagha oman maglend nÄmataÅ›cÃ¤rthataÅ›cÃ¤pi mahadevo maheÅ›varah ghiol riot is inten tadanye kevalam deva mahadeva na te’nagha sarvanana-siro-grÄ«vaá¸¥ sarva-bhÅ«ta-guhaÅ›ayaá¸¥ sarva-vyÄpi sa bhagavÄms tasmat sarva-gataá¸¥ Å›ivaá¸¥ kÃ¤ryam viÅŸnuá¸¥ kriya brahmÄ kÄraá¹‡am tu maheÅ›varaá¸¥ prayojanÃ¤rtham rudreÅ†a mÃ¼rtir ekÃ¤ tridhÃ¤ ká¹›tÄ 26 sakto vÄ vaiá¹£á¹‡avo vapi sauro va ganapo’thava sivarcana-vihinasya kutaá¸¥ siddhir bhavet priye 25 desamor al d

126 1-17 VisÅ†u Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva through existence (sÃ¼trÄtmÄ), and the cosmic being (virat). I am im Brahma, ViÅŸÅ†u, Rudra, Gauri, Brahmi, and Vaiá¹£á¹‡avÄ«. I am the sun, the stars, and the moon. Whatever is seen or heard - inside or out - I am always situated there while pervading it. There is no manifest object, movable or immovable, that is abandoned by me. (Devi-bhÄgavata Purana 7.33.12b, 13, 14a, 16-17a)27 H61 From the statements of Padma Purana and Varaha Purana cited in this anuccheda, it can be understood that scriptural assertions declaring Åšiva, or any god other than Visnu, as supreme are set forth for persons whose faith and eligibility accords with the gunas of rajas and tamas. At the level of self-identity that is presently plugged into rajas and tamas, the nirguna truth that Visnu embod- ies either makes no sense at all or is seen to be without pragmatic relevance. For this reason, the above-mentioned scriptural asser- tions serve to divert consciousness away from the nirguna truth, and to stabilize faith and awareness in the specific level for which such a person has eligibility. In this way, too, the cycle of nat- ural creation is perpetuated. So, the statements regarding Åšiva’s supremacy are relative in the sense that they have value for those at the lower to middle range of consciousness evolution. From the perspective of nirguna truth, however, they are not to be taken in their primary sense. This is also supported by other passages in the Devi-bhÄgavata PurÄá¹‡a: In this world, whatever scriptures oppose Åšruti and Smrti are surely tamasika. [The Tantra] scriptures, such as the VÄma, KapÄ- Blaka, Kaulaka, and Bhairava Ä€gamas, are propounded by Åšiva only V to bewilder people and not for anything else. Paris 27 In these books, there are also sometimes parts that do not oppose the Veda. Followers of the Veda incur no flaw in accepting those mayi sarvam idam protamotam ca dharani-dhara iÅ›varo’ham ca sÅ«trÄtmÄ virÄá¸ ÄtmÄham asmi ca brahmaham viá¹£á¹‡u-rudrau ca gauri brahmi ca vaiá¹£á¹‡avÄ« suryo’ham tÄrakÄÅ› cÄhaá¹ tÄrakeÅ›as tathÄsmy aham yac ca kiÃ±cit kvacid vastu dá¹›Å›yate Å›ruyate’pi vam antar bahis ca tat sarvam vyÃ¤pyahaá¹ sarvadÄƒ sthitÄ vedrandom anvil bbunlÃµhey mist Bromid-abov bultov na tad asti maya tyaktam vastu kiÃ±cic caracaramo sad ett bry 127 1 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self parts. A brÄhmaá¹‡a has no right at all to accept the other por- tions that are different from the Vedic teachings. A person who is not qualified to follow the Veda is eligible only for Tantra. (Devi-bhÄgavata Purana 7.39.26-27, 31-32) 28 The division of the Puranas according to the three gunas is spo- ken of by Åšiva to Parvati. Prior to this topic, Åšiva explains the signif- icance of fasting on the eleventh day of the lunar fortnight (EkÄdaÅ›Ä«- vrata) for the pleasure of VisÅ†u. In this context, he explains the procedure for observing the fast and lists the things to be avoided. One of the prohibitions forbids not only the association of heretics (pÄá¹£aá¹‡á¸Ä«s), but even the act of merely looking upon them. Åšiva then provides a lengthy list of people who fit his description of heretics. Included in the list are people who smear their bodies with ashes or adorn themselves with garlands of skulls. Hearing this description, Parvati raises a question about Åšiva himself, as to why he adorns his body with ashes, skulls, bones, and leather - the very articles forbidden by him and considered unclean. On this inquiry, Åšiva becomes very grave and replies that although it is the topmost secret, he will divulge it to PÄrvati because she is extremely dear to him. 928 lbbim wol adt is Åšiva relates that in the reign of Svayambhuva Manvantara, the great daityas like Namuci became devoted to Visnu and restrained themselves from all immoral acts. They devoted themselves to the Vedic principles and conduct. This greatly troubled the devas, headed by Indra, because they were consequently incapable of sub- duing the daityas. Being distressed, they approached Visnu and pleaded for His help. At that time, Viá¹£á¹‡u ordered Åšiva to behave like a heretic and propagate tÄmasika scriptures. Hearing this, Åšiva became sad and said, “O Lord, I will do as You command, but this axawollot Eb 28 anyÄni yani Å›ÄstrÄá¹‡i loke’smin vividhani ca Å›ruti-smá¹›ti-viruddhani tÄmasÄny eva sarvaÅ›aá¸¥ vÃ¤maá¹ kapalakaá¹ caiva kaulakaá¹ bhairavagamahá¸¥ sivena mohanÃ¤rthaya pranito nanya-hetukaá¸¥hen-negie redundord tatra vedÃ¤viruddho’mso’pyukta eva kvacit kvacit vaidikais tad grahe doÈ™o na bhavaty eva karhicit sarvathÃ¤ veda-bhinnÃ¤rthe nadhikari dvijo bhavet vedadhikara-hÄ«nas tu bhavet tantrÃ¤dhikÄravÄn 128 117 Visnu Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva will bring about my ruin.” Bhagavan VisÅ†u conferred upon him a thousand of His Names and a six syllable mantra to chant. This would provide him protection. Åšiva then describes how he propagated tamasika scriptures, the MÄyÄvÄda doctrine, Saiva-Å›Ã¤stra, and so on. He also lists the PurÄÅ†as according to the divisions of the gunas. He concludes: “The sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as lead to liberation, the rajasika PurÄÅ†as are ever inauspicious, and the tamasika PurÄÅ†as lead to hell, O Devi” (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 235.21-22). The verse cited from Varaha Purana is spoken by Bhagavan Visnu. In the same chapter, Åšiva explains why it is that people are bewildered about the real spiritual path, which is bhakti to Hari. He tells sage Agastya that in the past, all human beings on earth were pious and engaged in bhakti to Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. As a result, liberation became the normal state of affairs for all of them. Concerned about this, the devas approached Visnu and submitted to Him that the cre- ation would not be able to proceed in this manner, since everyone was engaged in bhakti. Hearing this, VisÅ†u said that He would cre- ate delusion and ordered Åšiva to propagate illusory scriptures. Åšiva then relates the story of how sage Gautama cursed the brahmanas to become heretics in Kaliyuga and how they propagated delusory literature, being bewildered by Åšiva. The hermeneutic principle that Jiva GosvÄmi proposes is that not all scriptures carry equal authority. Although different scrip- tures apparently seem to propound different deities or spiritual practices, their ultimate aim culminates in only one Absolute Real- ity. There is no conflict among the scriptures, as confirmed by Brahma-sutra (1.1.4): “But the truth that Brahman is knowable only through the Vedas is due to the fact that the Vedas are consistently reconciled in Him alone.“29 ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va continues with this theme by citing from the NÄrÄyaá¹‡Ä«ya section of Mahabharata. BP The son of Brahma, known as UmÃ¤pati, Bhutapati, ÅšrÄ«kantha, or YOÅšiva, who is of unwavering mind, spoke the body of knowledge called Pasupata. 98 The speaker of the entire PaÃ±carÄtra system is, however, the original complete Absolute Truth, Svayam Bhagavan, who is 92visible in all these different systems of knowledge, O best of kings. batio -80997 adi al odwyĞ¹ hÃ¨ vino nifi of 19bzo ni amataya In conformity to the respective scriptures and to the respective forms of knowledge, O Lord of the earth, Bhagavan NÄrÄyaá¹‡a is the ultimate end [of all these systems], but people covered by ignorance do not understand this fact in this way. -gi AlbamiH The great thinkers and authors of the scriptures proclaim only Him, the sage NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, as the original cause of the scriptures and no one else. This is my view. Bhagavan Hari ever abides in all those scriptures that speak of Him unambiguously. But Bhagavan Madhava [Hari] does not reside in any scripture that speaks with ambiguity or on the OM ho strength of reasoning alone. dgos godt fedt O King, those who are true knowers of the PaÃ±carÄtra, however, follow it in the proper sequence, and upon attaining exclusive devotion [to Bhagavan Hari], they verily enter into Him. TO King, both, SÃ¤nkhya and Yoga, as well as all the Vedas, are Meternal. All the sages combined together have concluded that this primeval creation is NÄrÄyaá¹‡a. This [fact] is known from the same section of Mahabharata (Santi-parva 349.59). These [ten] verses should be explained as follows: [In the first verse cited above,] ÅšrÄ« VaiÅ›ampayana points out various philosophical systems in order to affirm only ÅšrÄ« NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, who is the recog- nized Deity of the PaÃ±caratra, as supreme above all. In the fifth verse, he establishes the superiority of the PaÃ±carÄtra [scrip- tural tradition] alone, saying that it is spoken by Bhagavan Himself. à¤…à¤¥ " à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥Œ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥Œ à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µ à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤° à¤à¤µ à¤šâ€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ â€œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£ à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥ â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ â€œà¤¨ à¤šà¥ˆà¤¨à¤®à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ (à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¥©à¥®à¥§ à¥¤ à¥©à¥¯) - add to mil Now, when it was said, “These are various kinds of philo- sophical perspectives” (first verse), it should be understood that they [come into being] in accordance with the secularist- materialistic (Äsurika) nature, for it is said: “In this world, there are two types of created beings - divine and Ã¤surika” (dvau bhÅ«ta-sargau loke’smin daiva asura eva ca, GÄªTÄ€ 16.6). After care- fully examining all the various knowledge systems, people of paÃ±carÄtrasya ká¹›tsnasya vaktÄ tu bhagavan svayam sarveÈ™u ca ná¹›pa-Å›restha jÃ±Äneá¹£v eteá¹£u dá¹›Å›yate lavaming eids yathÄgamam yatha-jÃ±Änam niá¹£á¹­hÄ nÄrÄyaá¹‡aá¸¥ prabhuá¸¥(-ARE LO na cainam evaá¹ jÄnanti tamo-bhÅ«tÄ visÄm pate tam eva Å›Ästra-kartÄram pravadanti maniá¹£inaá¸¥ niá¹£á¹­hÄm nÄrÄyaá¹‡am rÅŸim nanyo’stiti vaco mama niá¸¥saá¹sayeá¹£u sarveÅŸu nityam vasati vai hariá¸¥ sa-samsayan hetu-balan nÃ¤dhyÄvasati mÄdhavaá¸¥ paÃ±caratra-vido ye tu yatha-krama-parÄƒ ná¹›pa ekanta-bhÄvopagatÄs te harim praviÅ›anti vai sankhyam ca yogam ca sanatane dve vedaÅ› ca sarve nikhilena rÄjan sarvaiá¸¥ samastair rÅŸibhir nirukto narayano viÅ›vam idam purÄá¹‡am å‡ºã— 132 17 Visnu Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva the divine nature conclude that they all culminate only in ÅšrÄ« NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, who is propounded [as Bhagavan] in the PaÃ±caratra. This is stated in the fifth verse. In the second half of the sixth verse, sage Vaisampayana censures those of materialistic men- tality. This is reiterated in the ViÅŸnu-dharma Purana and the Agni Purana: einmo ass odw odw saod bred todo ads no [audrgnivaaj oliastnd à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥Œ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¥Œ à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µ à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤° à¤à¤µ à¤š à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µ à¤†à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ In this world, there are two types of created beings - divine Brand materialistic. Those who are consummately engaged in devotion to Bhagavan Visnu are divine, whereas those preoccupied in exactly the opposite are materialistic. (Agni Purana 381.39)31 à¤¨à¤¨à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¤à¤¯ à¤à¤µ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹ â€œà¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µâ€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¤°à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤ƒ - à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾-à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤‚ à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤•à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤° à¤‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£ à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µ- à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ the It may be asked: In different scriptures, different opinions are expressed [so how can anyone know that Visnu is their pur- pose?]. In response, the sage speaks the seventh verse. The authors of scriptures other than the PaÃ±caratra are of two types - those with limited knowledge and the omniscient. The first are those who offer a partial [or one-dimensional] view of the Absolute Reality that accords with their own respective metaphysics. Just as a description of a part of the ocean is still a description of the ocean, their explanations also culminate in the complete reality, Bhagavan NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, even though they speak of Him in a limited way. 31 dvau bhÅ«ta-sargau loke’smin daiva asura eva ca viÅŸÅ†u-bhakti-paro daiva asuras tad-viparyayaá¸¥ Alternate reading: adt en badeil art al smeiqua tovopada homie odr and batasbenorquin dound ahimsÄdiá¸¥ ká¹£amÄƒ caiva daivi-sampattito ná¹›á¹‡Äm na saucam napi vÄcÄro hy asurisampadodbhavaá¸¥ologs to tual art movi 1331 The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤šà¥ˆà¤µà¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ â€“ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¥‹à¤¹à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤•à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¥‡à¤£ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤°à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¬à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤•à¥à¤²à¥‡à¤¶à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤—à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤š à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤®à¤¯à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤·à¥à¤ à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤•à¥‡ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤à¤µ à¤—à¤¾à¤¢à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹ â€œà¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒà¤¸à¤‚à¤¶à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥ â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ On the other hand, those who are omniscient have the following intention [saying thus]: “The scriptures have not been authored by us simply to confound the materialists, but to enlighten those of divine nature through negative inferential insight (vyati- reka). After examining these scriptures that propound a partial [and hence divided] view of reality that is mixed with rajas and tamas and that propose excessively arduous [spiritual] prac- tices, and after seeing that the Vedas are difficult to comprehend, people will lose interest [in these other texts]. They may then plunge deep into the PaÃ±carÄtra, which skillfully establishes the pure undivided [i.e., complete] Absolute Reality, Bhagavan NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, who is the essence of all the Vedas and whose worship is easily executed.” It is to this end, then, that VaiÅ›ampÄyana speaks the eighth verse. à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤œà¥ à¤à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹ â€œà¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ â€œà¤¸à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤š à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤‚ à¤š â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤ à¤à¤µà¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ â€œà¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥­à¥¤à¥§à¥¦) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤•à¥ƒà¤¦à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€- à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤šà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Consequently, in order to incite exclusive study of the PaÃ±cara- tra for those who wish to quickly apprehend the true mean- ing of the Vedas, VaiÅ›ampÄyana goes on to speak the ninth verse. And because this is the situation, he concludes with the final verse. Thus, if the supremacy of Bhagavan is estab- lished as the teaching of the PaÃ±carÄtra, then how much more supreme is the form of Bhagavan that is established as such by the Srimad Bhagavatam, a [text] which time and again offers unprecedented teachings such as this: “The sages, though freed from the knot of egoic identity, and though delighting in the 134 17 Visnu Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva Self alone, engage in causeless devotion to ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, the majes- tic player. Such, indeed, are the entrancing qualities of ÅšrÄ« Hari (Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a)” (SB 1.7.10).32 This specific form established by the Bhagavata Purana should be discussed. Commentary respect sadbgass sgoy sydne One may ask why Å›Ã¤stra would involve the intention to bewilder people. In reply, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va says that not all scriptures carry equal authority. The scriptures are related to the three gunas of praká¹›ti, just as ViÅŸÅ†u, Brahma, and Åšiva are also similarly related. As VisÅ†u, the facilitator of sattva-guna, is superior to Brahma and Åšiva, the scriptures connected to sattva are also superior to those of rajas and tamas. This is so because only sattva can release one from material bondage, as confirmed by Åšiva, “A conditioned being is liberated by sattva, whose essence is NÄrÄyaá¹‡a” (Varaha Purana 70.20).33 Peo- ple become attracted to deities and scriptures in correspondence to the guna, or nature, with which they are predominantly identified (sama-sila bhajanti vai, SB 1.2.27). Those who are under the influ- ence of rajas and tamas would naturally be attracted to the deities connected to those gunas, and the Å›Ã¤stras provide them support by strengthening their faith in those particular deities. Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a also affirms this point: “I alone supply unwavering faith to the devotees of various deities toward whatever specific deity they wish to worship with faith” (GITA 7.21)34 True knowledge, however, comes only from sattva, which has an illuminating nature. The correct understanding of sastra can be known only when one is impelled by sattva. Furthermore, any statement that contradicts the sÃ¤ttvika scripture must be inter- preted to reconcile with it. The conclusion of all scripture is that Visnu is the Supreme Person and that devotion to Him alone is 32 34 ÄtmÄrÄmÄÅ› ca munayo nirgrantha apy urukrame kurvanty ahaitukim bhaktim itthambhÅ«ta-guno hariá¸¥ 33 sattvena mucyate jantuá¸¥ sattvam nÄrÄyaá¹‡Ätmakam yo yo yam yam tanum bhaktaá¸¥ Å›raddhayÄrcitum icchati tasya tasyacalaá¹ Å›raddham tam eva vidadhamy aham 165 135 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self both the means and the end. The various opinions exist because people with a materialistic nature do not accept VisÅ†u as Supreme, so they are naturally attracted to scriptures related to other paths, even though those too lead to Visnu indirectly. T The verses cited here are spoken by sage VaiÅ›ampÄyana in response to King Janamejaya’s query about the ultimate purpose of Sankhya, Yoga, PaÃ±carÄtra, and Aranyaka. From the sage’s reply, it is evident that there are three divisions of sastra, namely, the Vedas (also called nigama), the PaÃ±caratra (also called agama), and the darÅ›anas propagated by various sages. The intention of the authors of Å›Ã¤stra is to bring people to the Absolute Reality, Bhaga- van. The PaÃ±carÄtra is written as an alternative to the Veda, which is very difficult to understand and follow. Nor is everyone eligible to follow it. The authors of sastra other than the PaÃ±carÄtra, are of two types - those who know Reality only in part and those who know it fully. The first group writes according to their own realizations, and that too is a description of the Ultimate Reality, albeit only in part. The second group writes to bring people to the PaÃ±caratra path, seeing that following the Veda is cumbersome and that the paths propagated by the first group are imperfect, being related to rajas and tamas. Sometimes competition is needed in order to realize an object’s worth. Bhagavan Rama’s prowess was known because of RÄvana. Without RÄvana, ÅšrÄ« RÄma would have lived an ordinary life and people might not have appreciated His greatness. It is for this rea- son that many types of literature are written. One of their aims may be to keep the Ã£surika people busy with some sort of discipline and practice so that they do not cause too much of a disturbance in society. As it is said, an idle mind is the devil’s workshop and the idle mind of a devil would be a devil’s factory! Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑƒĞ· The other purpose is to provide those whose nature is primar- ily sÃ¤ttvika with a suitable context in which they may consider contradictory points of view presented in the form of an oppo- nent’s position (purva-paká¹£a). By refuting such oppositional views, they come to understand the PaÃ±caratra theology more decisively. 136 17 VisÅ†u Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva Moreover, although it is said that there are two types of people, namely, daiva and asurika, the fact remains that the majority of peo- ple are a mixture of both. So the rajasika and tamasika inclinations persist even in those who are principally of divine nature. These inclinations need to be uprooted to intensify one’s faith and fixity in VisÅ†u. Thus, the third category of literature aids in this respect by functioning as a counterpoint (pÃ¼rva-paksa). The subject of the PaÃ±caratra is ViÅŸÅ†u. Therefore, according to MahÄbhÄrata, one should follow the PaÃ±caratra system. ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va is using this as an a fortiori argument to inspire people to study the BhÄgavatam, which describes Bhagavan in such an unprece- dented manner that even ÄtmÄrÄmas like Sukadeva are captivated to study it. The ÄtmÄrama has no desires to fulfill and no aims to achieve, yet even such a self-realized sage is attracted to the study of the BhÄgavatam, a substantial book. How much more interest, then, should a common person take in it? For this reason, ÅšrÄ« Jiva next investigates what the Bhagavata PurÄna has to say about the relative superiority of the three devas. 17.4 om buiniz avle à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤ Sadasiva Is Not the Supreme of basis via ion aloitasug To digia di to senov à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤¹à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤š à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥- à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤¶à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤—à¤®à¥‡ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¹à¤¿à¤®à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¨à¤¾à¤¯ à¤§à¥ƒà¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°- à¤¶à¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤®à¤£à¥€ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤œà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤— à¤à¤µ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ According to the above verses, the contention that Sadasiva is the supreme controller and that Brahma, Viá¹£á¹‡u, and Åšiva are his expansions is also refuted. It should also be understood that because of the above reasons [that Sadasiva is not supreme], the Åšaiva Agama assigns appellations, such as Sadasiva, etc., to Bha- gavan and Purusa only for the purpose of glorifying Sadasiva. But in the Srimad Bhagavatam, the crest jewel of all scriptures, there is an inquiry into the gradation of the members of the 137 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self trinity of gods, i.e., Brahma, Viá¹£á¹‡u, and Åšiva, [but] no mention at all of any such gradation between Bhagavan and the Purusa. à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥§à¥ªà¥¤à¥¨à¥® - scort ni nava salaraq à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤²à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¤‚ à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ head 1.99 à¤†à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¥€ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¶à¤¾à¤šà¤šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤¹à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¡à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥§ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Josidual arith [In this context] it may be noted that the following statement in the Third Canto also indicates that Åšiva is nondifferent from ParameÅ›vara due to being a gunavatara: asb Even Brahma and the other gods respect the bounds set by [Lord Siva]. He is the cause of this universe and MÄyÄ is his maidser- vant. And yet he behaves like a fiend (pisaca). Strange, indeed, dos Jasare the activities of the Almighty Lord! (SB 3.14.28)35 anos do à¤¨à¤¨à¥ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥®à¥¤à¥­à¥¤à¥©à¥§)- à¤¨ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤—à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤ªà¤¾à¤²à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¥à¤£à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤°à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥‡ ? sted asd Ğ’Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´ Question: Is not Åšiva stated to be the Supreme in the following verse of the Eighth Canto? PO Giritra [protector of the mountains], Åšiva, your supreme Weffulgence cannot be understood even by all the protectors of the planets, by Brahma, by VisÅ†u, or by Indra, the ruler of on the gods. This effulgence is the Supreme Absolute, Brahman, utterly devoid of all distinctions, in which rajas, tamas, and sattva are entirely absent. (SB 8.7.31)36 DA à¤®à¥ˆà¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤®à¤¹à¤¿à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‚à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤§à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥ˆà¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤•à¥‚à¤Ÿà¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ â€œà¤ªà¥à¤°à¥€à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¹à¤°à¥Œ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥€à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¸à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤šà¤°â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥®à¥¤à¥­à¥¤à¥ªà¥¦) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ 35 36 brahmadayo yat-ká¹›ta-setu-pÄlÄ yat-kÄraá¹‡aá¹ viÅ›vam idam ca mÄyÄ Ã¶vez ÄjÃ±Ä-karÄ« yasya piÅ›Äca-carya aho vibhumnas caritam viá¸ambanam add mi tud na te giri-trÄkhila-loka-pala- viriÃ±ca-vaikuntha-surendra-gamyam jyotiá¸¥ param yatra rajas tamaÅ› ca sattvam na yad brahma nirasta-bhedamarly 138 17 VisÅ†u Is Inclusive of and Superior to Brahma and Åšiva [Answer]: No, this is not the implication of the above verse. There is a Vedic principle, “Gods excel in power when they are praised through glorious words.“37 Thus, such a conclusion [that Åšiva is Supreme] is improper. This prayer was uttered simply to induce Åšiva to drink the deadly poison [called] kalakÅ«á¹­a. In the same section, Åšiva says: “When Bhagavan Hari is pleased, then I and all the moving and non-moving beings are pleased” (SB 8.7.40).38 bit à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¨à¤µà¤®à¥‡ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¯à¥¤à¥ªà¥¤à¥«à¥¬ ) - (2.018) la sit ni tub loanlaiting Furthermore, in the Ninth Canto, Åšiva tells DurvÄsÄ: à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤® à¤­à¥‚à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤œà¤œà¥€à¤µà¤•à¥‹à¤·à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¥€à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¶à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤­à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥© à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ We [gods] have no power, dear son, over the all-pervading Supreme, in whom other universes, too, similar to this- and which are the amalgamated bodies of the jivas and BrahmÄ - appear and disappear in thousands at the appointed time. We wander in these universes. (SB 9.4.56)39 Sin Alfists â€œà¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¶à¥‡ à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥­à¥¤à¥¨à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤šà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸- à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤·à¤®à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤µ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¦ à¥®à¥­ à¥¨à¥ªà¥§) And [Åšiva again says]: “Remaining under the control of that Supreme Person, we are like birds controlled by a string” (SB 5.17.23).40 So, it is not the case [that Åšiva is Supreme, as might be inferred from SB 8.7.31 above], because such a conclusion is contradicted by the above statements of Åšiva. Alternatively, the meaning [of that verse] can be taken as follows: It is indeed fit- ting that even He [Visnu] is unable to know completely the con- scious being called ParamÄtmÄ, situated within the effulgence of Åšiva. As the Åšrutis said to Bhagavan: 37 mahimnÄ stÅ«yamÄnÄ hi devÄ vÄ«ryeá¹‡a vardhante 38 prite harau bhagavati priye’ham sacaracaraá¸¥a 39 vayam na tÄta prabhavama bhÃ¼mni yasmin pare’nye’py aja-jiva-koá¹£aá¸¥-for bhavanti kale na bhavanti hidá¹›Å›aá¸¥ sahasraÅ›o yatra vayam bhramamaá¸¥ my by ete vayam yasya vase mahÄtmanaá¸¥ sthitaá¸¥ Å›akunta iva sutra-yantritÄá¸¥ment O 139 I The Ontology of ParamÄtmÄ - The Supreme Immanent Self à¤˜à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¯ à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤¯à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ okho[mrowiA] à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¨à¤¿à¤šà¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥ª à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤dr ahrow Bucholg duords banisiq Because You are without end or limit, the cosmic administra-vi altors [such as Brahma] simply cannot find any limit to You. of bs Moreover, even You cannot do so. There, while describing Govinda as the original source [or the uncaused cause] of everything, it is said: al à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾ à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥€ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤‚à¤µà¤¦à¤¾ à¥¤ owl mengua ama silt a dolfw Hogarth han sqqs à¤¤à¤²à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¶à¤®à¥à¤­à¥à¤°à¥à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤à¥¤ à¥¯à¥« à¥¤ sw à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥¬ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ BF 130 BE FO Rama Devi, who is under Bhagavan’s intrinsic guidance (niyati), is His beloved and remains submissive to His will (tad-vaÅ›am- vadÄ).
