(SB 11.13.22)1 of all suc The rative à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤²à¥Œà¤•à¤¿à¤•à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¤à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤°- à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¹à¤‚à¤¸à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤–à¤²à¥ à¤…à¤‚à¤¶à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤šà¥à¤›à¥‚à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤à¥§à¥©à¥¤à¥¨à¥©) - vastuno yady ananÃ¤tvam Ätmanaá¸¥ praÅ›na idá¹›Å›aá¸¥n the ganivetase, they katham ghateta vo viprÄ vaktur va me ka ÄÅ›rayaá¸¥ 226inli 32 A Distinct Jiva in Each Body fir In this regard, the oneness of the jivÄtmÄs indicated in the words of ÅšrÄ« Hamsadeva, who assumes the perspective of an ordinary jiva, is posited in accordance with the common fashion of a teacher of the jÃ±Äna-mÃ¤rga, or as a consequence of the mate- rial vision of the KumÄras [implied by their dualistic question]. So, although there is a difference among parts, or between the whole and its parts, this statement of the oneness of the jivas is indeed spoken as a means to jÃ±Äna for those desiring jÃ±Äna and is submitted with reference to the jivas’ common identity [of con- sciousness], without distinguishing their individuality. This type of undiscriminated reference to a single common attribute is expressed again in the very next verse: bas 30 sa à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥à¤­à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¨à¥© à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ (inamford sing) Your question, “Who are you?” [if it relates to the physical body], REVis indeed just a meaningless sequence of words, since the bodies of the living beings are identical, constituted in reality of the five elements. (SB 11.13.23)2 à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤¶à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¾ â€œà¤¶à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤šà¥ˆà¤µ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¾à¤•à¥‡ à¤š à¤ªà¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¨à¤ƒâ€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤·à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®” (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥« à¥¤ à¥§à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µà¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ â€œà¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¸à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤®à¤¯à¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡â€ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥«à¥¤à¥¨à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Even in this regard, a difference exists among individuated parts. Therefore, Bhagavan Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a Himself says: “The wise see with equal vision a brahmana endowed with education and humility, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and a dog-eater” (GÄªTÄ€ 5.18) And, “Brahman is equipoised and faultless” (GÄªTÄ€ 5.19). Here the word brahman refers to the jiva. As ÅšrÄ« Narada said: “By the influence of enlightened intuition, I could perceive that 2 paÃ±cÄƒtmakeÅŸu bhÃ¼teÅŸu samÄƒneÈ™v api vastutaá¸¥ od ni sonsaib arido aland ko bhavan iti vaá¸¥ praÅ›no vÄcarambho hy anarthakaá¸¥asy af baxuanes al vidya-vinaya-sampanne brahmane gavi hastini 3 4 Å›uni caiva Å›vapake ca panditaá¸¥ sama-darÅ›inaá¸¥ nirdoá¹£am hi samam brahma ove to be tub 227 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-Å›akti this cause-effect aggregate [in the form of my body or the uni- verse] is merely assumed out of self-ignorance as existing in me, [which is to say] in Parabrahman” (SB 1.5.27). bestsog al vit à¤®à¤¯à¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¥‡ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¿ à¤š à¤œà¤—à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¸à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤¯à¤•- à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤‚ à¤œà¤—à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¥€à¤¦à¤‚ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ airtetzeq ati hus blodw The meaning of this statement is as follows: This cause-effect aggregate (sad-asat-sanghata) in the form of my body is merely assumed out of self-ignorance as existing in me, the [individu- ated] Brahman (mayi brahmani). Additionally, in the form of the universe, it is assumed as existing in the Supreme Brahman (pare brahmani). Because of the ignorance related to the self, called jiva-mÄyÄ, I conceived that “I am the body alone,” and that “the universe alone, consisting of gods, such as Indra and Candra, is the supreme regulating agency (iÅ›vara).” By the influ- ence of enlightened intuition (mati), I realized that all this was merely conceptually constructed (kalpita). à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤š à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¸ à¤š à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ It is only because of the jivas’ common identity [of conscious- ness], indicated above as well as elsewhere, that we find identity statements, such as, “I am That” and “You are That.” à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤ à¥§à¥¦ à¥§à¥©à¥¨) - à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ b. à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¹à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¨à¥ª à¥¥ orary isups, diwas à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤—à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ mama buA In this way, since the oneness of identity of all jivas whatsoever has been established, the incidental plurality presumed on the basis of the difference in bodies, such as gods and human beings, is censured in verses such as the following: to 5 bel yayaham etat sad-asat sva-mayaya paÅ›ye mayi brahmani kalpitaá¹ parei 228 in 32 A Distinct Jiva in Each Body As long as there is diversity of the gunas, there will be multi-H noiplicity of the ÄtmÄ. And as long as there is multiplicity of the) ad ÄtmÄ, the state of [karmic] dependence will certainly remain. (SB 11.10.32) à¤µà¤¿à¥¦à¤ªà¥à¥¦ à¥¨à¥¤à¥§à¥ª à¥¤ à¥©à¥¨ - da à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤·à¤¡à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿à¤¨à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¨à¥« à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤¯à¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ 30 Lodome geneida ni dugh al 30 waly ads si molileng On the other hand, statements, such as the one below, are specif- ically in reference to ParamÄtmÄ: Just as air, which is one without distinction and pervasive, is designated by names, such as sadja (“born of six”) to indicate the difference it assumes when passing through the six differ- ent holes of the venu flute, so too it is with the Supreme Self [the Supreme Immanent, ParamÄtmÄ, who is one but manifests in many ways]. (VP 2.14.32)” à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ â€œà¤…à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤§à¥à¤°à¥- à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¦ à¥¤ à¥®à¥­ à¥¤ à¥©à¥¦) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Intending all this, the Åšrutis submit their own view that there is a different jiva in each body: “If the embodied beings [jivas], who are innumerable and eternal, were to be admitted as all- pervading…” (SB 10.87.30). à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¥‡à¤¨ à¤…à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤§à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾- à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¤°à¤ªà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ “à¤à¤•à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤—à¥‚à¤¢à¤ƒâ€ (à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥§à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥‡à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ 6 yavat syad guá¹‡a-vaiá¹£amyam tavan nÃ¤nÄtvam Ätmanaá¸¥ nÄnÄtvam Ätmano yavat pÃ¤ratantryam tadaiva hi 7 veÅ†urandhraprabhedena bhedaá¸¥ á¹£adjÄdisaÃ±jÃ±itaá¸¥ abhedavyÄpino vayos tathasya paramÄtmanaá¸¥ aparimitÄƒ dhruvÄs tanu-bhá¹›to yadi sarva-gatÄá¸¥ This verse will be quoted in full in Section 34 (q.v.). 8 229 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-sakti Here, because innumerability (aparimitatva) and eternality (dhruvatva) are read as prior to the hypothetical conjunction yadi (if), there is no doubt about their [being attributes of the jiva]. This is the view of the Åšrutis. But all-pervasiveness (sarva- gatatva) is read after yadi [in the verse], indicating that there is doubt in this regard. This clearly shows that the latter sup- position is the view of others [and not that of the Åšrutis]. For this reason, the statement describing ParamÄtmÄ, “One Divin- ity remains hidden in all beings,”” informs us of the plurality of the jivas. Commentary Because of the igno the the self. IF THE JÄªVA HAS real “I”-consciousness, then this must lead us to the conclusion that there is a separate jiva in each body. Otherwise, there would be no meaning to the jiva having a real “I.” As a possible objection to this conclusion, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi refers to an episode from the Eleventh Canto, Chapter 13.) [ yem While Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a was instructing Uddhava, the latter inquired about the instructions of the Hamsa avatara to the Four KumÄras. Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a replied that the Four KumÄras once questioned their father, Brahma, about the unfailing and highest consumma- tion of yoga. They asked, “The mind becomes absorbed in sense objects and the sense objects enter the mind as impressions, so how can a person desiring liberation separate them from each other” (SB 11.13.17)?10 Brahma was unable to respond to the KumÄras and meditated on Bhagavan Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, who appeared as a hamsa, a swan. In Indian poetics, a swan is depicted as possessing the ability to separate milk from water. Bhagavan appeared in the form of Hamsa to sig- nify this ability of discernment between the ÄtmÄ and matter. The KumÄras along with their father, Brahma, approached Bhagavan in 9eko devaá¸¥ sarva-bhÅ«teá¹£u gÅ«á¸haá¸¥ SU 6.11 10 duramabmang ochdi zove oninayolida guneá¹£v avisate ceto gunas cetasi ca prabhoe bold-und avirul bilmisno katham anyonya-santyÄgo mumuksor atititirá¹£oá¸¥ 230 Ha 32 A Distinct Jiva in Each Body T this form and paid respects to Him. The KumÄras then asked, “Who are you?” face Jai Bhagavan began His response with verse 11.13.22, quoted at the beginning of this section. From His reply, it may appear that there is no difference among the various jivas. This is contrary to the conclusion of the plurality of the jivas brought out in the previous section. Alimielinen badhabab ÅšrÄ« Jiva explains that such a response by Hamsa was put forth in view of the convictions of the KumÄras, who were teachers of the jÃ±Äna-mÃ¤rga, in which the jiva is accepted as entirely one with and nondifferent from Brahman. It is as if Hamsa were asking, “How can you, the topmost brahma-jÃ±Änis, possibly pose such a question to Me?” If, however, their question was posed addressing Hamsa as just another jÄ«va, it would still make no sense, because according to them, all jivas are of one identity (samÃ¤n-Ã¤kÃ¤ra) and devoid of dis- tinguishing features. If the question was raised considering Him to be Brahman, that too would make no sense, because there is noth- ing other than Brahman. If one holds such convictions, it would be futile to ask, “Who are you?”, since there would be no difference between the questioner and the questioned. bi Moreover, if the question was related to the body, then again it would make no sense, because everyone’s body is made of the same five tattvas, namely, earth, water, fire, air, and ether. There would be nothing unique about Hamsa’s body. This was known to the KumÄras and thus their question was simply a formality, just as people ask, “How are you?”, and the reply commonly given is, “I am fine, thank you.” So, the intention of Hamsa’s reply to the KumÄras was to address their own presuppositions, rooted in the monistic view. The fact is, however, that all jivas are individuals. This is clear from GÄªTÄ€ 5.18 where Krsna says that whoever sees the equality of the jivas in all bodies, whether that of a brahmana, a cow, an ele- phant, a dog, or dog-eater, is genuinely wise. The differences per- tain to the body, not to the ÄtmÄ. If there were only one ÄtmÄ in all of these bodies, then Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a would have said that a person who recog- nizes the one Brahman in all of them, is truly wise. He would have 231 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-sakti used the words brahma-darsinah or eka-darÅ›inah instead of sama- darsinah. Therefore, in the next verse (GÄªTÄ€ 5.19), Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a says that a jiva (brahman) becomes faultless (nirdosa) when established in this vision of equality (sama).ra In this verse, the word brahman is used for the jiva, which is unusual. As such, ÅšrÄ« Jiva refers to the samadhi of ÅšrÄ« NÄrada described in SB 1.5.17, where the word brahman is similarly used for the jiva. Because both Brahman and the jiva are conscious by nature, the word brahman can also be used for the jiva, even though it is primarily used to denote the Supreme Consciousness. It is used in this way because the jiva is an integrated part of Brahman. It is not unusual for a word that generally designates the whole to be used instead to denote its part. For example, when we say, “There is not enough sun in this room,” the word “sun” is used to mean “sunlight.” It is because the ÄtmÄ and Brahman share an identity in terms of consciousness that some statements are found in scripture equat- ing the individual self with the Supreme Self, such as, “I am Brah- man,”” and, “You are that Brahman.“12 The intention of such state- ments is to emphasize the jiva’s identity as pure consciousness, dis- tinct from matter, not to convey absolute oneness of the jiva and Brahman. By way of contrast, the word jiva is also sometimes used for the Supreme Consciousness, as in the following verse: Time merges into the cosmic being (jiva), the regulator of mÄyÄ, and the cosmic being (jiva) merges into Me, the unborn Self. (SB 11.24.27)13 From the point of view of bodily distinction, there is a differ- ence from one person to another. Because of differences in appear- ance, there is favoritism, hatred, and exploitation. For this reason, Å›Ã¤stra teaches us to give up envy, hatred, and jealousy by informing us that all jÄ«vas are the same by nature. Unless we realize this unity, we will remain bound by the gunas of nature, which are the cause ads ads or son ybod sift of nisi He and blow say modestod sead 11 BAU 1.4.10 CHU 6.8.7 120 13 kÄlo mÄyÄ-maye jive jiva Ätmani mayy aje to ni namera so odt assin 232 this 32 A Distinct Jiva in Each Body of the varieties apparent to the eye. The first step on the spiritual path is to become aware of the existence of spirit beyond matter. It is on this account that the variety resulting from bodily differences is censured. This is the intention behind verse SB 11.10.32. Where there is no plurality, there is no dependency or control by anyone, and thus there is no cause of fear. alunod to reboose T ad In the Visnu PurÄá¹‡a verse cited next, however, even though the language is similar, it is indicated that everything is a manifesta- tion of ParamÄtmÄ. The self being referred to here by the com- pound mahÄtmanaá¸¥, “the Supreme Self,” is ParamÄtmÄ and not the jiva. The verse is spoken by Jada Bharata to King Rahugaá¹‡a, while instructing the latter on the supreme object of human attainment. He stated this earlier, “O King, hear from me in brief about the sup- reme goal.“14 From this it is evident that Jada Bharata’s statement is about ParamÄtmÄ and not the individual ÄtmÄ. The verse declares that just as the air, which is one without distinction, is auditorily experienced as different when passing through the various holes of a flute, so also the one Supreme Being manifests in diverse ways. Consequently, this verse from the Visnu Purana should not be inter- preted to support the idea that there is only one ÄtmÄ in various bodies. her mensa atomic (partmine), which means that To further emphasize the plurality of the jivas, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va GosvÄmÄ« cites a verse from the prayers of the personified Vedas, which is the principal quotation in this anuccheda. The verse says that if the embodied beings [jivas], who are innumerable and eternal, were to be admitted as all-pervading, they could not be under the regulation of any Supreme Being. po ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmi analyzes this statement as having two parts - that which is given and that which expresses the supposition. The given is the fact that the jivas are innumerable and eternal. In the Sanskrit verse, this part appears before the hypothetical conjunc- tion “if,” thus there can be no doubt as to the jivas’ attributes men- tioned here of innumerability and eternality. This being the sub- ject, or that which is given in sentential construction, its certainty 14 “O King, hear from me in brief about the Truth,” paramarthas tu bhÅ«pÄla sanká¹£epac chrÃ¼yatam mama (VP 2.14.28). 233 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Tatastha-sakti is not in question. A simple sentence is composed of a subject and a predicate. The subject expresses what is given or known, and the predicate proceeds to tell us something unknown about the subject. It is for this reason that Åšri Jiva takes this part of the statement as the opinion of the Vedas personified. ozud The second part of the Åšrutis’ statement expresses the supposi- tion, “If the jivas were to be admitted as all-pervading.” This part is doubtful because it is introduced with the hypothetical “if.” Åšri Jiva concludes on the basis of this doubt that the supposition is not the opinion of the Åšrutis. Moreover, if the jivas were truly all- pervading, they could not be subservient to any Supreme Being, a view which is unacceptable to the Åšrutis, as is clear from their prayers.d DdeaH The statement from SvetÄÅ›vatara Upanisad (6.11) also implies that there are many jivas. If there were only one jiva, it would be meaningless to say that one Divinity resides in all beings. ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va GosvÄm next continues to examine the attributes of the jiva listed in JÄmÄtá¹› Muni’s verses. fact from matter, not no convey absal oneness of the albed Talipasha boathogens Lonely joy & st 11 on eyes may off hob aidi ni nonstoup Inqioning ori gnia smsaqu? yns lo nobalugen www pokedes ma Tootingquaedam did anda hove Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ° [hidw ted) dintie an allidason gad bagoit ta do so inoltoutes latest ni nevig at doid prus ad Buldana od tod att seda 234 Lingaidh [loch (zalnih((4) The lobes ovato-todom at me I MILL) “avitodt me Anuccheda 33 The Jiva Is Atomic in Size à¤à¤• allest diy be further subdivided vttlemissstoloi lo tictil sidingbawal sdt al ovi sut 97019red 100 vtom die brow add salt (angalun à¥©à¥© à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ â€œà¤…à¤£à¥à¤ƒâ€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤£à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤¶à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤‚ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾ à¤•à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¦à¥‡- à¤¹à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¶à¤¿à¤°à¤†à¤¦à¥Œ à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¤¤à¥à¤œ- à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¤¹à¥Œà¤·à¤§à¤¿à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤ªà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡- à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤¹à¤šà¤¾à¤²à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤µ à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ JÄ€MÄ€Tá¹š MUNI OFFERS another reason why there is a different jiva in each body - namely, because it is anu [quality no. 15]. The word anu here means atomic (paramÄÅ†u), which means that it cannot be further subdivided even with respect to spatial dimen- sions [like a point]. This indeed is the irreducible limit of a par- ticle according to authorities in this particular field [i.e., the Vaiseá¹£ika philosophers]. Although atomic, it infuses conscious- ness into the whole body because this is its innate quality man- ifesting as a unique potency. This potency is like that of a dose of mahauá¹£adhi (a type of medicinal herb), which nourishes the entire body even if it is embedded in lac and kept on a single part of the body, such as the head. Or it is like that of a magnet, which induces a piece of iron to move.qgos besilered of al se avit ni bensins and (b) soto) Latv à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¤£à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¹ â€œà¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¹à¤‚ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤ à¥§à¥¬à¥¤à¥§à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ qua al sozol letiv med en as al ad bluoda nvitadt 1 n The word “atom” here is used to signify an entity that is limited, partless, and hence indivisible. 235 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Tatastha-sakti Its atomicity is spoken of by ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a: “Among immense objects I am the mahat-tattva, and of subtle [i.e., infinitesimal] things I am the jiva” (SB 11.16.11).2 à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿- à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤®à¤¹à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¨à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¹à¤‚ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤ à¥§à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥§à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤¿- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µ- à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¥‡ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ of this hi diat Therefore, the jiva is the irreducible limit of infinitesimality (sÅ«ká¹£matÄ). Here the word sÃ¼ká¹£matva is meant not in the sense of subtleness due to incomprehensibility [but rather, in the sense of infinitesimality or minuteness]. Otherwise, the nat- ural flow of these two statements, “Among immense objects I am the mahat-tattva, and of subtle [i.e., infinitesimal] things I am the jiva,” spoken of consecutively in mutual contrast, would be lost. In regard to the manifested cosmos, the mahat-tattva’s quality of immensity (mahattva) actually refers to its perva- siveness because it is the cause of all subsequent phenomenal appearances. [So just as the suksmatva of the jiva here does not refer to subtleness due to incomprehensibility,] the mahattva of the mahat-tattva does not imply that it is easily comprehensible in comparison to other elements, such as earth. Similarly, the subtleness of the jivas in the world refers specifically to their atomicity. This is the natural meaning. dqosolid ali -nen viilsup pad vbod afodwars 3890 à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š â€œà¤à¤·à¥‹à¤½à¤£à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤§à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¶â€ (à¤®à¥à¥¦à¥©à¥¤à¥§à¥¤à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤¬à¤¾à¤²à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¶à¤¤à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤¤à¤§à¤¾ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒâ€ (à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥¦ à¥«à¥¤à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤†à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤°à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤ƒâ€ (à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥¦ à¥«à¥¤à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ ||god vitins The following Åšruti statements also support this: “This atomic self is to be realized through pure intelligence into which the vital force (prÄna) has entered in five forms [implying that the vital force is supported by the ÄtmÄ]” (MUU 3.1.9); “The size of the jiva should be known as one ten-thousandth part of the tip 2 mahatam ca mahÃ¤n ahaá¹ sÅ«ká¹£maá¹‡Äm apy aham jivaá¸¥ stored “mots” browsi eÅŸo’nur ÄtmÄ cetasÃ£ veditavyo yasmin praá¹‡aá¸¥ paÃ±cadha samvivesa vibal oned 3 23633 The Jiva Is Atomic in Size of a hair” (su 5.9);* and “The jiva is perceived as of the size of the tip of an awl [or knife]” (su 5.8)5 estudi tiros der Commentary ONE OF THE CHARACTERISTICS of the jiva is its atomic size, anutva. An anu is defined as an infinitesimal particle that is without further parts. The BhÄgavata Purana (3.11.1) also defines a paramÄÅ†u as the smallest division of matter, which cannot be further subdivided. It is not even possible to make spatial or directional references to the aÅ†u, such as speaking of its eastern or western side. Indeed, it is more like a geometrical point that has location but no dimension. Being atomic in size, one jiva cannot exist in all bodies, and so there must be a different jiva in each body. This is further evidence as to the multiplicity of the jÄ«vas. An objection may be raised to this statement. If the jiva is the sole source of consciousness in the body and yet is atomic, then how does it render the entire body conscious? Should it not affect only that part of the body in which it is present? To this, ÅšrÄ« Jiva replies that the jiva has a special innate characteristic by which it extends its consciousness throughout the whole body although situated in just one part of it. In this respect, it is like a light bulb that illumi- nates the whole room while occupying just one part of it. In Bhaga- vad Gita, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a gives the example of the sun, which although one, illuminates this entire universe (GÄªTÄ€ 13.33)? 4 plmos ÅšrÄ« Jiva offers the additional example of a type of medicinal herb, called mahauá¹£adhi. If this herb touches one part of the body, it spreads its influence over the body as a whole. It appears that in the
  • bÄlÄgra-Å›ata-bhÄgasya satadha kalpitasya ca unohtakam fecitos bhago jivaá¸¥ sa vijÃ±eyaá¸¥asada en ÄrÄgra-mÄtro hy aparo’pi dá¹›á¹£á¹­aá¸¥ 5 6 murtatve sati niravayavaá¸¥ W galusem bertela er phil) gainsem-brow so shem Tarka-kaumudi, cited in Nyaya-koÅ›a, p. 470.9qobatni zo ston.(play) niravayaá¸¥ kriyÄvÄn paramÄnuá¸¥ Sapta-padarthi “yatha prakÄÅ›ayaty ekaá¸¥ ká¹›tsnam lokam imam ravih hogomb in Bitar tevmihrap dolarity odave-plow-aphil-tek pukarintroni ká¹£etram ká¹£etri tatha ká¹›tsnaá¹ prakÄÅ›ayati bhÄrata 237 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-sakti past, people would apply this herb to their hair with the help of lac or resin. A similar herb, often mentioned in Sanskrit literature, is hari-candana, a type of sandalwood that, if applied anywhere on the skin, would cool the whole body. Brahma-sutra (2.3.25) contributes the example of a flower’s fragrance to convey the same idea. ÅšrÄ« Jiva then directs us to the principal verse of this anuccheda. While describing His vibhutis to Uddhava, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a said that among subtle (sÃ¼ká¹£maá¹‡Äm), or in other words infinitesimal, things, He is the jiva. The word sÅ«ká¹£ma can mean subtle, small, or diffi- cult to comprehend. Here the latter meaning is not applicable, because in the verse it has been contrasted with the word mahat, or immense. Among immense objects, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a is the mahat-tattva. The mahat-tattva is all-pervading, whereas the jiva is aÅ†u, or atomic in size. Since the two are being juxtaposed here, if sÅ«ká¹£ma were to mean incomprehensible, then mahat-tattva would have to mean “easy to comprehend.” But such is not the case. On the other hand, to take the meaning of suká¹£ma as difficult to understand and that of mahat as all-pervading, would be a mismatch and would disrupt the flow of meaning. Moreover, there are numerous corroborat- ing statements in the Åšruti that describe the jiva as aÅ†u. ÅšrÄ«la JÄ«va GosvÄmi has cited three such references. The first of these is from the Mundaka Upanisad, which also states that the self is atomic. It might be objected that the subject under discussion here is ParamÄtmÄ and that, therefore, the word anu does not mean atomic but difficult to comprehend. The verse would then be read as, “This ParamÄtmÄ is difficult to understand and is to be realized through pure intelligence.” This view, however, cannot be accepted, because according to Jaimini-sÅ«tra (3.3.14), in deter- mining the hermeneutical strength of scriptural statements, the contextual meaning (prakarana) is weaker in force than linga, or the inferred meaning: “When direct statement (Å›ruti), inferential mark or word-meaning (linga), sentence or syntactical connection (vÄkya), context or interdependence (prakarana), position or order one ten-than 8 9 vyatireko gandhavat tatha hi darÅ›ayati Å›ruti-linga-vÃ¤kya-prakaraá¹‡a-sthÄna-samakhyÄnÄá¹ samavÃ¤ye para-daurbalyam artha-viprakará¹£Ät 238 33 The Jiva Is Atomic in Size of words (sthÄna), and name (samakhyÄ) are present simultane- ously, each member is progressively weaker in interpretive force, because of increasing remoteness from the meaning.” In the same statement of Mundaka Upanisad, the inferential mark (linga) is prÄna (the vital force), which overrides the context. The inferential mark is that reason, or cause, by virtue of which the conclusion can be validly inferred. In the reference cited, it is only in the individual ÄtmÄ, or in other words, in the jiva, that there is pervasion of the vital force in its five forms. Thus, there is invariable concomitance between prÄÅ†a and the jÄ«va (just as there is invariable concomitance between smoke and fire). So, where prÄá¹‡a is mentioned, it is clear that the reference must be to the jiva and not to ParamÄtmÄ. In other The second quotation is from ÅšvetÄÅ›vatara Upanisad (5.9). The last part of this verse reads, “[The self] is destined for infinity” (sa canantyÄya kalpate). This could be interpreted to mean that the self is unlimited (ananta), whereby its being anu, or atomic, would only be an illusion, the reality being its all-pervasiveness. But this can- not be the case because the word anantya here refers to liberation, and thus the intended meaning of the verse is “the self is eligible for liberation.” Anta means “end” or “death.” Ananta means “with- out death,” i.e., immortal, and thus anantyÄya means “immortality” or “liberation.” Or, an alternative interpretation is that by coming into contact with Brahman in the liberated state, the jiva becomes as if all-pervading by the power of Brahman. These statements referring to the ÄtmÄ as being one ten- thousandth the size of the tip of a hair or an awl are not meant to be taken literally, since its atomic nature has been defined as having no dimension. Next, Åšri Jiva GosvÄmÄ« refers to the prayers of the Vedas personified to further demonstrate the atomicity of the jiva. à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¨ enge the orld-unt zhvilliminen an id Aittar pradh optin into isworld and purin het hacm-noy no incolo atoms boy hotnture momoz yuto od brand bhandal phytoph-tom 239 Uzednicom Anuccheda 34 The colpisnÃ© ni vil ha Yale alle abou gadas partes The Åšrutis Argue for the Atomicity of the Jiva à¥©à¥ª à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¦ à¥¤ à¥®à¥­/à¥©à¥¦ ) - the SO THE ÅšRUTIS said: à¤…à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤§à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸ kafeefa toldmeup bhoose adfe to daci (Shoghool.intity tenido. (hidenheid à¤…à¤œà¤¨à¤¿ à¤š à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ƒ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤®à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¤®à¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¨à¥¬ à¥¥ od nerada ad ton O eternal one [Bhagavan], if the embodied beings [jÄ«vas], Tuwho are innumerable and eternal, were to be admitted as all- pervading, then their subordination to another could not be maintained, [for that] is possible only in the opposite case [of their being atomic in size and not all-pervading]. You, from whom all these jivas have come, being their cause, pervade them unrestrictedly [i.e., completely]; thus You are their regulator. Those who consider You as equal to others have not understood You due to adopting a faulty view. (SB 10.87.30)1 à¤…à¤¯à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ - à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤œà¥ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° â€œà¤®à¤®à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡” (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥«à¥¤à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤½à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ à¤…à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤µà¤ƒ 1 aparimitÄƒ dhruvÄs tanu-bhá¹›to yadi sarva-gatÄs tarhi na Å›Ã¤syateti niyamo dhruva netarathÄ ajani ca yan-mayam tad avimucya niyantá¹› bhavet samam anujÃ¤natam yad amatam mata-duá¹£á¹­ataya 240 34 The Å›rutis Argue for the Atomicity of the Jiva à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤ˆà¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤˜à¤Ÿà¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ This verse is to be understood as follows: It is described [in the Åšrutis] that the jiva is an integrated part of ParamÄtmÄ and is thus an emanation from Him. Since texts like GÄªTÄ€ 15.7 (mamai- vÄrÅ›o jiva-loke) establish the jiva as a part [of ParamÄtmÄ], it is improper to consider it as all-pervading. To correct this miscon- ception, the Å›rutis speak this verse. In reality, the jivas (tanu- bhá¹›ta, lit., “embodied beings”) are countless in number (apari- mitÄ) and eternal ( dhruvÄ ). If they were all-pervading (sarva- gatÄá¸¥), then they would not be subject to anyone else’s control (na Å›ÄsyatÄ), because in that case, they would all be equal, not being pervaded by anyone. In other words, the Vedic principle that IÅ›vara is the regulator and the jiva the regulated would not apply. (13 à¤¹à¥‡ à¤§à¥à¤°à¥à¤µ ! à¤‡à¤¤à¤°à¤¥à¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸ à¤˜à¤Ÿà¤¤ à¤à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥ â€œà¤¯à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ " ( à¤¤à¥ˆà¥¦à¥©à¥¤à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤µ- à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ On the other hand, O eternal BhagavÄn (Dhruva), because the jiva is atomic and is thus undoubtedly pervaded, the non- application of the above Vedic principle is itself negated, mean- ing that it is most certainly applicable. Moreover, it is said, “He from whom all these beings are born” (TU 3.1.1), indicating that even in the jiva’s state of being an emanation, the principle of the regulated and the regulator is valid, because one is the pervaded while the other is the pervader. à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ - à¤…à¤œà¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¤œà¤¨à¤¿ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥ƒ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤š à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¤®à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤µà¤¦à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¦à¤¦à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤®à¤¤à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤ƒ - à¤®à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ 2 yato vÄ imÄni bhÅ«tÄni jÄyante stovesh gadin Hadid mind boy romoted and sto bÃ¤mand nit vinnodd howsound â€¢ 241 11 The Ontology of the Jiva - Tatastha-sakti Because such a relation between effect and cause is seen in all cases, therefore, the Åšrutis speak the second half of the verse: Whatever is the material cause (yan-maya) of that which is generated (ajani), that cause, being the agent, is the regula- tor (niyanty) of the generated entity. It pervades the gener- ated entity completely, not leaving any part of it aside (avimu- cya). Moreover, should someone claim that the entity called ParamÄtmÄ, assuming the form of the material cause, is equal to some other being (sama), then even the person who endorses such a statement (anujÄnatÄm) does not know (amata) Param- ÄtmÄ [in truth]. The reason is that their opinion is faulty (mata-duá¹£á¹­ataya), meaning that it is impure. don à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤š â€œà¤…à¤¸à¤®à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤· à¤ªà¤°à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¶à¤¿à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤¨ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸- à¤®à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡â€ (à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤…à¤¥ à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šâ€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¥¤ â€œà¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒâ€ (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤à¥«à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¥¤ The impurity in this regard is that it contradicts the Vedic canons, such as the following Vedic statements: “This, the Sup- reme Being, is utterly without equal; no one at all is seen to be like Him. All these beings take birth, die, and are incomplete. Whereas, the Supreme Being [Bhagavan] neither takes birth nor dies. All others are incomplete” (Caturveda-sikha Upani- sad); “There is none equal or superior to Him” (su 6.8); “Why is He called Brahman? Because He expands (bá¹›mhati) and causes others to evolve (brmhayati)” (Atharva-sira Upanisad 3.4). In the ViÅŸÅ†u PurÄna also [it is stated]: “They know Brahman as the Sup- reme because of His immensity (bá¹›hatva) and because of being the cause of others evolvement (brmhaá¹‡atva)” (VP 1.12.57). asamo vÄƒ eÈ™a paro na hi kaÅ›cid eva dá¹›Å›yate sarve tv ete na va jayante ca mriyate sarve hy apurnaÅ› ca bhavanti 4 na tat-samaÅ› cabhyadhikaÅ› ca dá¹›Å›yate 5 atha kasmÃ¤d ucyate brahma bá¹›mhati bá¹›mhayati ca 6 âš« bá¹›hattvÃ¤d bá¹›mhaá¹‡atvac ca yad brahma paramam viduá¸¥ldi bu otoy 242 34 The Åšrutis Argue for the Atomicity of the Jiva à¤…à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ â€œà¤à¤•à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤—à¥‚à¤¢à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥€ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤- à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾â€ (à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥§à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤£à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¤œà¥€à¤µ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥ â€œà¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤ƒâ€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¨ à¥¤ à¥¨à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤£à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤£à¥à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤°à¥à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ dif Therefore, only ParamÄtmÄ is all-pervading, as is said: “One Divinity remains hidden in all beings. He is all-pervading and the indwelling Self of all beings” (su 6.11)? Therefore, the jiva is certainly atomic. But what, then, is intended by the description of the jiva in Åšri Bhagavad Gita, wherein it is said, “It is eternal, all-pervading, and stable” (GÄªTÄ€ 2.24)? Here “all-pervading” (sarvagata) indeed refers to ÅšrÄ« BhagavÃ¤n. Situated in Him and being under His shelter, the atomic jiva is [also] referred to as all-pervading and stable. Commentary from the mantra of Sublogannat dreamclan of gabroteralidW doplnenval pudem sinoming to stuley Jamary Muni TO FURTHER FORTIFY HIS ARGUMENT about the atomic nature of the jiva, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmÄ« refers to the prayers of the Vedas per- sonified at the beginning of creation. The logic set forth by the Vedas is that if the jivas were all-pervading like ParamÄtmÄ or Brah- man, then there would be no principle of ruler and ruled, or regu- lator and regulated. This would contradict Vedic statements, such as, “He is one, the controller, and the indwelling Self of all beings” (KU 2.2.12), and, “He alone is the one who fulfills the desires of the many” (KU 2.2.13) 10 Therefore, it is improper to adduce that the jiva is all-pervading. According to the Bhagavad GitÄƒ verse cited at the beginning of this section (15.7), the jiva is an integrated part of Bhagavan. A part cannot be all-pervading; anything that is all-pervading cannot be part of anything else. 7 8 The Åšrutis offer another reason why the jiva is not to be taken as all-pervading. They declare that Bhagavan is He from whom all eko devaá¸¥ sarva-bhÃ¼teÅŸu gudhaá¸¥ sarva-vyÃ¤pi sarva-bhÅ«tÄntarÄtmÄ nityaá¸¥ sarva-gataá¸¥ sthÄnuá¸¥ 9 eko vaÅ¡i sarva-bhÅ«tÄntarÄtmÄ muslaren mineralne byen min hainutsel 10 eko bahÅ«nÄm yo vidadhÄti kÄmÄn motivoqiy ongentot mov 243 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Tatastha-sakti jÄ«vas have come and is thus their source. He is both the material cause (upÄdÄna) as well as the efficient cause (nimitta), abhinna- nimitta-upÄdÄna-karana. To generate an object, there is need of some material ingredients (upÄdÄna) and a sentient agent (nimi- tta), who manipulates the ingredients to produce the object. Usu- ally, these two causal factors refer to two distinct entities or sub- stances. For example, gold is the material cause of a golden bracelet, whereas a goldsmith is its efficient cause. Bhagavan, however, is in an entirely unique category of causality in relation to the material world. In the beginning, only He existed, and thus He alone is both the material and efficient cause. Logically, a material cause per- vades the effect. For example, gold is the material cause of a golden bracelet. The bracelet is pervaded by gold; there is no part of it that is not gold. While referring to praká¹›ti as the cause of the mahat, which is the first evolute of primordial nature, IÅ›varaká¹›á¹£á¹‡a writes: The manifest [i.e., the evolute] is caused, non-eternal, non- to pervasive, mobile, manifold, dependent, mergent [i.e., subject OT to dissolution back into its originating cause], made up of parts, and subordinate. The unmanifest is just the opposite of this. (Sankhya-kÃ¤rikÄ 10)11 This kÄrikÄ clearly states that the effect is non-pervasive (avyÄpi), meaning that it is pervaded by its cause, and subordinate (paratantra), meaning that it is governed by another. The cause, on the other hand, is just the opposite of these attributes, meaning that it is pervasive (vyapi) and independent (svatantra), or in other words, the regulator. Therefore, the jiva cannot be all-pervading. It is anu, as stated in the various Upanisadic statements cited in the previous section. ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmÄ« next draws attention to a verse of Bhagavad GitÄ (2.24), in which ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a refers to the jiva as sarva-gata, or all- pervading. If this is the case, then how can the jiva be accepted as aÅ†u, or atomic? Jiva GosvÄmÄ« responds that the compound 11 hetumad anityam avyapi sakriyam anekam Ã¤Å›ritam lingam savayavaá¹ paratantraá¹ vyaktaá¹ viparÄ«tam avyaktam bahroated 244 34 The Åšrutis Argue for the Atomicity of the Jiva sarva-gata (“gone everywhere”) does not mean that the jiva is all-pervading, but since it is situated within Bhagavan who is all- pervading and is dependent upon Him, the jiva is also referred to as all-pervading. ÅšrÄ«la ViÅ›vanatha Cakravarti comments that sarva-gata means that the jivas enter into all the various forms of life according to their karma.2 Two other possible interpretations for sarva-gata have been provided. RÄmÄnuja in his commentary to this GitÃ¤ verse and to 2.17 says that it means that the individual jÄ«vas are present everywhere since consciousness is more subtle than matter13 ViÅ›- vanatha Cakravarti, on the other hand, interprets it to mean that the jiva is all-pervading in the body by virtue of consciousness.”” It is, therefore, concluded that the jiva is aÅ†u, whereas ParamÄtmÄ is all-pervading, as is explicit from the mantra of ÅšvetÄÅ›vatara Upanisad (6.11) cited in this anuccheda. F TE WE In the section that follows, ÅšrÄ« Jiva explains the next four charac- teristics of the jiva listed by JÄmÄtá¹› Muni, namely, it is nitya (eter- nal), nirmala (unblemished), jÃ±Ätá¹›tva (endowed with the capacity to know), and kartá¹›tva (endowed with agency, or the capacity to act). bim and 10 sing to sobom olgninniged à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤•à¥‹ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¨à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¥€ à¤®à¤¦à¤ªà¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¨à¥¨à¥­ à¥¥ Jedi awode tadual titsmette some avait davostom 12 sarva-gataá¸¥ sva-karma-vaÅ›Äd deva-manusya-tiryag-adi-sarva-deha-gataá¸¥…. svarga-naraka-nana-yoniá¹£u gamanaá¹ ca tasyopadhi-pÃ¤ravasyad eva. of ISÄrÄrtha-vará¹£iÅ†i 2.24, 2.17 13 sarva-gatatvad Ã¤tmanaá¸¥ sarva-tattva-vyÄpaka-svabhÄvatayÄ sarvebhyas diris tattvebhyaá¸¥ sÃ¼ká¹£matvad asya tair vyÄpty-anarhatvad vyapya-kartavyatvÄc ca chedana-dahana-kledana-soá¹£aá¹‡ÄnÄm…. ogrebn 14 yena Ã¤tma-tattvena cetanena tad-vyatiriktam idam acetana-tattvaá¹ sarvaá¹ tataá¹ vyÃ¤ptam. tat jivÄtma-svarupaá¹ yena sarvam idam sariram tatam vyÄptam. … sampurna- deha-vyapi-Å›aktimattvam jatu-jatitasya maha-maner mahauá¹£adhi-khandasya vÄ Å›irasy urasi vÄƒ dhá¹›tasya sampÅ«rá¹‡a-deha-puá¹£á¹­i-karaá¹‡a-Å›aktimattvam iva (13913 nÄsamaÃ±jasam. SÄrÄrtha-vará¹£iÅ†i 2.17 dobivenale orthu 245 well scooping long d bedded to sob Condor se atop-sector hemipuinny lis die si odpanavegada Anuccheda 35 The Jiva Is Eternal, Unblemished, and Endowed with Knowership no poil 102 and Agency To non si mort titles al as goibsving-lia al à¥©à¥« à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤²à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ â€œà¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ THE JIVA is eternal [nitya, quality no. 16] and unblemished [nirmala, quality no. 17] because it is intrinsically pure by nature, as demonstrated already in SB 5.11.12 (Anuccheda 2): “The pure knower of the presentational field merely witnesses these beginningless modifications of the impure actor, the mind.“1 à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ 1 Moreover, by the very same statement it is further shown that the capacity to know [jÃ±Ätá¹›tva, quality no. 18] also belongs even to the pure ÄtmÄ [by virtue of its being a knower of the pre- sentational field]. And this cognitive capacity, being a natural attribute of the eternal self, is also eternal and thus does not undergo modifications. à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤šà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š â€œà¤¨ à¤‹à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤•à¤¿à¤à¥à¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥‡â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤šà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤™à¥à¤—à¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒ- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤§à¤¿à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤®à¥€ à¤¯à¤¦à¤‚à¤¶à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ " (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥§à¥¬à¥¤à¥¨à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Å›uddho vicaÅŸte hy aviÅ›uddha-kartuá¸¥ 24635 The Jiva Is Eternal, Unblemished, and Endowed with Knowership and Agency Because the body is seen to have agency [kartá¹›tva, quality no. 19] as a result of its relation to the [individual] conscious being, and because inert objects are also acknowledged as some- times exhibiting agency due to the presence of the indwelling [Supreme] consciousness, in accordance with the statement, “without whom nothing is accomplished,” [it is concluded that] agency ensues only from the pure [i.e., only from the individual or from the Supreme Consciousness]. Thus, it is said: “Being infused with whose [conscious] portion, the body, senses, vital force, mind, and intellect perform their respective functions” (SB 6.16.24)2 à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ â€œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥¨à¥¬à¥¤à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¾- à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤ à¥¨à¥«à¥¤à¥¨à¥¬) - When this agency comes about primarily due to the adjuncts (upÃ¤dhis), it is said to be an attribute of the adjuncts, as is stated, “The cause of agency in the body and senses is known to be praká¹›ti” (SB 3.26.8). When, however, agency comes about pre- dominantly due to ParamÄtmÄ, it is free from those adjuncts (nirupadhi) [meaning that it is transcendental]. As Bhagavan Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a said: à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤•à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¥€ à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‹ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤®à¤¦à¤ªà¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¨à¥­ à¥¥ QhAn y An unattached agent is sÃ¤ttvika, one blinded by attachment is rajasika, and one whose discrimination has been altogether lost 03 ai is tÄmasika; but the agent who works under My shelter is free ad all from the material guÅ†as. (SB 11.25.26) (0.81) 45 hpvognda vbod anti bna yonsys to biovab erow saujA lo lles adtestovah à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥ || à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¥ at sorpt nodi gillsup done bees9220g anals The meaning is clear. lam di gattasporto al maelyninsem prove to bevingeb now Hos od 11 Joy sadovab alH 2 dehendriya-prana-mano-dhiyo’mi yad-amsa-viddhÃ¤á¸¥ pracaranti karmasu karya-karaá¹‡a-kartá¹›tve kÃ¤ranaá¹ praká¹›tim viduá¸¥au ingat 3 4
  • sÃ¤ttvikaá¸¥ kÄrako’sangÄ« rÄgÄndho rÄjasaá¸¥ smá¹›taá¸¥a tÄmasaá¸¥ smá¹›ti-vibhrasto nirguno mad-apÄÅ›rayaá¸¥ Nabohada took brual 247 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Tatastha-sakti Commentary] yoga oved of nose at ybod ad eansose anobanos [[subtvibat ads of noticed at to lands as [er.on THE PURE JIVA is intrinsically endowed with cognitive capacity (jÃ±Ätá¹›tva) and agency (kartá¹›tva). He is the witness of the actions of the mind and body and thus has the capacity to know. It is not that knowership is acquired only when the jiva is bound by the material body. Cognitive awareness is a natural characteristic of the jiva. Since the jiva is eternal, its cognitive awareness is also eternal by the principle, nityam gatam nityam, “The attributes of an eternal object are also eternal.” ada org alliant bas brim sorol Like knowership, agency is also an eternal attribute of the jiva. The material body does not have independent agency. The body is inert and acquires its awareness and capacity to act from the con- scious self. When it is said that the body is the agent of actions, it is meant only in a secondary sense. ab In Bhagavad Gita, Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a affirms that a person deluded by the separate self-sense (ahankara) thinks himself to be the doer, although all actions are effected by the gunas of praká¹›ti (3.27). But even in this statement, it should also be noted that if the jiva did not have agency as part of its intrinsic nature, he would not be able to think of himself as the doer. Thinking is also an action, and so by saying, “he thinks himself to be the doer,” Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a implies that the pure self has agency. The agency of the pure self is also stated in Brahma-sutra (2.3.31): “The self must be an agent, because then only the scripture can be purposeful.” If the self had no agency, and if agency belonged only to praká¹›ti, then the injunctions of scripture would become futile, because they would not be applicable to anyone. For example, in Bhagavad GitÃ¤ (18.65), ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a commands Arjuna to become His devotee. If the self of Arjuna were devoid of agency, and if the body alone possessed such quality, then Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s instruction would be meaningless. Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a is not requesting the material body to become His devotee, yet, if the self were deprived of agency, it could not 5 praká¹›teá¸¥ kriyamaá¹‡Äni gunaiá¸¥ karmÄÅ†i sarvaÅ›aá¸¥ ahankara-vimÅ«á¸hÄtmÄ kartÄham iti manyate th âš« kartÄ Å›ÄtrÄrthavattvÃ¤t 248 35 The Jiva Is Eternal, Unblemished, and Endowed with Knowership and Agency become a devotee. Since Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s statement is made in full knowl- edge, it cannot be futile. Consequently, it must be accepted that the self has agency. Agency also implies will. An agent can choose to follow an injunction or not. If an agent lacked the capacity of choice, and were thus deprived even of the possibility of rejecting an injunction, there would be no need for such injunctions in the first place. The very word injunction would be rendered obsolete. ÅšrÄ« Jiva goes on to explain that when an action is undertaken for the pleasure of the body and senses, then the action is considered to be material, i.e., under the gunas of praká¹›ti. If, however, the action is performed for the pleasure of the Supreme Person, it is nirguna, or beyond the material qualities. From this, it must be concluded that action is possible for the jiva even in the liberated state. In the principal verse of this section (SB 11.25.26), although it is said that an agent may be sÃ¤ttvika, rÄjasika, or tÄmasika, it should be understood that it is only the activity that is characterized by those qualities and not the pure agent, or jiva. The physical body is said to be the immediate agent. The body is not just sÃ¤ttvika, rÄjasika, or tÄmasika alone, but a combination of all three gunas. There is a rule that an injunction or prohibition is first applied to a qualified object, and if that is not possible, then it is to be applied to its quality or modifier? Because the agent (i.e., the pure self) who is qualified by the activity cannot be colored by the gunas, it is only the activity that is described as sÃ¤ttvika, and so on. yaad of 98 asall owd sas on.ya Next, ÅšrÄ« Jiva explains that experiential capacity or affectivity (bhoktá¹›tva) is inherent in the ÄtmÄ. -Ğ´Ğ¾Ñ€ ad of asd Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ² Ğ´Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ¼ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ· ÑĞ·Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞºĞ° Ğ¾Ñ‚ Jonas ani gated,baim bas ybod Ishvatam adi stolene aube eded at bisz esmitomos el vhod sa spastroqks to tajdua adr ed lo gled edt diw vhod surf 00 olis sarmed tege und ganiton al vowed yiosque Isiastisquesansa bas baim 7 merino Ardory tirpay the thirst-be sa-viseá¹£ane vidhi-niá¹£edhau viseá¹£aá¹‡am upa-sankramataá¸¥ sati visesye badhe T KÄlÄpa-paribhÄá¹£Ä-sÅ«tra 2 249 yanaga bas qidswork at Tweak thisbent et tuomelade aegypt sai setovah & amood tart hotqsoas ad sam se lined sona tieghe 11 linen moodoo magoliw nailymionlainngth younge and sor Igaytion Anuccheda 36 and Experiential Capacity Is Rooted in the Jiva missiyadi Istretem ad à¥©à¥¬ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥ à¤­à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¨à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹ “à¤­à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤¦à¥à¤ƒà¤–à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥© à¥¤ à¥¨à¥¬à¥¤à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ NEXT TO BE CONSIDERED is experiential capacity [bhoktá¹›tva, quality no. 20], which is in the form of feeling, or affect (samve- dana), and which culminates in the jiva alone, who is conscious by nature. As Bhagavan Kapila says in the same section of the Third Canto [referred to above]: “[Know] the purusa, who is transcendental to praká¹›ti [to be the cause] in experiencing happiness and misery” (SB 3.26.8). â€œà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒâ€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤£à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤•à¤ªà¤¿à¤²à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤à¥¤ add yd bezolon ad torso vivioned yd These two lines are to be syntactically connected with the words “know to be the cause” found in the previous line of the verse? Commentary because they would futile, in TO EXPERIENCE ENJOYMENT OR SUFFERING, one has to be con- scious. Therefore, the material body and mind, being inert, cannot be the subject of experience. The body is sometimes said to be the agent, because actions occur through the body with the help of the mind and senses. Experiential capacity, however, is nothing but 1 bhoktá¹›tve sukha-duá¸¥khÃ¤nÃ¤á¹ puruÅŸam praká¹›teá¸¥ param 2 The first line of the verse is: karya-kÃ¤raá¹‡a-kartá¹›tve kÃ¤raá¹‡am praká¹›tim viduá¸¥, cited in the previous anuccheda. 250 36 Experiential Capacity Is Rooted in the Jiva the awareness of the feelings of happiness and misery, for which there must be a conscious being. Therefore, experiential capacity cannot belong to the inert body or mind.art even of the material Here it may be noted that just as all actions occur in the physical body, the senses, and the mind, so too the feelings of happiness and misery are also experienced in the mind. This is the common expe- rience of all human beings in life. As was explained earlier, every experience is a form of citta-vá¹›tti, a state or modification of the mind. Why then does Bhagavan Kapila make a distinction between agency and experience, relegating the first to praká¹›ti and the sec- ond to the puruÅŸa (the conscious self)? The ultimate cause for both is the purusa, but while action, and hence agency, is visible even in the material body, feelings are deeper and more subtle, being experienced only within the mind. Moreover, it is obvious that a machine that is capable of performing some work cannot have feel- ings. The body is comparable to a machine that carries the puruÅŸa (GÄªTÄ€ 15.7). ing that is the inherent car birogmon 901 also radio ai or vites on of “Janam (“subissa ashater) na brow at bas dignitagalan sanshaque ban vones (tise albedo od) ning say of boo rifod 101 savas stamblood à¥©à¥­ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤•à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥‹à¤½à¤‚à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥Œ à¤¸ à¤š à¤à¤•à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤à¤•à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤•à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤•à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¾ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¦à¤¶à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®- à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¥¤ NEXT TO BE EXPLAINED is the meaning of paramÃ¤tmaika-seá¹£atva- svabhÄva, i.e., “the jiva is by nature the unitary, irreducible remainder of ParamÄtmÄ” [quality no. 21]. In the compound paramÄtmaika-seá¹£atva-svabhava, the word eka (“a unit”) refers to an entity who is other than, or distinct from, ParamÄtmÄ, and the word Å›eÅŸa (“remainder,” “residue”) means “a part.” That entity who is both a distinct unit (eka) and an irreducible part (Å›eÅŸa) is eka-sesa, a part of ParamÄtmÄ that is yet different from Him. A unitary, or integrated, part of ParamÄtmÄ is known as paramÄtmaika-Å›eÈ™a, and its existential condition (bhava) is called paramÃ¤tmaika-seá¹£atva. So, that which has this condi- tion as its intrinsic nature (svabhava) is called paramÄtmaika- Å›eÅŸatva-svabhÄva [referring to the jiva]. Moreover, this is its per- manent state of being (sarvada), implying that such is the case even in the liberated state. The jiva has this intrinsic nature by its very own inner constitution (svarÃ¼pata eva), meaning that it is not the outcome of some covering or limitation (pariccheda) [on Brahman by mÄyÄ]. dental cap à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤šà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥Œà¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿- à¤•à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ 252 37 The Jiva Is an Integrated Part of ParamÄtmÄ By virtue of ParamÄtmÄ’s natural inconceivable potency, the jiva is by nature like a particle of His rays, but in its conditioned state, it becomes to a certain degree a part even of the material energy, praká¹›ti (praká¹›ti-seá¹£atvam api). This is the [double] sense of the word svataá¸¥, “by its own inner constitution” [in the verses of JÄmÄtá¹› Muni in Anuccheda 19]. à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾- à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€œà¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤à¥­à¥¤à¥§à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¾- à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥Œ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¥ à¤šà¤¾à¤µà¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ DA Web Hpling VM af aldr ogs bus tellstai.bnim The jiva is understood to be of the nature of energy, because (1) it is the intermediary potency (taá¹­astha-sakti) [of Param- ÄtmÄ]; (2) though it is like a ray of ParamÄtmÄ, it is still ever under His shelter, meaning that it cannot exist without Him; (3) it is the means [sadhanatva]’ by which the universal creation takes place, as is said: “The jiva is the cause of this creation” (SB 12.7.18); and (4) although it is a substance [dravya, signify- ing that it is the inherent cause of effects, or the substratum of qualities], it is similar to pradhana [which is energy]. 1 à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥­ à¥¤ à¥¬à¥§, à¥¬à¥© ) - The jiva is also said to be an energy (Å›akti) due to being a spe- cific fundamental power (praká¹›ti) [of ParamÄtmÄ], as it is said in ViÅŸÅ†u PurÄna: Inametste svods art ted slant to surry va ady to roko vsillosga (royo) dog to à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¨à¥® à¥¥ Studylosin à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤ mo villsaurs to 1909 an à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤­à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤² à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¨à¥¯ à¥¥d past aodies batutor VisÅ†u’s energies are designated as “the potency of inherent transcendence” (para), “the potency that is other than, or apart from, inherent transcendence” (apara), which is also called The word sadhanatva here implies that the jiva is the instrumental cause (nimitta), as explained in Tattva Sandarbha (Anuccheda 63). 2 hetur jivo’sya sargÄdeá¸¥ 253 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-sakti sithe knower of the field (ká¹£etrajÃ±a), and a third potency called va be avidya-karma (ignorance as causal entanglement). (VP 6.7.61)3 vi of its Being covered by ignorance (avidya), O King, the potency called perthe knower of the field” (kÅŸetrajÃ±a) exists in graded stages of 292 evolution throughout all species of life. à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤²à¥à¤²à¥‡à¤ªà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤®à¥Œ à¤›à¤¾à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ - of dist In this way, although the jiva is an energy, it is distinct from the other two [intrinsic and extrinsic] due to being intermediately situated (taá¹­astha). It is intermediate because it cannot be sub- sumed under either of the other two categories. The reason for this is that it is superior to the mÄyÄ energy; [but at the same time,] it is subject to the defect of being overpowered by igno- rance, which does not influence ParamÄtmÄ. Although the jiva is the energy of ParamÄtmÄ, the latter is not tainted by [mÄyÄ, or ignorance, like the jiva], just as the sun rays in a particular area may be covered by an object that shades them from view, mamaivÃ¤á¹so jiva-loke GÄªTÄ€ 15.7 The idea here is similar to that conveyed by the phrase “the village in the Ganges,” which does not literally mean that the village is in the water but on the shore. So the word ká¹£etra (i.e., the body) in ká¹£etrajÃ±a should be taken merely as an indicator of the pure self present within the body, and not that the jiva is inherently or constitutionally limited by the body.mod omsland and 255 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Tatastha-sakti but the sun [itself] remains uncovered. The intermediary status (taá¹­astha) of the jiva is stated in Sri Narada PaÃ±caratra: à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤°à¤à¥à¤œà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸ à¤œà¥€à¤µ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥§à¥©à¥§ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ That entity which is intermediately situated, conscious by nature, whose self-awareness has been lost, and who is taintedit by attachment to the material gunas, is called the jiva. (NÄrada PaÃ±carÄtra)9 TIME THE à¤…à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤² à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¤ à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥Œ â€œà¤…à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¥€ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¤à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤ƒâ€ (à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥¦à¥ª à¥¤ à¥¯ ) â€œà¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€ (à¤®à¥à¥¦ à¥© | à¥§|à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ 92 brow adt drem gaidaingabeib letash As such, in Visnu Purana also, the jiva has been mentioned as situated in the middle [between the material and spiritual ener- gies of Bhagavan]. The jiva’s being other [than, or distinct from, ParamÄtmÄ] is also stated in the Åšrutis, “So the Lord of mÄyÄ cre- ates this universe and the other [the jiva] becomes bound in it by mÄyÄ” (su 4.9),10 and, “The other of these two [the jiva] eats the divergent fruits of fruits of karmaâ€ (MUU 3.1.1).” à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¥‡ (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦ à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥­ à¥¤à¥¯à¥ª) - Sub] Thedro Thus, it is said in Visnu Purana: edo sdi to radio zobou bemua 9 DVIT statement of asthe Pirand ry of Torisque ar ji tedd ar ami à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤œà¤¨à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤—à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥§à¥©à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ noter potency Even if the ignorance that produces the perception of dif- ference were completely destroyed, who could render non- 20 existent (asanta) the difference between the [individual] selfis and Brahman? (VP 6.7.94)12 yat taá¹­astham tu cid-rupaá¹ sva-samvedyad vinirgatam salol-nvit mbviamom raÃ±jitaá¹ guá¹‡a-rÄgena sa jiva iti kathyateco led of alinda al bied esi suff 10 asman mÄyi sá¹›jate viÅ›vam etat tasmimÅ› canyo mayaya sanniruddhaá¸¥ 11 tayor anyaá¸¥ pippalam svadv atti a bad ed 12 vibheda-janake’jÃ±Äne nÄÅ›am atyantikam gate ang brow orb 02.0 and to oth to torsda atmano brahmano bhedam asantam kah karisyati llanoushan 25637 The Jiva Is an Integrated Part of ParamÄtmÄ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¨à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¤¨à¤•à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤‚ à¤—à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ ? à¤…à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µ à¤à¤µ à¤•à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ Ingle Ignorance is the cause of the perception of difference (bheda), which here refers to cognitive awareness of distinctions (visesa) based on the unique characteristics by which individuals are defined, such as those that determine the nature of a god, a human being, or a lower creature. Even if this ignorance were destroyed, who would be able to render non-existent (asanta) the innate (svabhÃ¤vika) difference between the jiva (ÄtmÄ) and ParamÄtmÄ [here indicated by the word brahman]? In other words, everyone would affirm that their difference does indeed exist. à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤•à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿ à¤à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¦à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¤‚à¤¶- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿- à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¤à¤²à¥à¤²à¥€à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ â€œà¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¿â€ (à¤®à¥à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥§à¥¤à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥ª à¥¤ à¥¨- biopos ni al 9msz Because the principle to be predicated in the subsequent part [of the sentence] is the negation of the “non-existence” (na-asanta) of distinction [between the jiva and ParamÄtmÄ], any contrary interpretation would certainly be a stretch of the imagination.13 Thus, because the jiva is the inherent (svabhÃ¤vika) energy of ParamÄtmÄ, it is never divorced from its constitutional nature of being an integrated part of Him, even in the liberated state. Therefore, in final liberation, which is characterized by estab- lishment in the self’s intrinsic identity (svarupa) after being freed from ignorance, the merging of the self in the Absolute actually refers to entrance into the state of identity with the nature and qualities of Bhagavan, as is seen from the Åšruti statements such as, “The illuminated seer, free from the condi- tioned state, attains the supreme sameness (paramam samyam)” (MUU 3.1.3), and from the words of the GitÄ: 13 An instance of such a contrary interpretation is found in the auto-commentary of verse 1.40 of Siddhanta-leÅ›a-sangraha of Appaya Diká¹£ita. Åšri Jiva GosvÄmi refutes his explanation. is also 14 niraÃ±janaá¸¥ paramam samyam upaiti dabiltyd bodaidug 257 II The Ontology of the Jiva Tatastha-sakti à¤‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤® à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤—à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ (à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¥ à¥§à¥©à¥© à¥¥ STE GS FROTRO à¤•à¥ƒà¤¿ Those who, by resorting to this knowledge, have attained same- ness with My nature and qualities are not born again at the time of creation nor are they distressed at the time of dissolution. doldw (GÄªTÄ€ 14.2)15 sdp supinu ada ao baasd à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ â€œà¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿â€ (à¤®à¥à¥¦à¥©à¥¤à¥¨à¥¤à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤šà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ â€œà¤‰à¤ªà¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒâ€ (à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥¦ à¤¸à¥‚à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ wind 93 (olivbridore) stanni I Therefore, statements such as, “The knower of Brahman becomes Brahman indeed,“16 indicate that such a knower specifically attains sameness of nature (tÄd-atmya) with Brahman. This is to say that the transrational intuition of the Supreme self- manifests of its own accord [in correspondence with the specific intent of the worshiper].” So, attainment of the inherent nature of the Supreme is in accordance with the principle outlined in Brahma-sutra: “The aspired-for result of a person’s contempla- tion manifests in exact accordance with his or her conviction because such a position is logically justifiable” (vs 3.1.23).18 blnow not HÃ£o dots à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¥‡ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿- à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¥ˆà¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¨à¤¾à¤¸à¤®à¤à¥à¤œà¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ nd as gated to It has, therefore, been established that the jiva is the potency of ParamÄtmÄ. Sometimes the two are described as being with- out distinction, because (1) there is mutual interpenetration of energy and energetic; (2) energy cannot exist without its ener- getic source; and (3) energy and energetic are nondistinct from 15 idaá¹ jÃ±Änam upÄƒÅ›ritya mama sadharmyam agatÃ¤htis, stala benott svarge’pi nopajayate pralaye na vyathanti ca 16 brahma veda brahmaiva bhavati MUU 3.2.9 mont bus*(E.LE DUM) 17 The sentence svenacintaniya-jÃ±Änam bhavati (“The transrational intuition of the Supreme self-manifests of its own accord”) inserted here is found in the edition published by ÅšrÄ« Haridasa ÅšÄstrÄ«, but not in all editions. nalgas ad magte morta donna 18 tat-sabhÃ¤vyÃ¤pattir upapatteá¸¥ 258 37 The Jiva Is an Integrated Part of ParamÄtmÄ the point of view that both are of the nature of consciousness. [Nevertheless,] it is also not improper to describe them as dif- ferent, because varieties of energy can be seen even in a single object. à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤œà¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤…à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿- à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦ à¥§ à¥§à¥¯ à¥§à¥¬à¥¯). On the other hand, the followers of Sri RamanujÄcÄrya consider statements portraying the nondifference of the jiva and Param- ÄtmÄ - who are distinct, nonetheless, as the seat (adhiá¹£á¹­hÄna) and its occupier (adhiá¹£á¹­hÄtá¹›) - to be comparable to the use of a word like “cow” for both an individual as well as its universal class. (SB 4.28.63)21 STESS à¤¤à¤¦à¤ªà¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤šà¥à¤›à¥‚à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤ªà¥‹à¤·à¤£à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¬à¤¿à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¦à¥à¤µ- à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ “à¤…à¤®à¥à¤¬à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€ ( à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥¦ à¤¸à¥‚à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥¨à¥¤à¥§à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Such statements are also spoken only to nourish the view of non- difference in those who desire jÃ±Äna, [and do not mean] that the jiva is factually a reflection. This is because accepting the jiva as a reflection [of Brahman] is contrary even to the opin- ion of the preceptor of the radical nondualists [Sankara], on the basis of the sutra, “But there is no ‘suchness’ (tathatva) [of Brah- man, i.e., no state of Brahman being like the reflected sun or the demarcated earth], because of the non-apprehension (agraha- nÄt) [of Brahman’s remoteness from the reflecting medium or delimitability by any circumscription], as in the case of water [which is remote from the sun or which demarcates the earth]” (VS 3.2.19).22 accepted only in a restricted sense according to the principle stated in the sub- sequent sutra, “There is, however, participation in [appar- ent] increase or decrease on account of [Brahman’s] imma-
