ust IN THIS WAY, there are verily unlimited intermediary poten- cies (taá¹­astha-saktis), called jivas. They form two groups. One consists of those whose consciousness is turned toward Bhaga- vÃ¤n (bhagavad-unmukha) without beginning; the other consists of those whose consciousness is turned away from Bhagavan (bhagavat-parÄn-mukha) with no beginning. This division is according to whether or not they are intrinsically endowed with experiential awareness, or direct knowing, of Bhagavan. à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥€à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹ à¤—à¤°à¥à¤¡à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤®à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡ â€œà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤­à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ Jivas of the first group are favored by the blessings of Bhaga- vÄn’s intrinsic potency and are His eternal associates, such as Garuda, as stated in the Uttara-khanda of Padma Purana, previ- ously also cited in Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anuccheda 78.1): “There are unlimited worlds and beings in the tripad-vibhuti, or the transcendental abode characterized by threefold dimensional- ity of being [i.e., immortality, fearlessness, and all-auspicious worship of the Absolute]. All inhabitants of this realm are of the nature of unalloyed being (Å›uddha-sattva) and are known as brahmananda-sukha, the joy and bliss of Brahman. They are 302 47 Two Types of Jivas I all eternal, immutable, and devoid of the lower gunas; they are golden, pure, and brilliant as a million suns. They are all full of Vedic knowledge, divine, and free from the attributes of lust and greed. They relish only the nectar of unalloyed devotional ser- vice to Bhagavan NÄrÄyaá¹‡a’s lotus feet. They are always filled with the bliss of the sweet chanting of the Sama Veda and are effulgent with the Vedic knowledge. They are the personifi- cations of the fivefold worship of Bhagavan” (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 228.1-4)? rily the attal à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤•à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ The jivas of the first category [those eternally devoted to Bha- gavÄn] are also classified as part of the intermediary potency (taá¹­astha), because the widely acknowledged condition that “jiva-hood” (jivatva) entails necessarily excludes them from being included in the same category as ÃÅ›vara Himself. gnist atre (on à¤…à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¦à¥‹à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤²à¤¬à¥à¤§à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥€ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¹à¤‚à¤¸à¤—à¥à¤¹à¥à¤¯- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥‡ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥€à¤¡à¥‡â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥ªà¥¤à¥¨à¥«) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ By contrast, the jivas of the second category are those bound to empirical existence, being overpowered by mÄyÄ, which takes advantage of their flaw of indifference to Bhagavan. This con- dition is depicted in the Hamsa-guhya-stava: “The jiva knows all these [the body, the vital force, and so on] as well as the gunas, but though it is the knower of all these, it does not know the omniscient, unlimited [Bhagavan], whom I worship” (SB 6.4.25)? à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¥‡ à¤š â€œà¤­à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥§à¥¨ à¥§à¥©à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ 1 tripÃ¤d-vibhÃ¼ter lokÄs tu asankhyÄá¸¥ parikirtitÃ¤á¸¥ Sabogor Å›uddha-sattva-mayaá¸¥ sarve brahmananda-sukhÄhvayÄá¸¥ 3sarve nityÃ¤ nirvikÃ¤ra heya-rÄga-vivarjitÄá¸¥ 2 sarve hiranmayaá¸¥ Å›uddhaá¸¥ koti-sÃ¼rya-sama-prabhÄá¸¥ sarve vedamaya divyaá¸¥ kama-krodhÄdi-varjitÄá¸¥ nÄrÄyaá¹‡a-padambhoja-bhakty-eka-rasa-sevinah nirantaram sama-gÄna-paripÃ¼rá¹‡a-sukham Å›ritÄá¸¥ sarve paÃ±copaniá¹£at-sva-rupaya veda-varcasaá¸¥ Tigai voda be toup bel gorld an sarvam puman veda guÅ†ÄmÅ› ca taj-jÃ±o na veda sarvajÃ±am anantam ide up onla 303 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-sakti And also in the Eleventh Canto: “A living being who is set apart from Bhagavan becomes absorbed in separativeness (dvitiya). As a consequence, he is overpowered by fear, his conception of being is reversed, and he becomes forgetful of his constitutional position. All this takes place by Bhagavan’s extrinsic potency. Therefore, one who is actually wise worships Him by the pro- cess of unalloyed devotion, considering his spiritual teacher as an embodiment of the Divine and as his very self” (SB 11.2.37). à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¥‡ (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦ à¥¬/à¥­ /à¥¬à¥©) - SITY BRE And as said in VisÅ†u PurÄna: ada ot batovab vllenasta 020d à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤

  1. à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤­à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤² à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥§à¥«à¥© à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ sarsood.(orihina) vlinseason slicine (avtovi) “boor-nu Being covered by ignorance (avidya), O King, the potency called “the knower of the field” (ká¹£etrajÃ±a) exists in graded stages of evolution throughout all species of life. (VP 6.7.63)* PENET à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥­à¥¤à¥©à¥­) - consists ÅšrÄ« Vidura has also made reference to these two very same categories of jÄ«vas in the following verse: à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤¤à¤¿à¤§à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ly off à¤• à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¥€à¤°à¤¨ à¤• à¤‰ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤°à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥§à¥«à¥ª à¥¥ aiqubit nohtib bod srii] sasra Ile gurudangalg inrao and wom! Please describe, O great sage, in how many ways do the ele- ments of material nature dissolve into their source? Who wor- varships Him even during dissolution? And who follows Him into Garrepose? (SB 3.7.37)5 3 4 bhayam dvitiyabhiniveÅ›ataá¸¥ syad iÅ›Ã¤d apetasya viparyayo’smá¹›tiá¸¥ tan-mayayÄto budha abhajet tam bhaktyaikayeÅ›am guru-devatÄtmÄ taya tirohitatvÄc ca saktiá¸¥ ká¹£etra-jÃ±a-saÃ±jÃ±itÄ sarva-bhÅ«teá¹£u bhÅ«pÄla taratamyena vartate Also quoted above in Anuccheda 37. tattvÄnÄá¹ bhagavams teá¹£Äm katidha pratisankramaá¸¥ tatremam ka upasiran ka u svid anuserate Also quoted in Bhagavat Sandarbha, Anuccheda 96.3. ahisional- of 304 47 Two Types of Jivas nali à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤•à¤–à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤® à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤š à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤® à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µ- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ 9370l Istiv sidrald diod ylamen (wen Although the jivas whose attention is directed away from ParameÅ›vara are pure [in their inherent nature], they are sub- jected to taking birth along with their upadhis [i.e., the body- mind complex] from ParameÅ›vara [i.e., ParamÄtmÄ] who is intrinsically endowed with the jiva potency. And that birth is verily the attainment of the state of empirical selfhood (ÄdhyÄ- tmikatva) [in relation to the body], caused by the phenome- nal identification (abhimana) that mistakes the birth of one’s limiting conditions (upÄdhis) for the birth of the self. à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤ƒ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¦à¥¤à¥®à¥­à¥¤à¥©à¥§) - [To this end,] the Åšrutis say the following: -à¤¨ à¤˜à¤Ÿà¤¤ à¤‰à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤œà¤¯à¥‹à¤° boigna ada ang gitaalibom aut to goi à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¤¯à¥à¤œà¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹ à¤œà¤²à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ of banio non sna adi 2015 à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤‡à¤®à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤—à¥à¤£à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡ sd anobleogah led anobs à¤¸à¤°à¤¿à¤¤ à¤‡à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¤µà¥‡ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¨à¤¿ à¤²à¤¿à¤²à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤ƒ || à¥§à¥«à¥« à¥¥ .bata.bsmolaibno No generation of praká¹›ti or of puruÅŸa ever takes place, because they are both birthless. Rather, the coming into existence of the embodied living beings is like the appearance of bubbles don the surface of water, occurring only when the two [praká¹›ti via and puruÅŸa] are conjoined together. During dissolution, they enter into You, the Supreme, with all their various names and attributes, just as rivers enter into the sea or just as the nectar of unlimited numbers of flowers is dissolved in honey. (SB 10.87.31)6 à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤—à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤œà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¥‹ à¤¨ à¤˜à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤ à¤†à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¯à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¯à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¯à¥à¤œà¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ 6 na ghatata udbhavaá¸¥ praká¹›ti-puruá¹£ayor ajayor ubhaya-yuja bhavanty asu-bhá¹›to jala-budbudavat tvayi ta ime tato vividha-nama-gunaiá¸¥ parame sarita ivÄrnave madhuni lilyur aÅ›esa-rasÄá¸¥ Î¿Ï€Î¿Î¯Î¿Ï‚ Î²Î¹Î² and tush shizh as niwapend babounes.az 305 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-Å›akti Praká¹›ti consists of the three gunas [in their equilibrated state]. The puruÅŸa [here means] the jiva in its pure state. Since they are both birthless (aja), they are not created [udbhava, generated]. But those who are equipped with the vital force (asu), namely, the embodied beings (jivas) who are conditioned by their lim- iting adjuncts that provide shape to their sense of empirical selfhood (adhyatmika), are subjected to birth. It is due only to ParamÄtmÄ, the cause, who is endowed with both these energies [i.e., praká¹›ti and puruÅŸa] that the jivas take birth. lieninial à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¿ à¤²à¥€à¤¨à¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤£à¥€à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¥à¤¯ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤µ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥à¤šà¥à¤šà¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ qu) an 102 [During the period of dissolution,] the energies (sakti) called the jÄ«vas, who are merged in ParamÄtmÄ, are said to be pure because their dispositions (vÄsanÄs) are then dormant due to the dissolu- tion of the modifications of praká¹›ti. At the time of creation, how- ever, they are conjoined to praká¹›ti, which is undergoing modifi- cations. Their dispositions being revived, they relapse into the conditioned state and spread forth [i.e., manifest in the world]. de à¤à¤¤à¤¦à¤­à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ â€œà¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤• à¤†à¤¸à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥«à¥¤à¥¨à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥«à¥¤à¥¨à¥¬) â€“ at agated garell halbodas ori It is with this intent alone that it is said in the section of the Third Canto starting with “Prior to creation there was only Bhagavan: “7 à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¯à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤œà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤¤ à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥«à¥¬ à¥¥ mophotigu 7 When the equilibrium of the three gunas that constitute the The mÄyÄ potency was displaced by the force of time, the transcen- dent Bhagavan, who is beyond the senses and endowed with bhagavÃ¤n eka Ã¤sedam SB 3.5.23, Anuccheda 50 lil indham svo Albom svob 306 47 Two Types of Jivas His own intrinsic potency, placed His seed (virya) [i.e., His con- scious parts] into that mÄyÄ through the Purusa, who is His own 55 self-expansion. (SB 3.5.26, Anuccheda 58.4)8 à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿ â€œà¤®à¤® à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¹à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤—à¤°à¥à¤­à¤‚ à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¹à¤®à¥ â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥ªà¥¤à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ al 30 bua si atexiault of vino a Taldded to In this verse, it is said that the jiva, referred to by the word virya (“seed,” “semen,” or “potency”), was placed within praká¹›ti. Sim- ilarly, in Gitopanisad, it is also said: “The immeasurable material nature, called Brahman, is My womb (yoni), into which I sow the seed of living beings (garbham dadhÄmi)” (GÄªTÄ€ 14.3). à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾ à¤—à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¥€à¤µ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ The revered commentator [ÅšrÄ«dhara] has also explained that the word brahman here means praká¹›ti [because it is the material cause of the unfolding of its own evolutes], and garbha (embryo) refers to the jiva [which is a conscious reflection (cid-ÄbhÄsa) as the cause of world evolution].10 to tins ses bosseada nij gnola egiam yada ylisupse à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¥‡à¤· à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥¨à¥¬à¥¤à¥§à¥¯ ) - bas This is repeated in the Third Canto: 8 9 ava se to vas zalogale s die bos esmen troroltub risdt iod? as low asabog” as doura à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥à¤·à¤­à¤¿à¤¤à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¥Œ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤†à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤¤ à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤ à¤®à¤¹à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿à¤°à¤£à¥à¤®à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥«à¥­ à¥¥ ettilaup anoiros Bartolby at odw adjoini isins SH” ing up Their When the Supreme Person placed His seed (virya) in His IS own womb, whose equilibrium had been displaced by destiny (daivÄt), she [praká¹›ti] gave birth to the golden mahat-tattva. (SB 3.26.19)11 dal gimos envied to sasa ni as] ovoda aA tiesib lo so at ni navigste anoitet kala-vá¹›ttyÃ¤ tu mÄyÄyÄm guá¹‡a-mayyam adhoká¹£ajaá¸¥ bas “saad ji ne puruÅŸenÄtma-bhÃ¼tena viryam adhatta viryavÄn mama yonir mahad brahma tasmin garbham dadhamy ahamiel esswall to 10 brmhitatvÃ¤t sva-karyÄnÄá¹ vá¹›ddhi-hetutvad va brahma praká¹›tir ity arthaá¸¥, tana mahad brahma mama parameÅ›varasya yonir garbhadhana-sthÄnaá¹ tasminn ahaá¹ garbham jagad-vistara-hetum cid-abhasam dadhÄmi niká¹£ipÄmi. “daivÃ¤t ká¹£ubhita-dharminyaá¹ svasyaá¹ yonau paraá¸¥ puman Ädhatta viryaá¹ sÄsÅ«ta mahat tattvam hiranmayameld mebaut galtaiks 307II The Ontology of the Jiva - Tatastha-Å›akti à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥€à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤šà¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥‡ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ - à¤œà¤²à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Here SvÄmi explains that virya means the cit potency; therefore, his commentary confirms that the jiva is a potency of Param- ÄtmÄ. Hence, the example [in SB 10.87.31], â€œ like the appearance of bubbles on the surface of water,” is only to illustrate the sud- denness of the jiva’s appearance (udbhava) [and not its creation out of a conglomeration of factors].dogo à¤…à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤ à¤‡à¤®à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¿ à¤¬à¤¿à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤®à¤¿- à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤ à¤à¤µ “à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿â€ ( à¤›à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥®à¥¤à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥‡à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤—à¥à¤£à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾- à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤­à¤—à¥à¤£à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤¹ à¤²à¤¿à¤²à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¥à¤²à¥€à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¥€ Thereafter, at the time of dissolution, all these jivas along with their limiting adjuncts [again merge into You], who are the orig- inal conscious source comparable to the sun orb, and who are intrinsically self-endowed with the potency known as the pure jÄ«va, characterized as a unit of consciousness and comparable to a singular ray of the sun. Consequently, they merge along with their different names and attributes, their various appellations such as “gods,” as well as their various meritorious and unmer- itorious qualities, into You, the Supreme, meaning ParamÄtmÄ, who is referred to by the word “Self” (sva) in Åšruti texts such as, â€œHe enters into the Self â€ ( svam apito bhavati, CHU 6.8.1). (svam à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ â€œà¤¸à¤°à¤¿à¤¤ à¤‡à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤£à¤µâ€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤…à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤°à¤¸à¤¾ à¤‡à¤µ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¨à¤¿â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¨à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤—à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤²à¥€à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾- à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ bail diftups dmow nwo ald, svag [Htplay) ade (lovinb) As above [as in the case of the jivas’ coming into existence], illus- trations are given in the case of dissolution as well: “as rivers enter into the sea” and “just as the nectar of unlimited numbers of flowers is dissolved in honey.” The intention here is to say that even though they merge into Him by giving up their names and forms, such as [those of] gods and human beings, their fundamental distinctness remains due to their being factually existing [irreducible] parts of ParamÄtmÄ mahotsa 308 lab-47 Two Types of Jivas T à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤ƒ â€œà¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¥€à¤¤à¤¿â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ ( à¤›à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥©à¥¤à¥¨) à¥¤ Some statements from the Upanisads confirm this: “Let Me manifest names and forms by entering into these three gods, as the Immanent Self (ÄtmÄ) along with the jivas” (CHU 6.3.2).2 à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¥¦à¥ªà¥§à¥«- They do not bodies [Similarly, ÅšvetÄÅ›vatara Upanisad says:] à¤…à¤œà¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤¾à¤‚ à¤²à¥‹à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤•à¥à¤²à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤µà¥€à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ thus they web Pit is solanta à¤…à¤œà¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤·à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¶à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡ à¤œà¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤­à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤­à¥‹à¤—à¤¾à¤®à¤œà¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥«à¥® à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ³ There is a red, black, and white she-goat [“the unborn”] that produces offspring all of the same nature as herself. There is also a ram [the jiva, also “unborn”] who is captivated and enjoys sen her, but yet another ram [the unborn ParamÄtmÄ] abandons this she-goat as one already having been enjoyed. (SU 4.5)13 à¤®à¥à¥¦à¥©à¥¤à¥¨à¥§à¥®- [Mundaka Upanisad also says:] Tblugw à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤—à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥«à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Just as flowing rivers merge into the ocean giving up their the names and forms, similarly a wise person, becoming free from WE Haname and form, etc., attains the self-effulgent PuruÈ™a, who is behind the beyond. (MUU 3.2.8)14 à¤›à¤¾à¥¦ à¥¬à¥¤à¥¯à¥¤à¥§â€“à¥¨â€“ diledi at anied bouwbivi [And Chandogya Upanisad says:] 12 hantemÄs tisro devatÄƒ anena jivenÄtmanÄnupraviÅ›ya nama-rupe vyÄkaravÄá¹‡Ä«ti ajÄm ekÄm lohita-sukla-ká¹›á¹£á¹‡Äm bahviá¸¥ prajaá¸¥ sá¹›jamÄnÄm sarupÄá¸¥ 14 ajo hy eko juÅŸamano’nusete jahaty enam bhukta-bhogam ajo’nyaá¸¥ yatha nadyaá¸¥ syandamÄnÄá¸¥ samudre’stam gacchanti nama-rÅ«pe vihÄya tathÄ vidvÃ¤n nÃ¤ma-rÅ«pÄd vimuktaá¸¥ parat param puruÅŸam upaiti divyam 309 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-Å›akti à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¥Œà¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤®à¤¾ à¤®à¤§à¥ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤®à¤µà¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤°à¤¸à¤‚ à¤—à¤®à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¬à¥¦ à¥¥ à¥© à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤²à¤­à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤®à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¤‚ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¤‚ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤–à¤²à¥ à¤¸à¥Œà¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯ à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¹à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¬à¥§ || of h à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ fits to illustrate the sud- O dear one, just as honeybees extract the nectar from variouse] are trees of different shapes and bring them together to produce a single taste [i.e., honey], [and] at that time those individual nec- tars cannot identify themselves [saying], “I am the nectar from this tree or that flower,” so, upon reabsorption within the Exis- tent (sat), all these created beings do not discern that they have so entered. (CHU 6.9.1-2)15 Commentary IN THIS SECTION, ÅšrÄ« Jiva concludes the description of the taá¹­astha- Å›akti of ParamÄtmÄ. JÄ«vas exist both in the material creation as well as in the spiritual world. Their consciousness, however, is differ- ent. Those in the material creation are under the influence of mÄyÄ and thus are not devoted to Bhagavan. They are ignorant of Bhaga- vÄn and consider themselves as independent of any superior real- ity. In contrast, the liberated jÄ«vas in the spiritual world are in full awareness of Bhagavan and are whole-heartedly devoted to Him. This is contrary to the Advaitavada theory, according to which the jiva in the liberated state ceases to exist as an individual being, distinct from any other jiva or from Brahman. In Advaitavada, the jiva, or individuated being, is thought to exist only in the conditioned state. 15 à¸Ÿà¸­à¸‡ yatha saumyema madhu madhu-ká¹›to nistiá¹£á¹­hanti nÄnÄ-rÅ«pÄá¹‡Äm vá¹›ká¹£Äá¹‡Äá¹ rasÄn thesamavahÄram ekatÄm rasam gamayanti te yatha tatra vivekam na labhante’musyaham vá¹›ká¹£asya raso’smy amuá¹£yÃ¤haá¹ vrká¹£asya raso’smiti mno evam eva khalu saumyemÄá¸¥ sarvÄá¸¥ prajaá¸¥ sati sampadya na viduá¸¥ sati sampadyamahe whiy bito 310 Ilsbad 47 Two Types of JÄ«vas ol Although the jiva is never in fact born, it comes into existence in the material world because of its being conditioned by mÄyÄ. Birth, therefore, is only of its upadhi, the psycho-somatic organism. Because of its identification with the body, the jiva thinks of the body’s genesis as its own birth. bib In their prayers to ParamÄtmÄ, the Åšrutis state that during the dissolution, the jivas are in a dormant state, merged within Param- ÄtmÄ. They do not have physical bodies at that time and thus they can neither perceive nor experience anything external. When it is time for the next cycle of creation, the gunas of praká¹›ti are thrown into disequilibrium, and the dispositions (vÄsanÄs) of the jivas are thus revived. This process is described in an allegorical manner: ParamÄtmÄ impregnates praká¹›ti by injecting her with the jivas. The jivas are compared to semen and praká¹›ti to a woman’s womb. When a man unites with a woman, he also injects the jivas contained in his semen into her womb. 10 bod snoothie (2014) When it is time for dissolution, all jÄ«vas merge back into Param- ÄtmÄ, devoid of all names or forms. This does not mean, however, that they become one with Him and thereby lose their individual existence. The Åšrutis offer two examples to illustrate this occur- rence: that of rivers merging into the ocean and that of pollen brought by honeybees from various flowers to make honey. Once the rivers enter the ocean, they lose their respective names and forms, but this does not mean that the rivers themselves are lost. We are not able to distinguish between the water of the river and that of the ocean, but both exist separately, simultaneously. Simi- larly, although honey appears to be a uniform substance, in reality it is composed of parts from various types of flowers.ol even vedt Bot These examples should not be misunderstood to mean that the jiva and Brahman are one without any differentiation. If such were the case, then the jivas would not be able to take birth again in the next cycle of creation. When the jivas merge into ParamÄtmÄ, they lose their material identities. The examples of rivers merg- ing into the ocean and pollen into honey are to convey only this aspect of the analogy. The jivas enter into ParamÄtmÄ, losing their names and forms. They remain individual beings, however, along 311 II The Ontology of the Jiva - Taá¹­astha-sakti with their daiva (translated as “destiny” in SB 3.26.19 above), or karmic inheritance. This daiva is the cause behind the creation. ParamÄtmÄ brings forth the universe to mete out the results of the jivas’ past karma, which was accumulated in the previous cycle of creation. ritid nwo at an alasnog aybod adiÅšrÄ« Jiva cites various relevant statements from the Upanisadic texts to show the distinction between the jiva and ParamÄtmÄ even at the transcendental level. In the citation from Chandogya Upani- ÅŸad (6.3.2), the word jivena is used in the instrumental case, which implies that ParamÄtmÄ enters the three devatÄs along with the jiva. This is self-evident, as both the jiva and the ÄtmÄ (i.e., Param- ÄtmÄ) are mentioned separately in the verse. The instrumental case (in the word jivena) conveys the idea that the jiva is secondary to ParamÄtmÄ and accompanies Him.” The three devatÄs, under- stood from the previous section, are earth (anna), water (ap), and fire (tejas), which constitute the bodies of all beings.ad otni nomee 17 The quote from SvetÃ¤Å›vatara Upanisad (4.5) clearly states that there are two types of ajas, or rams, to be understood as the jiva and ParamÄtmÄ. The verse from Mundaka Upanisad (3.2.8) says that a wise person, becoming free of material name and form, attains the self-effulgent PuruÈ™a. It does not say that he merges into or becomes one with Him. 308REY HIS The last quote, taken from Chandogya Upanisad (6.9.1-2), says that (at the time of dissolution) after reabsorption into the Sup- reme Existent (sat), the jivas are unable to discern that they have so entered. Their cognitive awareness being dormant at that time, they are in ignorance about their state, but this does not mean that they have lost their individuality.s The example is given of honey in which the pollen extracted from different flowers is indistinguishable. Indistinguishability should not be equated with the loss of individuality. If we mix papaya seeds with black pepper corns, we may not be able to tell esitiinabi lansim led seol yedi 16 ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmi glosses daivÃ¤t as jÄ«vÃ¤dá¹›á¹£á¹­Ät, the unseen consequences [of prior karma] of the jiva. 17 sahÃ¤rthairapradhane tá¹›tiya lo Joaqas Hari-nÄmÄmá¹›ta-vyÄkarana 4.111 vibni mimer your arrot bus sman 312 47 Two Types of Jivas one from the other, but it does not mean that the papaya seeds have become black pepper. This concludes the description of the jiva, the intermediary potency. The basic points discussed are as follows:
  2. The jiva is the knower of the field of the psychosomatic organism and is thus called ká¹£etrajÃ±a.
  3. ParamÄtmÄ is also a ká¹£etrajÃ±a, but He is the knower of the field of all bodies.
  4. ParamÄtmÄ is the primary ká¹£etrajÃ±a, because He does not depend on anyone else.
  5. The jiva is an integrated part of Paramatma’s intermediary potency.
  6. The jiva is ever distinct from ParamÄtmÄ, both in its conditioned as well as liberated states.
  7. The AdvaitavÄda view that Brahman alone is real and that the jivas are merely a product of Brahman’s conditioning by mÄyÄ is not supported by scripture.
  8. The jiva is atomic in dimension, eternal, conscious, the ref- erent of the pronoun “I,” endowed with agency, knower- ship, and experiential capacity, imperishable and free of all modifications.
  9. There is a distinct jiva in each body.
  10. In the state of dissolution, the conditioned jÄ«vas remain within the body of ParamÄtmÄ along with their karmic inheritance, daiva.
  11. There are two types of jivas, those eternally liberated and devoted to Bhagavan (nitya-mukta), and those in the beginning- less state of bondage to phenomenal existence (nitya-baddha). 11. The nitya-baddha jivas can become liberated by surrendering to Bhagavan. In the next section, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va Prabhu begins a new topic to delineate the nature of the extrinsic potency, bahiranga-sakti. 313 sich abess sig Karmic faharitat am this toob koht hoo his date is the causinggay blondamise Peatbotinski bay buhab to houquet armew juns past harn volunt creation text to show the distinction betwes bled pdf to new seals and grase scale af mism sibod He to è¨˜ The dary To And fired every 20vit The st from Sepoyptare Unisa 14. suutensa yo bedrogque 200 that than coming becat Banditibnon add notuloseib to sja that fat the time of dissolution) after re sorption ante or Thed Sup Cosultive awarenes Dibbed-nyin sonstats lensmonang of agrono lo state anel they The example ged wriders navegada pat ven of honey in which the pollen extracted papaya seeds with black pepper corns, we may not be able to tell The Instrumental (Nimitta) and Constituent (UpÄdÄna) Aspects of Maya Anucchedas 48-55 III The Ontology of Maya - Bahiranga-sakti The Instrumental (Nimitta) and Constituent (UpÄdÄna) Aspects of MÄyÄ Anucchedas 48-55 T Alma ban been gil) shoul à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾ mediary (tapastha) potency of Param. The potency called intrinsic (antara- nga) should be known as previously [explained in the Bhagavat Sandarbha, cf. Anuccheda 7]. Now we shall discuss the potency known as “extrinsic” (bahiranga). (SB 11.3.16) of 1ster itin 1 but sadly ifgodila nobulosaib has 50 à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¥¤ à¤à¤·à¤¾ à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤¾- à¤°à¤¿à¤£à¥€ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤ à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ â€œà¤¸à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾- à¤¸à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤š à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤š à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤˜à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‹à¤ƒâ€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š â€œà¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¥€ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾ à¤—à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¯à¥€ à¤®à¤® à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾â€ (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥­ à¥¤ à¥§à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤—à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¯à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥€à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤®à¥ à¥¥ Bhagavataá¸¥ (“of Bhagavan”) here means “of ParamÄtmÄ,” who has divine majesty and power (aiÅ›varya) that are rooted in His eá¹£Ä mÄyÄ bhagavataá¸¥ srsti-sthity-anta-kÄriÅ†i tri-vará¹‡Ä vará¹‡itÃ¤smÃ¤bhiá¸¥ kim bhÅ«yaá¸¥ Å›rotum icchasi sidne stranu spo es vol einh 319 III The Ontology of Maya - Bahiranga-Å›akti own intrinsic nature. This potency, called mÄyÄ, which is oper- ative in the matter of cosmic creation [maintenance and disso- lution], was referred to earlier in terms of its incidental charac- teristics (taá¹­astha-laká¹£aá¹‡a). It is known as tri-vará¹‡Ä, or tricol- ored, signifying that which is constituted of the three gunas, as depicted by the followers of the Atharva: “The potency of Bha- gavan, which fulfills all desires, is white, black, and red.“2 That it is made up of the gunas is also stated in the GÄ«tÄ, “This divine mÄyÄ of Mine consisting of the gunas is very difficult to cross” (GÄªTÄ€ 7.14).3 Commentary US$5138 -(291 â‚¬159 OTF) first orgas IN THIS SECTION, ÅšrÄ« Jiva begins a new topic, the description of the bahiranga-sakti, or the extrinsic potency. This account continues till Anuccheda 55. ParamÄtmÄ presides over both the taá¹­astha and bahiranga-Å›aktis. Having defined the incidental and intrinsic char- acteristics of the taá¹­astha-sakti, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va now begins his explanation of the extrinsic energy, or bahiranga-sakti, which is the taá¹­astha- Å›akti’s field of action (ká¹£etra). This is called prasanga-sangati, or contextual correlation. The antaranga-sakti, which manifests the transcendental abode, associates, and divine play of Bhagavan, was already explained in Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anucchedas 13 ff.). The bahiranga potency is known by different names, such as praká¹›ti, mÄyÄ, and Durga. The incidental characteristics (taá¹­astha- laká¹£aá¹‡a) of the bahiranga-sakti refer to its role in the matter of cos- mic creation, sustenance, and dissolution. Although these func- tions are ultimately conducted by ParamÄtmÄ, who manifests as the three guá¹‡ÄvatÄras, they are executed in a secondary sense by the bahiranga-sakti consisting of the three gunas. 11 passt faire fifismug king (8910 Tafit) T odw “Emax to” anseman (“nevagada to”) dotovogoria aiH ni batoor erstedt (provÅ¾io) won has vastam enivib and 2 sitÄƒsitÄƒ ca ká¹›á¹£á¹‡Ä ca sarva-kama-dugha vibhoá¸¥ 3 Source untraceable Tons-n-dinle-hez dotovogod daivi hy eá¹£Ä guá¹‡a-mayi mama mÄyÄ duratyaya adam how-h 320 pichael ola sull fach fandtaylabaddishwanaofeng bas and brow did the grinniged.blogg.no fele pooled ad oral fyrstove moopdail van), the Self Anucchedas 49-52 places, hd Absolute solute Reality object Two Divisions of the Bahiranga-saktid) at made quite evident 15018 Idasce à¥ªà¥¯-à¥«à¥¨ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤—à¥à¤£à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤°à¥‚- à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥¤à¥¨à¥ª à¥¤à¥§) THIS MAYA also has two parts. In four verses Bhagavan describes the mutual difference between the instrumental part (nimitta- amÅ›a), called mÄyÄ, in the form of the gunas, and the constituent part (upÄdÄna-aá¹Å›a), called pradhana, in the form of primordial matter: à¤…à¤¥ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤œà¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤­à¥à¤°à¤®à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¬à¥© à¥¥ mos imava 980 979W I shall now explain to you the principles of SÃ¤nkhya as estab- lished by the teachers of the past, realizing which a per- son should immediately give up the delusion of difference. Here, ‘consciousness’ (jÃ±Äna) refers to the seer (draá¹£á¹­Ä), with which the totality of pre- sentational phenomena (artha) in the form of the seen (dá¹›Å›ya) were one only, without any differentiation whatsoever (avika- lpita), meaning that [seer and seen] were in complete identity in Brahman.” à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‡ à¤š â€œà¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤• à¤†à¤¸à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤—à¥à¤° à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥«à¥¤à¥¨à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ " à¤µà¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿â€ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§ à¥¨ à¥¤à¥§à¥§) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¦à¥- à¤­à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ â€œà¤à¤· à¤¸à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¥¤ â€œà¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤°à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¾ à¤®à¤¯à¤¾â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥ªà¥¤à¥¨à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥ˆà¤µ à¥¤dagrom 30 notienidmo od] to a 3o s 2 won’t on shima, dught wilho asij jÃ±Änam atho artha ekam evÃ¤vikalpitam yada viveka-nipunÄƒ adau ká¹›ta-yuge’yuge tai ant diguord Imingens ndio ohanmug nybitty boy 322 49-52 Two Divisions of the Bahiranga-Å›akti That [Reality] which is here referred to [by ÅšrÄ«dhara in his com- mentary] as Brahman is the same [Truth] referred to as Bhaga- vÃ¤n in the verse of the Third Canto, “Prior to the world appear- ance, there was only the all-pervading Complete Person (Bhaga- vÃ¤n), the Self of all selves” (SB 3.5.23). In both places, the object of exposition is verily the same one Reality, as stated in the verse: “Those who have realized Absolute Reality, which is nondual consciousness (advaya-jÃ±Äna), refer to It as Brahman, Param- ÄtmÄ, and Bhagavan” (SB 1.2.11). This will be made quite evident at the end of this chapter [SB 11.24], where that Reality is clearly [described] as existing in the form of Bhagavan, with the words “[has been explained] by Me, who am the witness of the ‘such- ness’ of cause and effect [or of consciousness and phenomena]” (paravara-dá¹›Å›a maya): “Thus, the process of SÃ¤nkhya, which cuts all the knots of doubt, has been explained through positive and negative inferential insight by Me [Bhagavan], who am the witness of the ‘suchness’ of cause and effect [or of consciousness and phenomena]” (SB 11.24.29).5 à¤•à¤¦à¤¾ ? à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¹-à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤†à¤¦à¥Œ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¯à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤£à¤¾ à¤œà¤¨à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ In anticipation of the question, “When [were the seer and seen one without distinction]?” Bhagavan responds [in SB 11.24.2], “In the beginning, during Satyayuga, when discrimination was highly evolved; and in that interim period (ayuga), i.e., during the period of dissolution prior to the new cycle of yugas.” à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥ªà¥¤à¥©- [It is further said:] à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤«à¤²à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤•à¥‡à¤µà¤²à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤—à¥‹à¤šà¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾ à¤¸à¤®à¤­à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¤à¥ || à¥§à¥¬à¥« à¥¤à¥¤ 3 bhagavÃ¤n eka asedam agra ÄtmÄtmanÄm vibhuá¸¥ vadanti tat tattva-vidas tattvam yaj jÃ±Änam advayam 5 brahmeti paramatmeti bhagavan iti sabdyate barved esa sankhya-vidhiá¸¥ proktaá¸¥ samsaya-granthi-bhedanaá¸¥o ni gaile JÃœ pratilomÃ¤nulomabhyaá¹ paravara-dá¹›Å›a mayai eldingssung smosed 323 III The Ontology of Maya - Bahiranga-Å›akti That one great (bá¹›hat) undivided and singular Truth, which is beyond speech and mind, was divided into two in the form of Its mayÃ¤ [the perceptible world] and Its result [Its individuated expansions, the jivas]. (SB 11.24.3) à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾ à¤š - à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥ƒà¤¹à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤µà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤—à¥‹à¤šà¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤«à¤²à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¿à¤²à¤¾à¤¸à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤µà¤¾ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾ à¥¤ eved odw SvÄmi comments: “In order that the Great (brhat) Brahman could become accessible to speech and the mind, It became divided into two forms, as mÄyÄ and as Its individuated expan- sion (vilÄsa), where maya means ‘what is perceptible’ (drsya) and the result (phala) means ‘Its manifestation’ (prakÄÅ›a).” à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤«à¤²à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤›à¥‡à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤«à¤²à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ Here [in Sridhara Svami’s commentary] the compound tan- mÄyÄ-phala-rÅ«pena is broken into two [with the pronoun tat (“Its,” i.e., “of Brahman”) being applied to both the terms that follow], where mayÄƒ refers to the phenomenal world as an object of perception (dá¹›Å›ya), and phala (“result” or “fruit”), to a manifestation of Brahman (tat-prakÄÅ›a). This means that the object that is perceptible to Brahman is His mÄyÄ, whereas that which is a specific, or individuated, manifestation of Brahman (prakÄÅ›a-viÅ›eÅŸa) is the result (phala). à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥ªà¥¤à¥ª- Thereafter it is stated: 6 7 à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¤¤à¤°à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¥¤ ai has hovlove were in complete lÃ©nyone à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤®à¥‹ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¬à¥¬ à¥¥ tan-maya-phala-rupena kevalam nirvikalpitam [:bise nedut atal] à¤®à¤¾à¥¦à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥€ à¤¦ van-mano’gocaram satyam dvidhÃ¤ samabhavad bá¹›hat apo mais nos novapild The verse is read either as van-mano-gocaram, “accessible to speech and mind,” or as van-mano’gocaram, “beyond speech and mind.” ÅšrÄ«dhara here prefers the first reading. In other words, the One Truth is divided in two so that it can become perceptible to speech and mind.ng maridamolanolitong 324 49-52 Two Divisions of the Bahiranga-Å›akti boll of these two, the [one referred to in SB 11.24.2 as] “presen- tational phenomena” (artha) refers to praká¹›ti consisting of b two aspects [namely, cause and effect], while “consciousness” (jÃ±Äna) refers to a completely different status of being, which is called puruÅŸa. (SB 11.24.4) à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾ à¤š â€“ à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤‚à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¿à¤£à¥€ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾ à¥¤ vinb Here SvÄmi comments: “Out of these two individuated parts, tayoá¸¥, one is praká¹›ti, which has two aspects in the form of cause and effect.” buthandede and fresh à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ â€œà¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤° â€ (à¤µà¤¿à¥¦ à¤ªà¥à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥¤à¥¨à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾ à¤š-à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¥ Similarly, in Visnu Purana it is said: “O brahmana, two other forms, pradhana and purusa, appeared from the intrinsic nature of VisÅ†u, who is transcendental” (VP 1.2.24). SvÄmÄ« also com- ments on this statement: “From the intrinsic nature of VisÅ†u, who is transcendental (parataá¸¥), i.e., devoid of any condition- ing (nirupadheá¸¥), [appeared] these two other forms, pradhÄna and puruÅŸa, which were described earlier. The pronoun ‘other’ (anye) means ‘made out of [or through the influence of] mÄyÄ.”” lenists all Ila yd beinsgmosos al senols even al H voworl Commentary THE EXTRINSIC ENERGY, called mÄyÄ, has two divisions, namely, nimitta and upÄdÄna. The three gunas are the nimitta, or instru- mental cause, and pradhana, which transforms as matter, is the upÄdÄna, or the constituent cause. To explain this, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va refers to Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s instructions on Sankhya philosophy to Uddhava.ey on svisoisg audi bas nup-ovinz mi batentie ni 6 -de Sankhya posits that praká¹›ti undergoes various stages of mod- ification. Under the influence of Paramatma’s time energy, the livtite sd of sgbalword todt 9 8 tayor ekataro hy arthaá¸¥ praká¹›tiá¸¥ sobhayÄtmikÄ jÃ±Änam tv anyatamo bhavaá¸¥ puruá¹£aá¸¥ so’bhidhiyate viá¹£á¹‡oá¸¥ svarÃ¼pÃ¤t parato hi te’nye rupe pradhanam puruÅŸaÅ› ca vipra bisimlend 325 III The Ontology of Maya - Bahiranga-sakti material world undergoes cycles of creation and dissolution, like day and night. During the creation, jivas perform actions and suf- fer or enjoy the outcome of their meritorious and unmeritorious deeds. At the time of dissolution, the evolutes of praká¹›ti merge back into their respective causes and ultimately back into praká¹›ti, which remains in an inactive state. During this period, the jivas have no physical bodies and their residual karma, called destiny or daiva, remains with them. This daiva is instrumental in bringing forth corresponding new bodies in the next cycle of creation. Verse SB 11.24.2 describes that when the jivas along with their destiny and praká¹›ti are in the dormant state within ParamÄtmÄ, there are no divisions of seer and seen. This state is described in the Upanisads by statements such as, “In the beginning, there was only the ÄtmÄ” (BAU 1.4.1) 10 The word ÄtmÄ here refers to ParamÄtmÄ. The Bhagavatam verse 3.5.23, “Prior to the world appearance, there was only the all-pervading Complete Person (Bhagavan), the Self of all selves,” cited in the present as well as in the previ- ous anuccheda, refers to the period of cosmic dissolution. Because praká¹›ti and the purusas are all merged in ParamÄtmÄ at that time, it is said that He alone existed. His “aloneness” is only in reference to the material creation, which is non-manifest at that time. From the point of view of the eternally self-manifest spiritual domain, however, He is never alone. He is accompanied by all His eternal associates. In this verse (SB 11.24.2), it is said that praká¹›ti and puruÅŸa were one, not only during the period of dissolution, but in Satyayuga as well. How is that? It was so because in that yuga, people were fully endowed with wisdom, and thus they envisioned only Brah- man without any variety, as is proclaimed in the Mundaka Upani- sad (2.2.11), “This world is Brahman alone.”” People in Satyayuga are situated in sattva-guna and thus perceive no variety, as Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a says in GÄªTÄ€ 18.20, “The knowledge by which one sees one imperish- able and indivisible Reality in all the diverse species of life, know that knowledge to be sÃ¤ttvika.” 10 atmaivedam agra ÄsÄ«t 11 brahmaiveidam visvam 326 49-52 Two Divisions of the Bahiranga-sakti In verse SB 11.24.3, the word maya refers to the world appear- ance from praká¹›ti, and phala (“fruit,” “result”) refers to the jiva. The jiva is called phala, or the result, because it is the jiva that suffers or enjoys the results of its actions. Praká¹›ti itself is inert and thus inca- pable of suffering or enjoying. The word phala can also be under- stood to mean “aim,” “object,” or “purpose,” which would indicate that the purpose of the extrinsic energy is to unfold the individual self’s karma, as stated in the Bhagavatam (10.87.2). Both praká¹›ti and puruÅŸa manifest from Brahman or ParamÄtmÄ. This is made explicit in the next verse (SB 11.24.4). Here praká¹›ti refers to the upÄdÄna, or constituent, part of mÄyÄ. Although the puruÅŸa is not part of mÄyÄ, the residual karma or destiny (daiva) of the puruÅŸa is maya’s nimitta, or instrumental, part. It is to show these two divisions of maya that ÅšrÄ« Jiva has cited these four verses from the Eleventh Canto. The verse from ViÅŸnu PurÄna makes the same point even more explicit. Here again, praká¹›ti refers to the upÄdÄna part of mÄyÄ, and the purusa’s conditioned state implies its nimitta part. In the following anuccheda, ÅšrÄ« Jiva cites additional pramÄÅ†as about the two divisions of mÄyÄ. I take shelter in You, the prohibitor of mÄyÄ. previous action (karma) is the instrumental cause (nimitta); the same karma, when manifest as on the verge of delivering its fruit, is called daiva, or destiny; innate disposition (svabhava) is 1 kalo daivam karma jivaá¸¥ svabhavo dravyam ká¹£etram prÃ¤á¹‡a ÄtmÄ vikÄraá¸¥ tat-sanghato bija-roha-pravÄhas tan-mayaiá¹£Ä tan-niá¹£edham prapadye 328 53 The UpÄdÄna and Nimitta Divisions of MÄyÄ [made up of] the unconscious impressions left by karma; the jiva is that entity to whom these attributes belong (tad-vÃ¤n); matter (dravya) means the subtle or causal elements; the presentational field (kÅŸetra) is material nature [as a whole] (praká¹›ti); the vital force (prÄna) means ‘sutra,” [or the first modification of praká¹›ti predominated by rajas]; ’the empirical self’ (ÄtmÄ) [here] means ’ego’ or “I”-consciousness’ (ahankara). à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤° à¤à¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤·à¥‹à¤¡à¤¶à¤•à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤˜à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤¬à¥€à¤œà¤°à¥‹- à¤¹à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤°à¥‹à¤¹à¥‹à¤½à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥€à¤œà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤® à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤¹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¤§à¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤­à¤œà¥‡ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾ à¥¤ “The modifications (vikÄra) of praká¹›ti are sixteen, namely, the eleven senses and the five gross material elements; their combi- nation (tat-sanghata) is the body; the body is implicated in a con- tinuously repeated flow or series, like that of seed and sprout (bija-roha-pravaha); roha means ‘a sprout,’ whereas the karma performed by the body is like a seed, bija; from this seed arises a body like a sprout (roha); from this again the seed emerges in the form of karma. All this is [called] ’the flow,’ pravaha. I worship (prapadye) You (VisÅ†u), who are the ultimate or final prohibitor of all this [mÄyÄ].” Here ends ÅšrÄ«dhara’s comment. à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‚à¤­à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤¶à¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤¹à¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤£à¤¾à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤·à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‡ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥¬à¥¤à¥¨à¥«) - In this verse, kala, daiva, karma, and svabhÄva are the nimitta (instrumental) part of mÄyÄ [or the extrinsic energy, bahiranga- Å›akti]; the rest are the upÄdÄna part (the constituent ingredi- ents). But the jiva, who possesses all these properties (tad-vÄn), is made up of both. A part of the instrumental potency (nimitta- Å›akti) also proceeds correspondingly into the set of constituent ingredients (upÄdÄna), such as the “I”-consciousness (aham- bhava) of the jiva entering into the element called aham, which characterizes the limitation (upadhi) of the jiva. (SB 3.6.25)3 | STER à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° â€œà¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¹à¤™à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹ à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾ à¤…à¤¹à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾” à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾ à¤š à¥¤ 22013 ftsds bog asansa devels SvÄmi comments on this: “The word ÄtmÄnam (the individuated self) here means the ego (ahankara) [of the virat-purusa]; the word abhimana (‘self-identity’) [is a name for the god] Rudra. ‘Along with his active sense’ (karmaá¹‡Ä) means through the function of the “I”-awareness (aham-vá¹›tti).”) onges solilybod gida à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤š à¤¯à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥€- à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ [byom] aidt Is to [This verse is part of a series of verses that all follow the same pattern. To understand these verses, one must follow the guid- ing principles set forth by Sridhara SvÄmi in his commentary to the beginning verse of the section (SB 3.6.12). ÅšrÄ« Jiva’s expla- nation here is with reference to these guidelines.] In any of these verses, the word that is qualified by the adjective nirbhi- nna (individuated) refers to the locus (adhiá¹£á¹­hÄna) [wherein the overseeing god (here Rudra) enters and establishes him- self]. The particular sense faculty, such as speech [as in SB 3.6.12, or such as the “I”-awareness (karmaá¹‡Ä), here in verse 25], for 3 ÄtmÄnam cÄƒsya nirbhinnam abhimano’visat padam karmanÄmsena yenÃ¤sau kartavyam pratipadyatek sarvatra yan nirbhinnam tad adhiá¹£á¹­hÄnam agny-adi-prathamÄntam adhidaivam vÃ¤g-Ã¤dindriyam tá¹›tiyantam adhyatmam pratipattavyam adhibhutam. b BhÄvÄrtha-dipika 3.6.12 330 53 The UpÄdÄna and Nimitta Divisions of MÄyÄ which the third case is used, refers to the particular psychi- cal, or cognitive, instrument (adhyatma). These points are con- cluded from the context, as has been done expressly in ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmi’s commentaries on this section. à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤¬à¥€à¤œà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶- à¤®à¥‚à¤²à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤¶à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤§à¤¿à¤—à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤œà¥à¤µà¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ Karma [in verse SB 10.63.26] is compared to a seed only to point out its causality. In this way, here also primordial matter (pradhana), which is referred to by the word ká¹£etra (“the presen- tational field”) and which is the root of the entire constituent (upÄdÄna) part [of maya], is understood to be only a part of the original mÄyÄ. [When ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmi says,] “the jiva is that which possesses all these properties” (tad-van), he is indicating that the pure jiva is beyond mÃ¤yÃ¤. Commentary THE PRESENT VERSE is spoken by Jvara, the personification of fever. This may sound strange to the modern mind, but not so to that of the traditional dharmic culture of India. According to Vedic scrip- tures, even insentient objects, such as mountains and rivers, have personal conscious traits underlying their visible features. This needs to be researched by modern science. The eminent scientist James Lovelock created something of a stir in the scientific com- munity in the 70’s of the last century by proposing the Gaia theory, which holds that the Earth itself is a sentient being. But it was not a surprise to those of the traditional Indian mindset. In a similar vein, many common diseases also have personali- ties representing them. In Ayurveda, there are three ways to treat a disease, one of which is called daiva-vyapÃ¤Å›raya, or cosmic heal- ing. This includes appeasing the deity of the particular disease by ca. 5 trividham auá¹£adham iti daiva-vyapÄÅ›rayaá¹ yukti-vyapÄÅ›rayaá¹ sattvÄvajayaÅ› c Caraka-samhita, SÅ«tra-sthÄna 11.54 odi daidw 331 III The Ontology of MÃ¤yÃ¤ - Bahiranga-sakti chanting mantras, worshiping, or performing a fire sacrifice. This is similar to energy healing in the West.mani evitingos to Jes Bali was the grandson of Prahlada, the famous devotee of Nrsimha, whose story is told in Canto 7. His eldest son, BÄÅ†Äsura, was a great devotee of Lord Siva, whose capital was at Sonitapura. BÄá¹‡a had a young daughter, named Uá¹£Ä. One day Uá¹£Ä saw a hand- some man in her dream and fell in love with him. When she woke up and could not find her beloved anywhere, she called out, “Where are you, my darling?” Her friend, Citralekha, heard her and inquired into the cause. UÅŸÄƒ then told her about her unusual dream and that she was dis- tressed due to separation from her lover. Citralekha consoled her by saying that she would unite the lovers. She made portraits of all the famous contemporary princes, examining which, Uá¹£Ä was delighted to recognize her lover as Aniruddha, a grandson of Bhagavan ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. AloUsing her metanormal yogic powers, Citralekha kidnapped the sleeping Aniruddha from his bed in DvÄrakÄ, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s capital city. Uá¹£Ä was overjoyed to be united with him, and Aniruddha also enjoyed her company for many days, all the while concealed within the princess’s private quarters. HT The eunuchs guarding the princess were eventually able to deduce Usa’s loss of virginity when they saw telltale signs on her body, which they reported to the king. BÄÅ†a was enraged to hear that his daughter’s sanctity had been breached and immediately rushed there to punish the intruder. There he engaged Aniruddha in a fierce duel, eventually taking him prisoner. When ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a heard of his grandson’s plight from the celes- tial sage Narada, He was obliged to take up hostilities against BÄá¹‡a’s kingdom. This eventually led to a great battle between Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a and Lord Siva, who had come to support his devotee BÄÅ†a. During the course of the battle, Lord Siva released his weapon, jvara, or “fever personified,” on Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. Bhagavan Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a counteracted by releas- ing His own fever weapon, called NÄrÄyaá¹‡a-jvara, which easily sub- dued Åšiva-jvara. The latter then offered prayers to ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, from which the verse under discussion has been taken.des- 332 53 The UpÄdÄna and Nimitta Divisions of MÄyÄ The instrumental (nimitta) and constituent (upÃ¤dÄna) compo- nents of maya are being specified in the verse. Time is that which unsettles the equilibrium of praká¹›ti. Karma refers to meritorious and unmeritorious deeds, and daiva (or destiny) is the outcome of these actions. Svabhava (or innate disposition) is the unmani- fest state of daiva. Together these four constitute the instrumental (nimitta) part of praká¹›ti. The rest of the items, i.e., dravya, ká¹£etra, prÄá¹‡a, ÄtmÄ, and vikara comprise its constituent (upÄdÄna) part. Here the word prÄna (“vital force”) has been taken by ÅšrÄ«dhara to refer to sutra, or the first modification of prakrti endowed with active potency. SÅ«tra is usually subsumed within the mahat-tattva, the cognitive potency, which is commonly accepted as the first modification of praká¹›ti (cf. SB 11.24.6). The jiva, or conditioned self, is here said to include both nimitta and upÄdÄna, because it is delimited by both gross and subtle bod- ies. The nimitta part in the form of daiva, karma, and svabhÄva is located within the subtle body, which is a product of the upÄdÄna part of mÄyÄ. KÄla influences both the subtle and gross bodies.com ÅšrÄ« Jiva comments that nimitta also pervades the upÄdÄna cause. There is a subtle element called aham-tattva, or ahankÃ¤ra, which is part of the upÄdÄna cause, since it constitutes the subtle body. But the “I”-consciousness (aham-bhava) within this aham is a nimitta cause, being the agency behind all action. This “I”-consciousness is a product of the avidya potency of maya. This is stated in the verse cited from the Third Canto (SB 3.6.25). sdt at (atÃ¼rdÃ¼rlam) framele bat This verse forms part of a series describing the appearance of the Cosmic Body, which has three aspects, namely, adhyatma (the psychical, or cognitive, instrument of knowing or acting), adhi- daiva (the cosmic, or higher order facilitation of sensory or cogni- tive operations), and adhibhÅ«ta (the physical function, or object). Adhyatma refers to the ten senses and the mind, adhidaiva to the presiding deities of these senses, and adhibhÅ«ta to their objects. of The structure of all the verses in this series is similar with respect to the cases used for the three aspects mentioned above. 6 tebhyaá¸¥ samabhavat sutraá¹ mahÃ¤n sÃ¼trena samyutaá¸¥dinongent tato vikurvato jÄto yo’hankaro vimohanaá¸¥ 333 III The Ontology of Maya - Bahiranga-sakti ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmi, while commenting on the first of them (SB 3.6.12), explains that each verse describes one of the Cosmic Person’s senses. As an example, the following verse can be considered:me The guardian of the world, Agni, entered the seat of the individ- uated mouth [of the Cosmic Person] along with a portion of his [Agni’s] power of speech, by means of which the jiva is endowed with the sense of what is to be said. (SB 3.6.12)” The god whose name is mentioned in each verse (such as Agni here) and placed in the nominative case, is the adhidaiva, or the presiding deity of a particular sense faculty, who facilitates and governs its function. The bodily part named in each verse, e.g., the mouth, which is placed in the accusative case and modified by the word nirbhinna (“individuated” or “separated”), refers to the locus (adhiá¹£á¹­hÄna) of that sense. The sense faculty itself, e.g., vÄcÄ (“along with the power of speech”), which is in the instrumental case, is the adhyatma (the psychical, or cognitive, instrument of knowing or acting). The task that is to be accomplished, e.g., vakta- vya, “that which is to be spoken,” i.e., the spoken word, is the adhi- bhÅ«ta (the physical function). In conclusion, the physical organ, such as the mouth, is the locus, the presiding deity of the sense faculty is the adhidaiva, the sense faculty that functions through the physical organ with the assistance of the presiding deity is the adhyatma, and the physical function related to a particular gross element (mahÄbhÅ«ta) is the adhibhÅ«ta. lo According to this scheme, the word ÄtmÄnam (the individuated self) in SB 3.6.25 is the seat (adhiá¹£á¹­hÄna) and has thus been under- stood as ahankÃ¤ra, or the material element of ego, that evolves out of the mahat-tattva. Abhimana (self-identity) is the presiding deity (adhidaiva), Rudra, who takes his seat in this aharkÄra. Karmaá¹‡Ä, which is in the instrumental case, is the psychical instrument (adhyatma), here referring to aham-vá¹›tti, or “I”-consciousness, which also has its seat in ahankÃ¤ra. Kartavya, “that which is to be done,” refers to the physical function (adhibhÅ«ta) that is meant tasyÃ¤gnir Ã¤syam nirbhinnam loka-palo’viÅ›at padam 7 vÄcÄ svÄá¹Å›ena vaktavyaá¹ yayÄsau pratipadyate 334 53 The UpÄdÄna and Nimitta Divisions of MÄyÄ to be accomplished. The ahankÃ¤ra, which is a material element, is the upÄdÄna-karaá¹‡a (the constituent cause), and aham-vá¹›tti, which is the sense of doership predominated by one of the three gunas of mÄyÄ, is the nimitta-karana (the instrumental cause). The aham-vá¹›tti is within ahankara like an electric current in a wire. ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ« recognizes karma as the seed of the body, because it is the cause of new ones, which are compared to the sprouting of karmic seeds. The body can be likened to fossilized karma as well as to the source of further karma, which leads to the next body. ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmi cited the prayer of Jvara to show the two divisions of mÄyÄ along with their corresponding subdivisions. The intention behind this is to convey the pure self’s distinction from everything material, which includes the phenomenal “I”- consciousness. Next, ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va describes the two divisions of the nimitta cause. ply functions, word sphurotly bec Mind ha ther mentary) ley Its the state in simply blue

    O Uddhava, know that knowledge (vidya) and ignorancese f(avidya) are My two forms [energies], created by My mÄyÄ. the They are beginningless and cause the bondage and release of all the embodied beings. (SB 11.11.3)1
    à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾ à¤š - à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¨à¥‚ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥€ à¤®à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿- à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤•à¤°à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¥¤
    ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmi comments: “The word ‘forms’ (tanu) here means ‘potencies’ (Å›akti), because bondage and liberation are expanded (âˆštan) or accomplished by them. They are created or brought about (vinirmite) by My maya, being forms of maya’s functions. Moká¹£a-bandha-kari, though singular, is meant to be taken in the which I to

    54 The Vidya and Avidya Potencies of the Nimitta-kÄraá¹‡a
    à¤¨à¤¨à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥ ? à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥€ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤°à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¤¦à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾ à¥¤
    “A doubt is raised: If bondage and liberation are the effects of mÄyÄ, then surely they cannot be beginningless and endless [respectively]? To this, the verse replies [with the word] Ädye, meaning beginningless. Therefore, for as long as I inspire igno- rance, there is bondage, and when I bestow knowledge, then liberation becomes manifest.” Here ends Åšridhara’s comment.
    à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥€ à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤«à¥à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤· à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆ- à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥‹ à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¦à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¤à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤µ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤· à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤
    I
    T
    Here, “being forms of maya’s functions” means that knowledge and ignorance are factually “states of maya” (mÄyÄ-vá¹›tti). By saying that they are “created” (vinirmite), what is meant is sim- ply that they are manifested by mÄyÄ, which has unlimited other functions, because they have no beginning. In the same way, the word sphurati, “becomes manifest” [in Svami’s commentary], is to be applied only to liberation because the jiva is liberated by its very own inherent nature, and it is due to ignorance alone that there is but an appearance of bondage. When knowledge arises, the liberated state is simply brought to light. So, the intended sense is that liberation is the jiva’s permanent state.
    obat sor and windy Hadom
    à¤¨ à¤š à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ â€œà¤à¤·à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥©à¥¤à¥§à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¥‡ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤-

    litiquesliv
    One should not object that the general definition of mÄyÄ given in verse SB 11.3.16 [cited in Anuccheda 48] is incomplete, since it was not said there that mÄyÄ awards liberation. [Rather,] in that verse, it was stated that mÄyÄ brings about dissolution (anta),
    (moká¹£a-bandha-kari) does not agree with the modified noun (tanu) in number. It It should have been moká¹£a-bandha-karyau.

    à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¥‡ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤

    ged od
    Here it should be understood that the aspect of mÄyÄ known as vidya is only a gateway to the illumination stemming from the wisdom faculty that is a specific feature of the svarupa-sakti, or the intrinsic potency [of Bhagavan]. By itself, however, the vidya potency of maya is incapable [of bestowing liberation].
    à¤…à¤¥à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥€ - à¤†à¤µà¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¥€à¤µ à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€ à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¥ƒà¤£à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾ à¤š à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¥
    FTS
    DISTER
    à¤•à¤¾à¤°
    The aspect of mÄyÄ known as avidya [in turn] has two functions, called “the potency of concealment” (avaraá¹‡ÄtmikÄ) and “the potency of projection” (viká¹£epÄtmikÄ). The first is situated in the jiva alone, covering his inherent consciousness. The other con- tinually causes attachment in the jiva by inciting cognitions that are other than the reality (tad-anyathÄ-jÃ±Änena).
    Commentary
    292
    urige
    brow
    MAYA HAS TWO DIVISIONS, namely, upÄdÄna in the form of praká¹›ti or pradhana, and nimitta in the form of the gunas. The upÄdÄna part manifests 24 tattvas, beginning with mahat. Nimitta has the two divisions of vidya and avidya.
    Avidya has two further divisions, known as avaraá¹‡ÄtmikÄ and viká¹£epÃ¤tmikÄ. The first of these covers the true nature of the jiva and the second furnishes it with illusory knowledge. Here it may be noted that avidya is also described in Advaitavada as having the Ävaraá¹‡a and viká¹£epa potencies, but there the function of avarana is to cover Brahman and that of viká¹£epa is to project the vivarta, or illusory object, as well as to furnish illusory knowledge. In other words, viká¹£epa also functions as the upÄdÄna (or the material cause) of illusion.
    used avad bluatte
    338
    54 The Vidya and Avidya Potencies of the Nimitta-kÃ¤raá¹‡a
    InThe word tanu (body) in this verse is formed from the root âˆštan, meaning to stretch, expand, spread, etc. ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmi translates it as “energy” (sakti), of which there are two divisions, namely, vidya and avidya, which manifest liberation and bondage, respec- tively for the living beings. Both vidya and avidyÄƒ are forms of mÄyÄ, or the extrinsic energy. The compound moká¹£a-bandha-kari is in the singular, but should have been dual, i.e., moká¹£a-bandha- karyau, because it is being used as an adjective for the copulative compound (dvandva-samÄsa), vidyÄvidye.qmi na zem sviÄ® ITÄŒ and If bondage and liberation are produced (vinirmite) by mÄyÄ, as stated in the verse, then they could not be beginningless and end- less, respectively. To refute this, the verse says, Ädye, i.e., that both are anadi or beginningless. This, however, creates a further problem. Bondage is beginningless but has an end, whereas lib- eration has a beginning but no end. So how can the word adya be applied to moká¹£a, or liberation? To solve this, ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ« says that as long as ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a extends avidya for a particular living being, it remains in bondage, but as soon as He infuses it with the vidya potency, liberation begins. In other words, although libera- tion is the beginningless state of the pure self, bondage is the begin- ningless absence of awareness of that state. So, in fact, liberation amounts to the removal of this beginningless absence of awareness, an event which can be said to have a beginning.
    ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmi further adds that when ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ« says that vidya and avidya are in the form of functions of mÄyÄ, he means that they are actually two modes of the maya energy. The word vini- rmite (produced), is used because mÄyÄ, which produces unlimited states, reveals both vidya and avidya. Therefore, in reality both are beginningless. or the effect) and not (the lnvisible or the
    ÅšrÄ«la Jiva Prabhu also clarifies that in reality there is no bondage for the living being. In other words, bondage is not part of the essential nature (svarupa) of the living being, but is external to it. Liberation is thus intrinsic to the pure self, but it is not aware of this due to the power of avidya. When one is endowed with the vidya potency, the latter reveals the liberated state of the jiva, which is its inherent nature.
    339
    ein The Ontology of MÃ¤yÃ¤ - Bahiranga-sakti
    A further doubt is raised. The sage Antariksa offered a general definition of mÄyÄ in verse SB 11.3.16, cited in Anuccheda 48. There he did not include the characteristic of granting liberation as part of his definition, so it appears to be incomplete. ÅšrÄ« Jiva responds by saying that the function of mÄyÄ as anta-kÄriÅ†i, or “she who brings dissolution,” includes liberation, because that is the ultimate dis- solution. ÅšrÄ« Åšuka has elsewhere included liberation as one of the four types of dissolution (SB 12.4.38).
    themand ais
    ÅšrÄ« Jiva makes an important comment about vidya granting lib- eration. Vidya is a potency of mÄyÄ, which truly speaking has no power to grant liberation. This vidya is in fact a doorway to a higher vidya, the specific part of the intrinsic potency that is actu- ally instrumental in revealing the liberated state. Both have the same name, i.e., vidya, but are two distinct potencies. Liberation is not possible without the help of the intrinsic potency (cf. GÄªTÄ€ 7.14; SB 1.5.12).
    gai Åšri Jiva next explains the three potencies of the nimitta-kÄraá¹‡a and the nature of the upÃ¤dÃ¤na-kÄraá¹‡a.

    à¥«à¥« à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥‡à¤šà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤§à¤¾ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ (2TTO 314124).
    THE NIMITTA PART OF MAYA should here be considered in the fol- lowing way: That energy, which in its capacity as the effective cause (nimitta) is popularly known by the appellation mÄyÄ, is seen to have three dimensions as knowledge [cognition], will [volition], and action. Of these, [the first,] mÄyÄ’s form as ParameÅ›vara’s cognition (jÃ±Äna), is spoken of in the Third
    Canto:
    m. The
    à¤¸à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤— à¤¯à¤¯à¥‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤®à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥­à¥¦ à¥¥
    O greatly fortunate one, this very energy of the all-witnessing [i[ParamÄtmÄ], which is of the nature [of the recognition] of sat [the visible or the effect] and asat [the invisible or the cause], is called mÄyÄ, by means of which the Omnipresent God (vibhu) fashions the cosmos. (SB 3.5.25) gaines bored in a dipunri sob

    341
    III The Ontology of Maya - Bahiranga-sakti
    In his commentary, SvÄmÄ« writes: “This very [potency called mÄyÄ] is of the nature of the ’re-cognition’ (anusandhana) [of the distinction] of seer and seen. Here sat means the visible, and asat, the invisible. The word ÄtmÄ [in sad-asad-atmika] means having that nature. MÄyÄ is in essence both sat and asat because it is of the nature of the ’re-cognition’ (anusandhana) of both.”
    à¤¤à¤¦à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ â€œà¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥«à¥¤à¥¨à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ â€œà¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥Œ à¤²à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤
    MÄyÄ is spoken of as the form of ParameÅ›vara’s volition (iccha) in the same chapter: “Prior to the world appearance, there was only ParamÄtmÄ, who is the very Self and the Regulator of all living beings. At that time the Self was not characterized by the distinctions of seer and seen, since the will to manifest creation (atmeccha) was dissolved (anugatau)2 in Him” (SB 3.5.23). Com- menting on this, ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmi writes: “The will of Param- ÄtmÄ (ÄtmecchÄ) [to enact the creation] here refers to mÄyÄ, which was enfolded within Him, meaning that it was dissolved in Him.”
    cotton b[nobilov] llw à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤šà¥ˆà¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¥‡ â€œà¤à¤·à¤¾ à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥©à¥¤à¥§à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¤à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‡ à¤à¤µ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤
    [Jef ads]
    MÄyÄ’s form as ParameÅ›vara’s action (kriya) is to be seen in the verse from the Eleventh Canto (SB 11.3.16) cited above [Anucche- da 48]: “We have described this tricolored mÄyÄ of Bhagavan that creates, sustains, and dissolves the universe.” Q

    own will” would be the immediately transparent reading. Anu (in) gati (going) does have the attested meaning of “dying out,” “going into,” “being molda
    extinguished” (Monier-Williams).

    wn balles à¥ª) (imols 02 Isthnoming) tplong has (eggu Although ParameÅ›vara’s own direct cognition and so on, do not belong to mÄyÄ but rather to His svarupa-Å›akti alone, still they function in the world specifically for the sake of His devotees and not for the purpose of material operations. It is only inci- dentally that they also support the work of creation and so on. This will be discussed later (Anucchedas 100-104). The jÃ±Äna, iccha, and kriya that are aspects of maya are indeed different from those that belong directly to ParameÅ›vara, but being con- joined with a semblance of His functions, they are referred to by the words, â€œParameÅ›vara’s jÃ±Äna and so on.â€ guineam (motiven)
    à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤®-à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥‡à¤µà¤²à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥ƒà¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¤¿à¤¸à¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤­à¥‹à¤—à¥‡- à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤
    As such, ParameÅ›vara’s jÃ±Äna, icchÄ, and kriyÄ are of two types - one which is grounded exclusively in Him, being an inherent part of His intrinsic nature, and the other situated in the jiva, being bestowed by Him. The first category takes the form of the recognition of seer and seen [jÃ±Äna], the intention to create the world [icchÄ], and the cosmic influence of time (kÄla) and so on [kriya]; the second category is in the form of conventional knowledge and ignorance [jÃ±Äna], the desire for enjoyment [icchÄ], and conditional action [karma] and so on [kriyÄ].
    à¤…à¤¥à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¥ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥© à¥¤ à¥¨à¥¬ à¥¤ à¥§à¥¦)
    Now the definition of pradhana, the upÄdÄna part of mÄyÄ, is given:
